I'm coming from a Nexus 5 mind you, so I know a little something about crappy batteries. I'm a bit disappointed that this doesn't have wireless charging, but the quick charger is pretty handy. I did have a bit of trouble rooting the thing, and really had to hunt around for a factory image to correct my mistakes. This was a bit of a surprise, since finding something like that for the Nexus had been a piece of cake.
Solid phone. I like the near-stock Android OS, and the battery life is better than my S5 ever was.

I had a 1st Gen Moto X Dev Edition that I bought because I needed to keep my unlimited data at Verizon.  I dropped the 1st Gen and I needed a new phone.
This was logical choice for me.  It has ZERO carrier loaded bloat wear.  I don't have to worry about NFL or Verizon apps.
It is HUGE - and for me this is positive.  I like that I don't have to have a seperate tablet.  Back when I bought the 1st Gen Moto X, I really wished I could have found an unlocked Galaxy Note.  But now, this is the same size as a Note. And about the same size as the Amazon Fire 6".
I upgraded it to Android 6 the day I got it and it is working smoothly.
Screen is very clear.  Big plus is the MicroSD slot, that is so rare now.  Looking forward to a huge card to add.
edit - Forgot to mention, I just moved my Verizon SIM card over and the new phone worked instantly

Love this phone! Bought one for for my wife and one for me. Upgraded from a Samsung Galaxy S3 because we wanted a larger screen and a better camera. Processor is so much faster. Pure Android experience has been great. Was difficult to activate phones with Verizon due to Nano SIM card. We had the card but Verizon's database didn't recognize phones. It was as if phones didn't exist. Spent countless hours on phone and online chats with Motorola, Verizon's Customer Service and local Verizon store with no satisfaction. No one mentioned a SIM card adapter until after 2 days of discussion. Went to Walmart and bought the adapter from T-Mobile section and put Nano SIM card in adapter and into Galaxy and called Verizon for them to activate it. Once activation completed, transferred Nano SIM card into Moto X pure edition and all was good. Phone was not the problem. Apps are easy to install and operation is simple. 21 MP Camera - Colors are crisp and my wife has already taken videos and photos of hummingbirds and is very happy with the camera's performance. Two speakers are a plus...sound is awesome. Turbo charge is amazing! Who knew a phone could charge so fast?! Battery was down to 38% and charged fully in 30 minutes. Can't say enough positive things about this phone. Blows Galaxy away! Larger screen is fantastic! Main selling point for me was the phone is unlocked, meaning it can be used with any carrier without having to sign a contract. I didn't want to be under another 2 year contract with Verizon. Prices have become outrageous for phones and data plans. Would recommend this to anyone who wants a faster, more advanced cell phone! A+++

Update! After using this phone for a few weeks we love it even more. It is an awesome phone and we are very happy we made this purchase. You cannot go wrong with this purchase!
Super nice phone packed with features, would like  fingerprint reader but at this price point super happy.

A very pleasant device to use. As they say : 3rd time is the charm ;)

It indeed is a very powerful device compared with their earlier MOTO X releases.

Bright screen, snappy performance, as almost pure Android experience + a microSD expansion slot ..... What a boon for less than $480 :D

Only grip is that I wish the battery was larger ... say a 3300 or 3500 mAh one at least ;)

Other than that ... Perfect

I've had this phone for a couple of days now and absolutely love it.  Very near stock Android is great and motorola does a great job with operating system updates.  I really like the front firing speakers, i actually have to turn the volume down now instead of keeping the volume wide open. The camera settings on my phone were on wide angle by default. I turned the settings up to 21 megapixels and it does much better now . The "turbo charge"  charger  is great also. I'm using this phone on cricket wireless (at&t),  set up took about 10 minutes, the phone even automatically installed my APN settings .  For $399 you can't go wrong.
Exactly as described . excellent price. Only one little quirk. Some moto X have speaker distortion and this in one of them.

You've read the initial reviews, you've searched the web for more info from various blogs, and now you're skimming amazon reviews to get a good idea of whether or not this is a good phone. I get it. I did the same thing. Let me ease your stress with a simple list of pros and cons:

Pros:
- excellent LCD display. Accurate colors and very sharp. Very bright also. IPhone 6+ owners tell me this is a nice screen when I hand it to them.
- excellent performance. Snappy and rock stable, just like every moto x. Go to developer options and set animations to .5 for an even snappier feeling experience.
- solid battery life. I'm typing this at 10 pm after a full day of use. My battery just hit 15% with over 4 hours of screen on time, half an hour of calls. It will get you through the day.
- solid camera. Takes excellent photos. Comparable if not better than gs6 in good lighting. Colors are extremely accurate. Suffers in very low light, but performs well in all other scenarios.
- moto reliability. Everything on this phone works well with few compromises and almost zero bugs. The same can't be said for the gs6, note 5 or g4. Excellent signal reception on Verizon as well.
- unlocked. Seriously! This is one of the first phones to support all major US networks. It's a surreal experience using a phone with no branding on Verizon.
- audio quality. The speakers on this thing are awesome. Loud and they sound great. Headphone audio is also excellent.

Cons:
- almost too big for me. Accidental touches on the sides of the display during one handed use are common for me. I'm adjusting, and your opinion may be different when it comes to big phones. It's small for a big phone, but still big nonetheless.
- vibration motor is a bit weedy. Doesn't get up to speed enough for solid keyboard feedback. It makes the phone feel slightly less premium to me.
- slippery metal. It was the same on the 2014 moto x. When my hands are dry, this thing is very slippery. Tpu case is coming!

Let me be clear on this one: I would get this phone even if it cost $650. I've always loved moto, and their software experience trumps even Google's nexus phones. This isn't a mid range device or a cheap flagship; It's a flagship. Period. Get this phone. You won't regret it.

A little background about me: I sell phones for a Verizon retailer. I see the s6, note 5 and g4 (and iPhones) on a daily basis and compare them with this phone frequently. I owned an s6 for several months, before that I had both 1st and 2nd gen moto x.

I received mine from Motorola two weeks ago and have been happy with the phone.  Two things prevent me from giving it 5 stars.

1.  I know it is a stock Android issue but a restart option would be nice.  Right now you can only shut down and manually restart.

2.  Even though it is an unlocked phone they still lock you out of using the phone as a Hot Spot.  I had been using an unlocked  Asus Zenfone 2 with Lollipop and the Wi Fi worked without issue.  On this phone I get a message to see my carrier.  If I am buying the phone the burden of dealing with the Wi Fi hotspot needs to be handled by the carrier, not by the phone manufacturer.  I shouldn't have to load a mod to use the phone's functionality. Italy felt it necessary to support Germany and it ended poorly for everyone.  Just because Motorola is a big corporation doesn't mean it has to lick the boots of other large corporations.

It is a perfect phone if it is not for the unusual battery drainage. Motorola should address this issue in the next upgrade. I have used it for a month now---and I love it. Amazon delivery service is out of this world---keep up the good service Amazon. Just buy the phone and keep charger handy you will love this phone----pure fun.

If you utilize your phone's wifi connection, do not buy this phone!
When connected to wifi, you will not be able to receive calls and text messages. Calls will go directly to voicemail, and messages will never be received. Once I turned off wifi, I received the missing messages. This does not happen with GSM carriers as I also tested this with Cricket, and did not experience the problem.
I spoke with Sprint support, and they confirmed this to be a phone issue with the Pure. I previously had a Sprint branded phone, and this never happened (we even tested it again by removing the Pure from my Sprint account and re-activating my old phone). In addition, this phone would not even accept Sprints attempt to update my cellular network settings.
I then called Motorola, and their support was useless. They stressed there was nothing wrong with the phone, and the issue was attributed to my wifi signal interfering with my connection. Their solution was to change the signal channel on my router? When I mentioned this also happens at my job when connected to wifi, they suggested I contact my network team and have them change the wifi channel- seriously????
Because of Motorola's not taking responsibility for this issue, I will be returning this phone. In this age of data caps, a number of people utilize wifi, but I cannot be put in a situation where someone attempts to call or message me, and them not getting through.
Excellent Product!!!!! The best in the business!!!!
Great!!!

i like the mobile very much and its features also.But i had a slight problem, its volume button is not working.but the good thing is amazon is ready to replace my device,so im happy about it.Otherwise the phone is great.It has an excellent camera and is very smooth running.Don't get the 16GB.

This is my first android smartphone, I've had iphones for sometime, and I do not want to color this review with my limited android experience. I like the screen, which is large bright and appears to have good color accuracy. The phone seems to have a very short battery life, perhaps12-14 hours, but if I have a busy day, odds are good the phone is down to 15% by dinner. The battery takes a *VERY* long time (8+ hours) to charge unless you use a qualcomm quick-charger, which they provided (I forgot mine in a hotel). Most of my chargers are 2 amp models for iphones, which I guess Android phones do not use.

Motorola's software is okay, their camera app seems superior to google's own. The camera itself has lots of pixels, but without good light the images are weak. Also, the camera tries to apply a lot of color correction (white balance) without giving a user a choice (the camera will push sodium (yellow-orange) lights in fog until the whole image is grey).
Yes.

So I bought this phone about mid December 2015 and it is now January 2016. The phone works fine however it froze up on me couple times but the biggest problem is that the battery charger stopped working!!! So that is highly aggravating, that now i have to find other means of charging my phone.
Very very good phone. However, it lacks a fingerprint sensor and that hurts its value, if that is something you care about.

Bought it during the recent Deal of the Day promotion--I was looking for a solid upgrade to my 2014 android which was getting long in the tooth. Basically, this phone covers all the basics that I need: (Almost) stock Android, official Marshmallow update already released, gorgeous big screen, capable camera, and SD memory expansion. The fact that it's carrier neutral, unlocked and still fully-compatible with Verizon (CDMA & LTE) is just icing on the cake.

This phone is big, but not too large for my medium-sized hands. Still, I'd recommend against using a bulky case. Good thing there's an included bumper but I'm using a clear TPU case. I installed the Marshmallow update before restoring my apps & data from Google backup--everything restored fine (including homescreen layout--coming from a GPE device.) This phone really flies--minimal lag even with dozens of apps cluttering my Recents menu.  Camera quality is excellent unless in really low lighting. The quick charger is indispensable--I've gone from near zero to 50% in roughly 20 minutes. Battery life on the whole is pretty decent--Marshmallow doze mode helps when the phone is just sitting idle, but I suppose
other big phones (Note 4/5, iPhone 6S Plus) may get more usage between charges.

Overall, this meets or exceeds what's expected for a flagship phone in 2015, and is a better value than buying anything else on a 2 year contract.

I love this phone.  I have had it close to a month now and I am very satisfied.  The camera is amazing.  It updated to Android 6.0 when I turned it on which was a huge plus.  My only complaint about this phone is that I came from a Samsung and it had a bunch of extra stuff that I miss with this phone like SMemo, personalized text screen (pictures, colors, shapes), more distinctions in notification tones (different tones for all notifications instead of the same for all)...etc.  But I love the larger size and the moto x has special functions just different types.  When I turned it on and got ready to switch my stuff from my old phone to this one there was an app I could download on my old phone that transferred EVERYTHING  from my old phone to this one.  I also like how the phone asks me if i want to save to the phone or the card.  Overall I would recommend this phone to anyone.  I took it to straight talk with an at&t sim card and love the reception I get with it and I also like the fact that I could switch to a Verizon chip if i change my mind in the future.

I have had this phone for a little over a month and I have enjoyed the experience with it. This is what these companies should be doing making flagship type phones with the a budget price. I had a HTC One M8 and paid almost double the amount for it and yet this phone has higher level specs with far more additional features with a stellar experience such as speed, expandable storage, quick updates and the Moto Assist features.

Highly recommend

This phone is probably one of the best android smartphones out there. There are two complaints I do have on this phone. One is that the battery is not the greatest although Motorola's Turbo Charging does make up for this. The second is that the phone does get warm every now and then through heavy use. Other than that, I can't complain on anything else. For one, this is a Pure, Stock Android phone running 5.1.1 Lollipop out of the box with Moto apps on top of it. This phone is unlocked and even capable of running on Verizon. I don't know why it was difficult for some people to activate this phone on Verizon but mine activated on it's first try, guess I got lucky. This phone also rocks a 5.7 QHD IPS display which is probably why battery life isn't the best since most of the power goes towards that screen. It also has expandable memory so I was able to load all of my music, pictures, and videos with ease. The Moto X is aesthetically pleasing with the wood back and metal frame. Although the phone is not the thinnest on the market, the curved edge makes it easy to hold. The 21 Megapixel camera is a lot better than the previous Moto X but the clarity could be better. Low light shots is where the camera takes its biggest fall. The phone is somewhat water resistant too so it could take splashes here and there but it is not submersible. It not right to call this a budget phone, but more of a value phone because of the Awesome specs you get with the price. If you're looking for an unlocked phone with amazing stock android experience, you have to give this a shot.
Awesome !!! No strings attached !!!

This is exactly what I wanted a fast large screen phone (but not bulky )without a bunch of clutter by my carrier (ATT)
16 gb is plenty for me since I can add a 128 gb micro sd. Worked flawless right out of the box Motorola migrate worked as well.

literally pure android. super slick and fast. well worth to bought it.

This is an excellent phone.  I upgraded from the original Motorola Moto X and I'm very pleased with this phone.  It took a bit of research to find the right Sprint Nano SIM card that works. Great phone - I use it for international travel since my iphone is locked to the carrier.  I recommend getting the 32G over the 16.  Pictures from the camera are awesome and performance is really fast.

Great Phone. HOWEVER, it is advertised as unlocked to be used on any carrier, yet when I took it into VERIZON to have it activated, small glitch. Verizon will only support this phone if purchased thru them due to a deal they made with Motorola!!!!

Great phone with all the features I needed and wanted at a price that was far more reasonable than the other major brand flagships.  It is a large phone - pushing almost 6" - but that is a minor adjustment in my opinion.  I upgraded from an HTC One M7 (I keep my phones for at least several years) and am pleasantly surprised at the lack of bloatware on the X Pure, the speed and responsiveness and the intuitive layout.  I got the 32GB build and a 64 GB memory card insuring that I have plenty of space for anything I might want to put on my phone in terms of media. There's a lot of great phones out there to choose from this year. I have always been a bit of a purist when it comes to the android experience, and so I've never strayed far from the Nexus line. While the Nexus 6p is pretty impressive this year, I ultimately decided against it for the same reason that many people will buy it -- the AMOLED display.

AMOLED technology is beautiful and has some of the most vibrant colors that you can get. However, screen burn-in is still an inevitability of the technology. I thought I could live with it when I got my Nexus 6 (2014), but in the end I was very unhappy. If you read a lot on your phone or do anything where images will be on the screen for any length of time, burn-in will eventually find you. In my case, it was really bad and distracting to my everyday use.

So this year I decided that I was back to LCD if I could possibly find something that caught my eye. Enter the Moto X Pure!

While AMOLED is quite beautiful, I don't feel like I've sacrificed anything with this screen. It is gorgeous and very vibrant. The phone itself is a bit thicker than most flagships, but the curved back is pleasant to hold in my hand. I originally wanted a customized phone from Moto Maker, but I ultimately went with the plain white from Amazon to save money. It's still really pretty!

I'm very much pro-phablet, but the 6 inches of my Nexus 6 was just too much. I do have small hands, so your mileage may vary here, but the Pure feels so much better in my hands. I don't miss the extra screen realestate as I feel like I can actually hold my phone now without being constantly in danger of dropping it.

As for speed and UI, the Pure is pretty much stock android with a few neat little Motorola features that can be turned off if you don't want them. I haven't been able to trigger any lag yet and the performance seems great on every front that I've tested.

This is probably the happiest I've ever been with a phone and I'd definitely recommend it wholeheartedly to anyone in the market.

Unfortunately the phone lags uncontrollably. I was still able to pinpoint the problem. It is Moto voice. I contacted Motorola and they don't seem too interested in speaking about the problem. I requested a second phone from amazon and it suffered from the same issue.

I will update this review once i receive my third phone. This will be the finial chance,

My last cell phone was an S3, I had it for 3 years and it still worked kind of "ok". I was looking for a good cell phone for a while, but didn't want a Samsung because, even though my S3 lasted for more than 3 years, there was a time where it gave me a lot of trouble.
I have only had the Moto X Pure Edition for one week, and I'm already in love. The good things: It's blazing fast, no lag whatsoever, it runs smoothly. The camera is great, takes good pictures. The bad thing: I would go for the battery. It doesn't last that long if you are using it to watch videos or reproduce music a lot. With a "normal" usage, like browsing, chatting, it lives a lot more, maybe like 12 or more hours. But it compensates with the turbo charger. It's really amazing, like literally turbo. I give it 5 stars because I love it, the design is beatiful, it doesn't feel *that* big once you are used to it, and the minor complaint of battery life doesn't matter that much because it charges amazingly fast.

I haven't had the phone for a really long time of course.  It was something of an impulse purchase for me.  My son's phone died.  I'd been contemplating the upgrade because I loved the idea of the open-ness and carrier independence of the phone.  So this would just be perfect, since he could inherit my old Galaxy S3 (yeah, what a dad, right?  Kudos to Samsung and Sprint I just got an update a month ago for it).  This is definitely a nice phone.  As you can tell from the S3 I like to keep my phones a while, and this looked like a phone I could live with for the long haul.

I use Ting, which can carry on either Sprint or T-Mobile.  Sprint coverage is better in my area, so I ordered the correct CDMA SIM card and this phone.  Going GSM is reported to work fine also.  At first it was a little odd having such a big phone, but I've grown accustomed to it over the last few weeks.  I installed Moto Migrate on the S3, and, after getting the included version of said app updated on the Pure, it was just a matter of touch and go (before the upgrade they couldn't maintain a WiFi connection).  Easy peasey.

Signal strength is better than the old S3.  Battery life is MUCH better.  I work in what seems like a Faraday cage for cell signal (regardless of carrier), and all the searching for signal would drain the S3 in a work day if I didn't keep it charged throughout the day (yet the phone could last all weekend at home).  No charging and the Pure ends the work day around 85%, despite weak signal.  The screen is crisp and clear.  There's a little more glare than I'd like - maybe a screen shield (on the way) will help.  My eyes are old enough that the jump to qHD isn't such a bit thing; though a little extra screen real estate is.  The Moto software is fine, though I really do wish this thing had a notification LED.  I knew I'd miss that, maybe not as much as I was expecting and maybe I'll get over it.

The phone definitely feels solid, though the (I got the plain ol' black) back seems a little slick.  The included bumper cover broke pretty quickly and I have a case on the way for some protection.  Yeah that cover was pretty much useless.  I mean, it was nice of them to include it I guess but it cracked quickly right around the button holes where there's little meat to it.  Other than that you only get the phone and a (turbo) charger, plus a little tool to eject the SIM/uSD carrier.  Not even earbuds or a data cable, sheesh.  I've not seen the battery below say 30% or so.  The charging is quite fast, but probably I've not let it get low enough to really show off what turbo charging can do.

Otherwise everything about the phone itself seems solid.  It's always responsive, largely junk-free, and easy on the eyes.  Great coverage and sound.  WiFi and BT have likewise been solid as a rock.  Pictures have been few but what it has taken has been sharp and accurate.  Yes I miss the notification LED, and I wish the battery were replaceable (though that would probably hurt water resistance).  Hard to have it all but at this price it's great.  Still waiting to see how Motorola is on updates.

About the day after ordering this I found out about the Nexus 5X and 6P being released, and the Google Fi service (that would be great for me).  The 5X in particular looked interesting, but the lack of uSD slot is a hard pill to swallow.  I had a little remorse at first but I think this is a better deal than those.  I just hope that Google Fi will soon allow BYOD with the MXP, as it's one of the few phones that can do it no problem.

TWO WEEKS LATER

After writing this review, I called Motorola customer service. For a company that claims to care about its customers, they sure aren't friendly to those with disabilities. The first representative hung up on me when I said that I was blind. The second person, after being told multiple times that I was blind, couldn't see the screen and needed some guidance through the reset process, kept asking me if I saw the menu with the reset option. After 30 minutes of this, he transferred me to yet another service person who claimed he couldn't help me because I couldn't read him the serial number on the box. Furthermore, he implied that I had stolen the phone, and that's why I couldn't give him the number.
I ended up finding some correct instructions online, was able to set up the phone and am using it. It is a good device, but the horrible customer service and the fact that it put me in the position described above keep me from giving it the highest rating.
Reason for giving 4 stars is that the battery surely not living up to expectation.

Bye Motorola. Want an advice, never flip flop too soon, because your customers will tax you about it!

This phone is just what I wanted; a large phone with pure stock Android and a microSD card slot. This is a really fragile phone, however, so I suggest you put it in a case as soon as possible. I usually prefer to not use cases, but I really think its necessary here unless you've got the insurance (or disposable income) to replace the phone when the screen shatters. The metal frames around the phone also make it feel "premium" yet slippery in the hand. I dropped my phone while doing the camera gesture (which I've since turned off) and my Moto X now has permanent dents and scuffs around said metal frame.

Most of the software additions seem rather pointless to me, but I tend to be someone that prefers a pure Google experience, so I just turned off all the features I didn't need. The camera gesture, which is the one where you shake your phone to open the camera app, is useful enough, however, don't do it too vigorously like I did. I don't use Moto Display since this screen is LCD rather than Amoled, so I'd rather save battery life than to see my notifications easier (and, I also have an Android Wear watch that does everything Moto Display does, only much better). Moto Assist is pretty decent. I like how it detects when I'm driving and reads my text messages for me. Moto Voice is also alright. I like how I can change the "Okay Google" phrase to anything I want (I used "Hello Computer" from Star Trek V).

TLDR; Phone has stock Android and microSD card slot, Motorola software is alright but not that useful, phone is slippery, put a case on it unless you can afford to replace a shattered device.

Having used the Moto X Pure Edition for a while now, I can say there is quite a lot to appreciate about this phone.
Okay, so let's get started.

The design of the device is just simply beautiful and it feels fantastic in the hand. The aluminum rim and the varying options of back styles, as well as the camera and accents works really well to give the phone a sleek yet sturdy form. The metal rim surrounding the edge of the phone feels like just the right amount of metal for the device. There are plenty of other alternatives in which overkill the aluminum ideal (HTC, iPhone and the Nexus 6P), but Moto X just uses it to emphasize. The nice curvature of the back definitely make it easier to hold and maneuver during use. It took a little time to get used to the peculiar camera design, however it does give a sense of personality to the latest Moto phones.
One of the features that I love the most about this phone is the support for additional storage, via microSD. If you buy a higher quality microSD card, then it's major bonus to storage. In Android 6.0, the microSD can be formatted to be recognised as additional internal storage if you desire so. It is very difficult these days to find a phone in which supports the use of microSD, so I'm more than glad that Motorola decided to go this route. I personally got my hands on a 16GB model, which on normal terms would be irrational, but in this case definitely worth it. I highly recommend a microSD card with read speeds of 80Mbps or higher, but my older SanDisk microSD worked as well.
I find the 5.7” display to be crisp and vibrant, having 1440x2560 pixels with a 520 ppi pixel density. No, it's not extremely saturated or rich in contrast to the extent that AMOLED displays generally are, but that's okay. Personally I find AMOLED to be a bit overrated. They're usually way oversaturated (even when toned down to be more natural) making them feel unrealistic, plus they tend to get burn-in very easy. I am the type of person who notices burn-in right away, so that's an extreme downside for me. I'm fully satisfied with the fact that Motorola has decided to drop the AMOLED idea, in favor of IPS LCD instead. That's pretty much the main reasons why I stopped going with Samsung and earlier versions of the Moto X. I, for the time being, refuse to use any devices sporting AMOLED technology until there is somehow an improvement with the lifespan.

You can definitely say I'm not an audiophile, but these dual front facing stereo speakers found on the Moto X Pure are very nice. Probably the best that I've had thus far on a phone, given the balance in sound. They get very loud as well. Not many high end phones on the market provide dual speakers on the front, especially of this quality. It's a huge plus for when listening to music or playing video straight from the device. Normally I'd be grabbing for my headphones to provide better sound and audio immersion while watching YouTube or Netflix, but now I prefer doing so without. Since having experienced speakers like this, I can't see myself turning back toward previous ways of smartphone audio.

When it comes to the camera on a smartphone, it's best to take the MP count with a grain of salt. However, the Moto X Pure sports a 21MP (f/2.0, 27mm, phase detection autofocus, dual-LED dual tone flash) rear shooter and a 5MP (f/2.0, 1.4 µm pixel size, LED flash, 1080p at 30fps) front facing shooter. There are of course times where I miss a shot, but it's far from frequent. Two flicks of the wrist and it's open and ready to go in which makes accessing it so easy. I can't really say that I'm disappointed with the lack of laser autofocus in which you find in other devices like the OnePlus 2 and both the Nexus 5X and 6P, because I prefer to manually select where I want to focus the image to be captured. The shots I take usually turn out very good, being they're very sharp and close in accurate color saturation, contrast and exposure. Most shots have quite a bit of depth where older cameras and smartphones failed. This in turn makes life a lot easier and gives more to work with when using my favorite app, Snapseed.

The battery life on the Moto X Pure is relatively decent. It's nothing spectacular and to be honest there is no real improvement when comparing to past generations of smartphones despite being a 3000mAh battery. That is by no means awful, but it's just simply not that awesome. Yes it is possible to stretch it for a full day and possibly a little more with the settings adjusted right. However, it would be nice to see a bit more. The fast charging is just downright incredible and quite the lifesaver in certain times of need. It really improves the dynamics of the battery life throughout daily use, in giving the ability to quickly refresh in between times of busyness. Usually at work or at school, the likelihood is that you won't be using the phone that heavily and with Marshmallow (Android 6.0) it should last just fine. Quickly topping off usually means you don't need to worry about a dying battery before the day is done, so when given the chance to do so it's definitely nothing to stress over. Say, if you have plans for the evening after a long day and have already consumed a considerable chunk of the battery so far, you could always charge up right after in the time it takes you to get freshened up. It's a workaround compared to having a massive battery crammed inside, but a very useful one at that. The only concern I have is how warm the back gets whilst charging especially with medium to heavy usage. Most of the time I leave it in front of the fan to ensure it stays cool whilst charging, but that might not be suitable for all.
In comparison to the other options available at this time, the processing package in the Moto X Pure definitely keeps the phone working smoothly and fast. Of course, on occasion there's a little bit of stutter (could be due to software), but overall the phone is definitely sharp and fast. The use of the Qualcomm MSM8992 Snapdragon 808 processor (dual-core 1.8 GHz Cortex-A57 and quad-core 1.44 GHz Cortex-A53 CPU and Adreno 418 GPU) accompanied by 3GB of DDR3 RAM appears to be playing it safe on Motorola's end, but I definitely don't believe that's a bad thing. It ensured that the phone would do exactly as was needed with a lesser likelihood of future problems (overheating or malfunctioning). Keep in mind, Motorola is usually skillful with software/hardware optimization. Obviously at the time of release, the Snapdragon 810 processor was quite the risk regardless of how strong and secure it as proved to be with the Snapdragon 810 v2.1. As far as I can tell, the Snapdragon 808 processor provides a decent battery life through power efficiency, yet the strength to execute the demands you throw it at it.
One of the largest concerns when it came to the Moto X Pure was whether or not it would get timely updates. For a while before Lenovo took over Motorola, the Moto phones had received updates the fastest out of all OEMs, bested only buy the Nexus lines. However, it seems as though Motorola has kept true to their word and the latest version of Android had a relatively quick release to the Moto X Pure. That may or may not be true for other Moto devices, such as the Moto G phones and previous versions of the Moto X, but at least it's true for this one. Marshmallow seems to be running fantastic so far, at least I haven't had any issues personally. Of course it will never compete with Nexus (in which I normally love), but it's tagging along very closely behind. Hopefully Motorola keep this up for the future.
With all that said, there are two features that I do wish were included in the design of this phone. It would have been nice if there was a fingerprint scanner in the beloved Moto dimple (I love that Moto dimple), and it would have been nice if the Moto X used USB Type-C which is more “future proof”. To be honest I'm not really sure if that is even a possibility, but it would have been very appreciated to say the least. I'm hoping that the next generation of Moto X continues with the very functional formula used so far, but also includes these two features as well.

After owning an iPhone since the original and then to a 4, I finally moved over to the Android side when the Samsung Note 2 came out. It was a great phone for me for well over 3 years, but it was finally time to get a new phone. That's my set-up to where I was at when I researched my purchase. Next I'll share the requirements that I was looking for so you can better understand why I rated this devise at 5 stars.

Now, for my requirements:
1. SCREEN SIZE. My shift from the iPhone was based on my realization that I really needed a portable "Internet device" with a phone feature, rather than a phone that has Internet capacities. The increased display size from the iPhone 4 (3.5-inch diagonal) to the 5.5 inches was a game-changer! So, no "small" smartphone for me. This means that only the larger phones were of interest to me and that the new iPhone SE was not an option. This leads me to my next requirement.
  >>MOTO X PURE EDITION. 5.7" Quad HD display with 2,560 x 1,440 resolution. Very impressive.
2. PRICE. I've moved over to a month-by-month carrier (Cricket) and saving serious money each month. The downside is that I'll be paying for a phone up front. So, I set my price point at $400. I really didn't want to pay more than that for a phone. I couldn't see paying almost $1000 for a phone...if I paid that much I should be getting a laptop!
  >>MOTO X PURE EDITION. The phone lists at $399, and this was clearly in the ballpark, but can be adjusted up or down based on the onboard memory.
3. CAMERA. The camera on my Note 2 was excellent for its time. It was 8 MP at f/2.6. I was able to publish shots from the camera both on the Internet as well as on print material.
  >>MOTO X PURE EDITION. This one is almost overkill, it has a 21 MP camera and a f/2.0 lens! The software is impressive too! This is a 10/10 for me.
4. BATTERY LIFE. The removable battery on the Note 2 was a real benefit for me when I purchased it. Getting new batteries and changing them on the fly was seen as a benefit. However, since I rarely replaced batteries on my Note 2 and found the process of changing an internal battery quite simple, the changeable batteries are a nice feature rather than a needed one.
  >>MOTO X PURE EDITION. After 1 week of use, it has an excellent (non-removable) battery--all day and still power to last another 8-10 hours of my typical use.
5. LOOK. I like when phones look good. Why make an ugly phone? I'm not sure.
  >>MOTO X PURE EDITION. It looks amazing. I have the real bamboo back that looks stunning against the metal sides.
6. PROCESSOR SPEED. I don't do gaming so I'm not too worried about this, but I don't want the delay when I'm moving from app to app and opening photos and video.
  MOTO X PURE EDITION. With the Qualcomm hexa-core Snapdragon 808 with 3GB of RAM this phone is quick and snappy. Very impressive (but then again, I'm not gaming either).
7. MICRO SD SLOT. I'd rather pay for an inexpensive micro-SD card than pay the big $ up front for more onboard memory. While it's true the additional onboard memory is better, everything comes at a cost.
  MOTO X PURE EDITION. This device will take up to a 128GB micro-SD card. Sweet!

In addition, there are some features that I liked and/or was surprised about, but that were not on my "must have" list:
- Quick Charging. It has, what they call, Turbo charge. It charges amazingly fast. While I've not tested their claims that a 15 minute charge will give 10 hours of use, I don't doubt it. Very impressive.
- Front Speakers. The volume and quality of sound are very strong. Speakerphone is good and music is wonderful for a device that small. These are the best I've heard on any smartphone.
- Video Quality.
- Minimal Bloatware. This phone doesn't have the clutter from a bunch of preloaded apps from Motorola. It's a sweet, crisp Android installation.
- Water Repellent. I don't plan to go swimming with the phone, but over the years, my phones have had their share of battles with water. This is a nice feature that can't hurt!
- Hands Free Response. The phone does a great job of responding to my voice. It's easy to make a quick call or text and not even touch the phone. This is very sweet.
- Front Camera Flash. I've not used it, but a nice feature to use with the wide-angle, 5-megapixel selfie camera.

Downsides:
- It's not an iPhone. Well, for some, that's an upside. But for me, I would love the ability to connect seamlessly with my Apple laptop. The problem is, I'm not willing to pay over $800 for a nicely-sized, nicely-equipped Apple cell phone!

Maybe I'll learn more later, but right now...it's a pretty impressive phone based on my first week of use. Of course, my rating of 5 stars may not be the same as others, but I've tried to be open about why I rated as I did. I hope this is helpful to someone else.

If it weren't for the Moto X I likely would have switched from Verizon, I was so fed up with overpaying for phones that would work on the network. I was spending more on used phones than I did for the Moto X.

The phone itself has been nothing but great, I have had a huge variety of phones over the years, ranging from, iPhones to Android phones from many manufacturers including, HTC, LG, Sony, and Samsung. They all offer their own spin on Android, some were ok and others like the samsung touch wiz drove me crazy. I was excited to get nearly stock android with the Moto X and the Motorola touches only add to the experience. Simple things like the notifications from the lock screen is awesome and now that I have it I couldn't live without it.
Another thing that Verizon hampers when it comes to their phones is the OS updates for Android. I am excited to know that my phone will actually receive updates rather than just talk of potential updates at some point in the future.

So the bottom line is simple if you are looking for a great phone at a great price then look no further than the Moto X Pure Edition.

This phone is replacing both an iPhone 6 Plus and a Note 4. I've used the Note 4 for most of the past year, and the 6Plus for over 4 months. Both have great features, great screens, but both are clearly overpriced for what they offer.

Here's a quick comparison between those two and the new Moto X Pure:

Screen:
Note 4 - average brightness, intense colors, sharp, over saturated, great viewing angles, deep blacks, but with terribly yellowed whites. Considered the 2nd best screen on the planet after the Note 5. But I greatly dislike it. Colors aren't real, reading black text against yellow white isn't pleasant. 518PPI.
iPhone 6 Plus - bright, clean, sharp, well balanced, great viewing angles, not so good blacks, TRUE whites. 441PPI. (BEST FOR ME)
Moto X Pure - bright, clean, sharp, well balanced, worst viewing angles, not so good blacks, less yellow than Note 4, but not as white as iPhone. 520 PPI. Aside from the viewing angles (not important for how we actually use a phone - by looking straight at it), it is a terrific screen.

Body:
Note 4 - ugly, fake leather, sharp edges, scratch magnet on the edges, capacitive buttons, protruding camera breaks EASILY, easy to  hold, body to screen ratio is good, perfect thickness. Ugly home button.
iPhone 6 Plus - ugly body, TOO THIN - doesn't feel substantial, slippery, protruding camera, large bezels on top and bottom, extra large phone for a smaller screen. Ugly home button.
Moto X Pure Edition - excellent screen to body ratio, easy to hold, a bit on the thicker side but it actually feels nice. On and volume buttons perfectly placed. No home button as the phone KNOWS when you approach it or pick it up to use it.

Battery:
Note 4 - 10-15 hours + extra battery - BEST
iPhone 6 Plus - 10-15 hours
Moto X Pure Edition - 6-10 hours

Operating System:
Note 4 - TouchWiz Android - Slow, laggy, obtrusive, filled with useless features, only gets worse the more you use the phone. Slow updates or NO updates from Samsung or Carrier. Terrible Support.
iPhone 6 Plus - iOS - Fast, responsive, always up to date, no lag, no slow downs, clean interface, unbeatable support! Great features by apple software.
Moto X Pure Edition - Pure Android - FAST, RESPONSIVE, always up to date, NO LAG, no slow downs, no slow down due to extended usage based on older models, support by Motorola isn't the best based on other reviews; if you buy it from best buy or Amazon and insure the device through them, it should be better. Great, useful features by Motorola Software.

Features:
Note 4 - Pen is phenomenal and works as advertised. Camera is one of the BEST in a smartphone, but it's slow to launch, sometimes taking up to 10 seconds, and you can't review the photo you just took because opening gallery will usually FREEZE the whole phone. Happens often enough! No manual controls. Remote control feature is great. MicroSD. Fast charging. NFC. Low volume output through the earphones.
iPhone 6 Plus - excellent camera. FAST, FAST, responsive, always there when you need it. No manual controls. Very slow charging. Excellent volume output and sound quality via headphones.
Moto X Pure Edition - excellent camera, FAST, responsive, can be launched FAST by twitching your arm twice. MicroSD. Fastest charging available. Excellent volume output and sound quality via headphones.

Overall:
Note 4 - SAY NO to Samsung. Until they make a phone with a decent, fast, reliable OS, don't buy it. It kills the experience. TOO EXPENSIVE.
iPhone 6 Plus - excellent phone. It does everything WELL. It is always responsive and reliable. TOO EXPENSIVE.

Moto X Pure Edition - Excellent phone. It does everything WELL. FANTASTIC Price. Right now, there's nothing that beats this phone for its price. Excellent screen, design, great camera, fantastic OS and software. I see no reason to ever pay over $400 for a phone again.

Best phone out there! PERIOD. I tried to make it work with Boost Mobile but no luck. They will refuse it with a hundred excuses. So, I switched to Cricket Wireless and now it works like a charm. Can't complain, it's ATT network, best network ever. And YES I would recommend this phone.

Overall, the phone seemed to perform basic functions ok. For me, however, there was a LOT lacking to the interface because it's nothing more than the base Android software. I wanted to really like it, especially since I bought the 32G version while it was on sale for $100 off of the regular price. But, it just isn't the phone for me. By the time I added on my email accounts (I have a lot, including work), the battery drain from all of the Push syncinc of all of the folders was pretty bad. Sent it back after buying a used Note 5.

PROS:

- Comparatively inexpensive for a factory unlocked phone.
- "Android Only" with no carrier add-on software.
- Fast charging can pile on a lot of battery power quickly when it's running low.
- Marshmallow is available on this handset, well ahead of anything else out there to get this version of Android.

NEUTRAL:

- Style: Personally, I hated the curved back and the slippery feel of the phone overall. I would have absolutely needed to put it in a case, but I am not convinced that it would have really helped since the cases are ALSO curved.
- Color choices: There are a LOT of options available for this phone, and that's good. But, the sellers on Amazon sell them only in very certain configurations, and that is bad. For example: If you want white with silver, you can only get that in the 16G model. If you want the larger storage of 32G, you can only get that with the champagne trim. In order to get white with silver in 32G (my preference), you have to buy direct from Motorola.

CONS:

- Unlocking the screen felt "clumsier" because there are no hard buttons on the face of the phone. And, the sensors that detect your hand and such don't reliably turn the screen on to the unlock mechanism.
- The phone uses no hard buttons and relies on proximity and motion sensing to initially turn the screen on for unlocking. This caused the screen to be on a LOT because of various vibrations and motions, especially while riding in the car.
- Battery life is sub-par. Sure, the battery is removable and it has fast-charge options. But, when I'm not actively using the phone, it was still discharging much more quickly than any other phone I've ever owned.
- "Android only" with absolutely NO carrier of Moto enhancements. This makes the phone a fair amount more difficult to set up exactly the way you want or control things easily because there are no add-on shortcuts or convenience buttons.
- The immense amount of configuration options on these phones is great when you buy them. But, if you're like me and keep a phone for 6-12 months and then sell it, this drastically cuts into the resale value since you have to find someone looking for the EXACT way you have your phone configured.
- Fast charging makes the phone fairly hot if you're trying to use it while it's charging.
- Obtaining Marshmallow with AT&T as your carrier currently requires that you pull the SIM and allow it to use ONLY the Wi-Fi connection to check for and download updates. I also saw no discernible difference from Lollipop after the update.
- Apps are laggy even though there is no "bloat". Running applications side-by-side with my AT&T Note 5 showed absolutely zero performance improvement in the "pure" android version on the Moto X PE compared to Samsung that has AT&T bloatware and Samsung's TouchWiz interface integrated in. In fact, the Note 5 can run the apps with little noticeable lag compared to the Moto X even with power saving being enabled on the Note 5 and not on the Moto X.
- Headphone jack and power jack are at opposite ends. Yep, this is a BAD thing. Because this phone is larger, the best way to keep it secure in the car is in a cupholder. That means you can have EITHER the charger plugged in OR headphones, but not both.
- Power and volume buttons are all grouped together on one side. Although the power button has a texture to it to make finding it easier without looking, it's way too easy to press the wrong button. Power on one side with volume on the other makes it FAR easier to find the correct button without looking.
- Doesn't come with earbuds / headphones

Excellent phone, I'm really happy with it. It has a beautiful and large display, it is really fast, the camera is great (it takes a lot of details), the speaker sounds great. Also the Moto voice works really well, is easy to get use to, and it is soo useful (at the middle of the night if you forgot setting the alarm, you only say "OK Moto X, wake me up at 6 o'clock!" and its done without even seeing the screen).
Pros:
 1) Excellent display.
 2) Excellent stereo speakers.
 3) Really smooth on whatever application you are using.
 4) A strong main camera. And the front camera is good enough to take good selfies even on the dark thanks to the front flash.
 5) Until nowdays I have no problem with the carrier signal, phone calls or text messages.
 6) It has a micro SD slot! So you can expand your current capacity, you can have photos, videos, music and (on the last Android version) you are able to install applications directly on the micro SD card!!!
 7) It runs the last version of Android (6.0 Marshmallow), and Motorola always get faster Android updates.
 8) Excellent baterry charge, it is really fast. The turbo charger is great, it can charge your phone (almost with no baterry left) in no more than 1 hour!!!
 9) No problem with overheating.
 10) The sound with headphones it really good.
 11) The also great Moto voice (as I mentioned on the beginning).
 12) Really nice size, although it has a huge display the space is use very well. Compare to the iPhone 6 plus and the Nexus 6p (that have the same display size) this phone is considerably smaller.

Cons:
 1) The battery doesn't last as much as you want. Do not expect more than a day with middle (common) use and with 1/4 screen brightness. It seems that the displays kills the baterry.
 2) It don't know if only happens to me but, the active display (calleed by Motorola) it is not working fine in mine device. The problem is that you can't unlock the phone or see a notification (on the active display). I point that this only happens on the active display, with the default unlock and notifications of Android I don't have any problems.
 3) It doesn't come with a fingerprint sensor.

In summary:
 It is a great phone at a middle price point, you get a lot of things for your money. Remember that the Moto voice and the active display you will only find in the Moto X line. There are some competitors on the market and they are also really good (as the Nexus 6p), I think that the decisions will be made on the details (I need a fingerprint sensor?, I want the amoled display instead of the IPS panel?, I want moto voice?, I want active display?, etc).

That coupled with 3 gigabytes of RAM and their stock Android experience this phone is great but the battery life would be way better I mean with a 3000 milliamp hour battery you would expect at least be able to get through the day and pretty much no matter what I do with this phone I get 4 hours of screen on time which is okay I can live with that, but again I say I'm a little disappointment bunch for what it is its a great phone I can give it a perfect score because of the battery life so 4 stars.
