I was a product tester for Motorola phones from back in the WM days, from the Q through the Droid series. My last test product was the 2013 Moto X. While I never had many positive things to say about the previous phones, the Moto X was my favourite, by far.

I use a company provided phone, so my next phone was a Galaxy Note 4. After 6 months of an extremely powerful phone that was slower to use than my 2013 X, I decided I'd had enough. My only option was to buy my own phone that I could just plug my SIM into. The Pure Edition is carrier agnostic and unlocked, so I had no issues doing just this.

What a difference... all the things I loved about the original X, and more. I'd forgotten how much I missed the Active Display, where the screen pulses to show you what your notification is, and even lets you take a peek at it. The new X improved this ability by adding sensors that detect your movement to show you notifications. A simple wave of your hand towards the phone shows you the time, and what you're missing.

The always listening voice detection was another innovative feature of the original X, and it too appears to be improved on this one. Rather than trying to replace Google's already excellent voice recognition like other's have done, Moto simply extends it. Simply train a trigger phrase, and you can do all that Google Now offers, without having to even touch your phone to wake it. If you feel weird talking to your phone, there's a nice stealth option where placing the phone to your ear as though you were taking a call also acts as a trigger, for a more subtle interaction.

Finally, Moto includes a camera that isn't garbage. Moto's never been known for their cameras, and while not perfect, or on par with the Note and other phones with highly rated cameras, it's pretty good. I'm not a photographer, I just want to snap a decent photo quickly. Quickly this does. My Note may have taken a better photo, but the lag in waiting for the camera caused many missed shots. I can pretty reliably go from a sleeping phone to a photo taken in about 2 seconds. A quick shake gesture to launch the camera followed by a tap on the screen, and it's done. I'm still amazed at how fast it is. If you're used to Moto's old sluggish auto-focus, this is a welcome surprise.

There is zero carrier bloatware on this device. It's a nearly pure Android experience, with a few very useful touches added. I never realized how much I liked what Moto had done with this line, until I left it. Partially due to the lack of carrier additions, and partially due to Mot's commitment to early Android releases, I was pleased to see the latest Android 6.0 upgrade notice waiting for me on first use. I was still waiting for 5.1 on by carrier locked Note 4, nevermind 6.0.

The only downside to the phone, is now my wife and kids want to go back to the X, so I'm going to have to buy a few more.

I have an iPhone 6 from work, my wife has the galaxy S6. The Moto X pure wipes the floor with both of them. You name it. Call quality, responsiveness, the smart Motorola apps (yes, they all work. This thing predicts your voice and movements to the point of it being creepy.. And I have a heavy mixed accent ). Don't worry about the storage - put a 64gig SD and it will format it in a way that it will behave as internal storage. The only draw back is the missing finger print sensor (Apple bought the only supplier), but this device is so smart that you barely notice it.
I cannot believe I got this for $300...

P.S.
I work as system admin, and it's a joke that they give us iphones. You cannot do much with the iOS, and this device being close to base Android is my ideal companion at work.

Update :
Have had it for a couple of months now and still I'm love. Just awesome. It's official - I am a lenovo fan boy now - got their thibkpad idea pad and this is the second Moto X .
A few caveats :
- Battery is to be monitored. Make sure adaptive brightness is on and remove all the bull $$ Google account syncs.
- sucks not to have fingerprint password but the location and smart pass work somewhat. Still...
- I still think it's the best phone around. Just a superstar. Does not feel at all bulky - I put an average case on it and glass screen protector and totally able to use one handed (I am 5-8, average hand size - I have thick fingers but not long and I am perfectly fine w it so is my wife)
The Moto chrome sync which enabled me to text from the broswer via phone has been discontinued. Alas..

Discovered lately:
Omg the speakers are amazing ..
Call quality is superb on both sides
The phone took a few nasty falls w/o case and a little splash - no issues visible thus far

So overall - unless something major happens (which I'll update here ) YOU CANNOT GO WRONG WITH THIS DEVICE !!!

PS
Aparanrly It also looks super impressive in the hand, it was not a factor for me - rather I have been told by colleagues.
Best phone out there for the price.....gives other big name flagship store a true run for the money. Plus the battery lasts almost 2 1/2 days!
A perfect phone for 2015 and a good value for money.
We've got 6 motorola phones and they all have had to be returned for numerous issues.  Some have gone back more than once!
Phone of the year

Probably the best [nearly] pure Android alternative to the Nexus series. Updated to 6.0 Marshmallow on the day of arrival, and works great. Love the microSD expansion port, something that's disappearing from most phones. Bamboo finish is slippery, but that's why you'll have to get a case.

Extended Warranty covers accidental damage for 2 years.
Good phone and good battery life

Hardware:

I love the rubber grip at the back (black normal and no customisation in Australia). It feels great to handle with care as my hands are slippery and afraid/paranoid with slipping off my hands. It's the best big phone or phablet at 5.7 you can get. Just a tag fatter than what I really wanted (comparing with iphone 6 plus). Nevertheless is now my primary phone.

The speakers are great as compared to others but HTC one,8,9,10. Is the best as it has 2 front speakers, great for watching youtube. But if you go to the volume at its max, it will crackle and noisy, which a is a little disappointing.

Camera is great, happy about it if you do not compare. If you do, then is nothing special as I came from iPhone 4,4S,5S,6 Plus,6S Plus and Huawei P8. I prefer iPhone ones for dim or lowlight photography and a tag prefer towards Huawei P8 for others for front camera. But then the selfie on Moto X Pure/Style is the best out of those phones.
Waiving at your phone screen for time/notification is very awesome, loving it.
Battery life is really poor, but I have charger in office, home and portable when traveling, so not fussed. Turbocharger is amazing, a plus point here.

Software:

The camera app pre-installed is not good, so do yourself a favour and download a camera app (using CameraMX).
Motorola came with their own pre-installed Moto Voice, which I think is the highlight of the phone. Personally I think is better than 'OK GOOGLE', I changed it to 'HELLO MOTO'. Best slogan ever for a device.

I used it for 1 week only, so not too much I can comment, but definitely the POSITIVES outweighs the NEGATIVES. Hence the 5-star. If I am fussed about the battery, would be 4-star still. Best android phone yet. But would I pay AUD$816 for the RRP? Nope. This phone is best at $500-700.

Excellent phone!! I upgraded from a galaxy s4 and this device made me love android again. Was fed up with Samsung's touchwiz version of android plus all the Verizon bloatware made it very slow and laggy. This is very close to stock android with a few nice features added.

The Moto display feature is great, I never have to push the power button to unlock it. Also the Moto gestures for camera and flashlight are very useful. Moto voice needs work though, it is a nice idea but at this point it is just a slower version of the Google now voice features. Having it read out texts while driving is nice, but the voice dictation for replying is hit or miss.

I have noticed no lag whatsoever in the 2 weeks I've had this phone, i turned off the window/app animations in developer options and it is even more snappy. 3gb of ram and the 808 processor are plenty for daily usage. Also the radios/call quality are excellent as well as the WiFi receiver.

 Also,, the screen is beautiful. Extremely crisp and bright. Honestly I don't mind its not AMOLED,, but it would have made the Moto display feature even better.

I am not so picky when it comes to cameras, but the shots I get in well lit to medium lit areas are very good. Low light shots have a lot of noise. Huge upgrade from the S4 camera.

So far the only downside of this phone has been the battery life. It's not bad, but not great either. It gets me from 8am to about 10pm with avg of 4 hrs screen on time texting, browsing reddit/internet, some Spotify and Netflix. However the turbo charging feature makes up for the battery life, gets a full charge in about an hour or less.

All these great features with a $400 price tag,, Moto really hit this one out of the park. Let's just hope it gets speedy updates and a few years of them.

Not sleek and slim.  Curve design of the back makes the phone chubby & chunky.
The quality of 21 MP phone is a lot less than 13 MP or 16 MP iPhone or Galaxy phones
The phone is good, but the battery lasts about 4 hours with screen on. Good thing it charges to full in an hour or so. If the battery lasted longer, i would instantly give it 5 stars.

Fantastic "Pure Android" experience. None of those horrible carrier/manufacturer installed "garbage" apps. Incredible performance, responsive screen. Not awful (but not stellar) battery life. Below are the lowdowns on the pros & cons :
PRO - Pure Android, no Garbage apps. Silky smooth performance with that Hexacore processor!
PRO - Still has Micro-SD card support!
PRO - Large, Colorful, Vibrant 1440p screen. 70%+ screen-to-body ratio.
PRO - Rich, Stereo sound speakers. Loud, clear and spiffy!
PRO - Standard micro USB cable support (Lightning charge support as well. Full charge from 3% to 100% in 40ish minutes!).
PRO - Fantastic 21mp camera takes awesome pictures and jives well with the google camera app.
PRO - 5mp "Selfie" camera takes decent selfies AND has an included flash!
CONS - Bland design (but who cares, this model is about performance)
CONS - No notification lights (thats right, light wont blink when screen is off for notifications. Kinda bothersome to me...)
CONS - Why do I still have to press 2 buttons for a screenshot? Asus Zenfone2 had a nice "button map" feature where I could do that with 1 button if so desired...sigh...
All-in-all a great phone for the price! Carrier freedom (works on GSM and CDMA). I would buy the 16gb or 32gb version, save a few bucks as this has micro SD card support ($15 or lower for a 64gb micro SD card is some decent savings).
Great mid-range priced phone.

So far so good! I am still in the process of still getting things set-up. Just BE AWARE that if you upgrade to the new Marshmallow operating system BEFORE transferring the contents from your other phone, you will not be able to do it via Motorola's installed "Migrate" function. It was something that I accidentally came across when reading about the new features of the Marshmallow operating system. I had downloaded it but luckily hadn't installed it b/c it takes 25 minutes to install & I didn't have the time before we had to leave the house.

I didn't think I would ever want to get away from my HTC One series but my phone is aging & getting laggy & buggy so I really bought this as a Back-up. I figured since we didn't have insurance on my husband's phone & mine was becoming a bit unreliable we better have something in reserve in case of an accident & price wise this was reasonable for an Android smartphone (esp with the added savings of the Amazon Deal of the Day). I had never held the phone or messed with it before buying it so I was rolling the dice. Hubby's current phone is the Samsung 6 which I'm not totally crazy about but I know Samsung has their fans...

Size is just about perfect. It is larger than my HTC One M7 but I'm still able to handle it in my hand. The length of my middle finger to the first crease on the inside of my wrist is 6.5". The distance on my palm from the base of my thumb to the base of my ring finger is about the same size as the width of the phone. Since the width of the phone is approx. 3 =/- inches & the way I hold my phone is at the base of my thumb & the joints in my fingers it fits just fine. (I don't have particularly long fingers either). If your hand measurements are at least as long as mine you should be ok.

One other comment I will say is that the soft, rubbery back really isn't grippy to me. In fact it seems like it has almost a greasy feel. I put a TPU cover on my phone anyway & I opted for the white back so that the color was neutral & wouldn't darken the color of my cover. I got a light turquoise-y blue cover that looks like the color of a Tiffany jewelry box. Also, I sometimes throw my phones in my purse & I figured lighter colors would be easier to spot in the dark abyss that is my purse!

Pro's (so far):
NO Bloatware!! All that comes installed is Google apps
Size- I was wanting a larger screen & this fits the bill without the phone being overly huge
Love the feature of the double twist of the wrist opening the camera.
The double shake turns on the flashlight (I'm still perfecting this motion)
Like being able to set "Safe" locations which keeps the phone from locking
Separate Micro SD Storage up to 128GB
Quick, Responsive
Keyboard is great with swipe although I do miss being able to long press buttons for certain keys (like exclamation points, etc...)

Cons:
None really yet... will try to update later as I get a better grip & after I install Marshmallow

So there are so many great features to this phone I'm retiring my HTC to be the back-up!

FOR VERIZON CUSTOMERS:  I was still a bit worried about the Verizon activation process. Luckily, others had posted in the questions about how they went about it. I thought I could transfer my sim card from my HTC One M7 but I think they might have a size difference. 1 was described as a Micro Sim Card & the other was described as a Nano Sim Card. Anyway, when I went online to do it I got the message to call Verizon's Toll-Free number. I thought, "Uh Oh" this isn't going to go well but one of the other reviewers said to just go to the Verizon Store & get one instead of waiting to have one shipped. Another reviewer said that it could only come "from Verizon Corporate." I figured since the two reviewers were somewhat in conflict that the one meant a corporate store as opposed to an "authorized Verizon dealer." There are stores out there that you think are the Verizon Corporate stores but are actually just the "Authorized" type. I had no trouble getting the sim card & they installed it & had me out the door with the phone in working order.

Bought it used from Amazon Fulfillment and everything looked brand new. The charger still had the plastic on it, new. Saved myself $100.

The 16 GB model isn't enough. I haven't formatted my SD as internal space yet, so my complaints may be void once I do, but the 64 bit processor requires more than double the cache meaning each app install size is at least triple it's download size. Motorola, in their infinite wisdom, also has 4 gigs locked out for the OS, but only uses 2 of it. The end result is this 16 gig phone has less than 10 gigs of usable space, and the extra storage needed for the 64 bit coding leaves under 2 gigs free with all my apps installed. Compare this with my old 16 gig Sony, all else being equal, which had close to 7 gigs free. If you root it, you can shove a bunch of apps into System and free up some space, but that's not the most elegant solution. Just stay away from the 16 gig.
Excellent Phone.  Works 4G in Latinamerica and US as well.  Unlocked!!

Just received my new Moto X Pure today.....I had been going back and forth between it and the Nexus 6P....The Moto was my choice due to expanding storage, and the overall footprint. I haven't had the chance to fire it up yet, but I will say this......for those of you wondering if it is too large.....get that out of your mind.....I have normal size hands and it feels great.....I'm moving from a galaxy s4 and the size difference is not even noticeable due to the ergonomics of this phone......My wife has the Nexus 6 and my kids have the Nexus 5.....the 6 was too big for me and I wanted a QHD display, so the Moto X Pure fit the bill.....I will write my full thoughts after Christmas when I can officially get it up and running....

Just a follow up.....finally got a chance to fire up the new Moto X Pure......what a beautiful piece of work.....the size is perfect for one handed use.....the screen if perfect....no, it does pop out like amoled, but it's truer to natural colors. The camera is great...I've read the reviews, and yes, its not the best in low light, but the pictures in normal condition room lighting and outdoors are fantastic. Phone was at 35% and fully charged to 100% in about 30 minutes. As soon as I turned it on, it was ready to update to Android 6.0.....Updating and downloading along with some you tube and web surfing and it certainly does not run hot......Great phone, The only complaint I have is with Motorola. I tried to purchase the Moto Care extended warranty and it said my time limit was expired....I just purchased it on Dec 17 and it is Dec 25....well within the time frame.....will try to contact Motorola tommorrow.......as far as the phone itself.....if you have any hesitations, put them aside....its fast, its very ergonomic, screen is great, reception is great, speakers are fantastic, and the camera is very good.....BUY IT.....You wont regret it...

Another follow up, lol.....after updating to Android 6.0, my battery life is great....yesterday, I used my phone excessively for me, I took quite a few pics, surfed the web, and watched some you tube.....I turned it on at approximately 6 am and at 10 pm, I still had 28% battery....Still not any sign of running hot, even downloading, watching movies....maybe a little warm, but thats to be expected, but it certainly is not what I would even consider HOT...
Perfect android phone. Not only equipted with excellent camera but also has satisfying battery. Better than my last HTC phone. By the the way HTC is nice but the battery is not very good.
The only downside i noticed was I can't use internet while on a call.

This is a great phone for the price.  The features for hands free driving and quick flicks to turn on the camera are a nice touch.  Battery handles my clicker hero addiction quite well.  The wood back is substantial and an eye catcher.  I am even impressed with the size which isn't too big at all.  The camera takes pretty good pictures in lighted areas, but can blur pictures in low light.

The phone doesn't have a finger print scanner or QI charging, but I don't think I will miss them.  The talking to your phone works well, but I will use it sparingly.  It makes me feel like a jerk when I use it in a crowded room.
It sucked

Just got mine today.  I was so anxious before it arrived, bc I had high standards for the camera..... I was disappointed...  Camera is NICE,  but my s6 edge somehow beats it.  I've only owned it for a few hours, so maybe I'm jumping the gun.  BIG CONS-can't change the font unless you root the phone, which I have no clue on how to do...2. Not many settings/options for message display, like the Samsung line has.  PROS-big, beautiful display,  gorgeous colors,  next to no lag when taking pictures or from app to app,  page to page, loading pages... Like I said,  I might be too critical too soon.  If I still feel this way in a week, I'll return it and take the plunge into the note 5. Battery test incomplete,  will add edit update later on.  For right now,  I'd rate it 7/10. Value wise,  for the $399.00, definitely worth the money.
UPDATE-9/17/15, returned the phone, continual bad pictures, battery average, not like Motorola claimed battery to be exceptional. Waiting for my Amazon refund before I can buy the note 5. Unit sent back 9/17/15, today is 9/19, still waiting....by the way, I'm on AT&T contract, and had no problem activating, just put the nano SIM in and was off and running... VERIZON AND SPRINT USERS- check with them before buying, ive been hearing rumors of them being able to activate this unit on the networks, been hearing that it can't ....
Great phone. Just gets hot sometimes. Other than that, the quick actions are useful.

Pretty fast and snappy out of the box. Feels very large in hand; this is slightly mitigated by the ergonomic design. I'm mostly neutral on the size difference and I knew what I was getting into but I would have preferred something smaller coming from a first gen Moto X. Chop for light and camera motions are pretty cool.

Bottom speaker grill was loose right out of the box and fell off after some use so I returned it the day after I received it. Motorola seems to have some serious quality issues if they let something obvious like a speaker grill get past them. Never had something just fall apart like that right out of the box.

This is why I prefer Motorola devices over everything else. Its a heavy phone feels solid. Phones these days are reviewed based on the materials they use but to me I like picking up a phone that feels like a brick not a hollow fragile device. And every Motorola phone I have ever had feels just that way. And this thing functions properly too. The best part about this phone so far is the fact that I don't use it all day when I hop in my car at the end of the day it is still at 93% try ever getting that on my Galaxy S5 and you would think something was wrong. Animations are smooth and it is what stock should be... just a few Motorola Brand apps that can be disabled if you do not want them and the rest is Google developed apps. Pure if you ask me. Not Nexus but that is okay.

I have it activated on Verizon. Don't bother with going to the store if you already have a NanoSIM. If not run to the Verizon store walk up and just ask for a SIM card.... Don't be so lazy that you are willing to wait for overnight shipping get this phone activated today. After you get your SIM just call Tech Support at Verizon at (800) 922-0204 follow the prompts to activate a device (Something like press 1, then 3 for technical support, say "Activate a device", and 3 again? Don't take that word for word) when it tells you "for 4g insert sim and reboot" stay on the line and press 0. This will take you to a rep and explain you have an unlocked phone and want to activate it. You give them the IMEI, MEID, and NanoSIM ID and 10-20 seconds later your phone will start activating. Give it about 5 minutes and it will work on their network.

For an unlocked phone, it comes bloated with unwanted Google apps. I can't figure out how to keep it unlocked long enough to make consecutive phone calls. Before each call I must enter my pin. The shake the phone for camera and/or flashlight feature is sketchy sometimes the light comes on and other times the camera turns on. Either way you have to shake it violently to make it work. Where is the advantage to that?
Excelent product

Its a good phone running lollipop. Its a great phone running Marshmallow. Expect it would be AMAZING if rooted and running a custom ROM.  Not giving 5 stars b/c when running lollipop it did lag from time to time.

I have only had this phone for a few days and my feelings are mixed. The setup and migration was easy. Google knew I have a Samsung  Note 2 and offered to install all the apps I have on that phone to the Moto X. Great. The phone is big, not too big, but the one-handed action may not always be possible in a lot of situations. The OS is Android so there aren't any extra apps to contend with once you log-in Gmail, Now, Maps and the Moto Profile, etc. That is basically it. Pop in a Sim card and a Micro SD and you are set. I took a few pics to get an idea of how the camera performs and the pics so far look okay (on the phones screen). I could not tell if it is camera or the phone screen. I have watch a couple of movies and tv shows and the pic great. Some other reviewers my tout how great the Samsungs screens are, but unless you are performing a side by side, you will not be disappointed. The  two front facing speaker are nice! They make the back facing and downward firing speakers appear dumb, now.

Cons: I am still working on trying to download apps I have purchased form the Amazon App Store. The Amazon Underground apps doesn't show my previously paid for apps in the cloud. Don't know if it the phone or Amazon's new app. I also can't get the phone to work with my car's head unit. It won't BT connect and it won't play through the USB cable. My buddy has the N6 and he said these features work. I doubt if these problems are related to the software, maybe it is something configured in the phone's hardware. Don't know yet, but when I do I will update my review.

I've only made it to the unboxing since this is a gift but so far I'm extremely impressed with the presentation of the phone. I also love the feel. They're able to pull off a thick phone in the middle but a thin phone on the bezel. Totally happy thus far!

Clear case Link- http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01547WEPC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00
I wish it fit a little more snug but it'll do.

I bought this for my brother.  I have used it for sometime when he moved to iphone 6s

 Design: It has this metal frame which just feels premium but also helps your phone remain cool. The rubber back provides great grip and the Moto logo dimple is pretty helpful for increased grip while your on a call. The bulged metal speaker grills feel quite good too.

 Software: The OS is pure Android with non-intrusive modifications. This phone shall be one of first non-nexus phones to receive the much awaited Android L update. The phone has cute little animations that pop-up on the home screen itself that will pleasantly surprise you. I love the bed-bug.

 The specs are are fantastic and have been tweaked to use the power only when its required.

 The Moto X's Moto Display is absolutely useful. You won't believe how helpful it is until you have used it. And on an average it use less battery than when you repeatedly wake up the phone to check notifications.

 Audio: The frontal speaker is very loud and clear. It has a rich output but not as good as HTC One M8 tough. But having used to M8's sound I personally didn't find it to be that bad. Its more than average. The phone comes with very ergonomic earphone with reasonably deep bass but it feels cheap and lacks a remote to control music playback like "next", "forward", "back" etc. The Phone's earpiece is just a bit low in volume. That would mean you "might" struggle hearing in a loud place, but then it has a benefit that the other party's voice is not heard even in a quite room with people in it e.g. conference rooms etc.

 Camera: The camera is not as good as iPhone 5S's or Galaxy S5's but it can be best used in broad sunlight or in bright artificial lights because thats when you would have the least noise.
 The ring flash is just a design and it doesn't have any major impact on the overall picture quality when compared to normal led flash cameras on similar phones. The front camera is slow and not good for taking selfies but I don't use it for that. The good part of it is that it can offer better video chat quality on Skype or Hangouts when on low bandwidth networks like 3G due its low resolution which will consume less data.

 Storage: Before buying the phone, I was wishing hard that the phone to be have a MicroSD slot. But when I actually used it I found it has about 10.66 GB of user space on the device. I have installed all possible messaging and social networking apps, few 2D games, productivity apps ~ 1GB , with about 100 songs ~ 500MB, migrated about 40 photos ~ 50MB and still I'm left with about 8GB of space remaining. Thats should work for an average user.

 Battery: Lasts for a day (10AM to 8PM) with WiFi, 3G, Location turned-on still left with 20%. With an average of checking Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp updates in about 30 mins frequency
thanks
Love my new phone! My friend is a die hard iPhone fan and he was impressed with this phone. It was a little bigger than I originally wanted but I've already adjusted to the size. Camera is excellent!

I bought this phone for three main functions. Size 5.5 is the standard for a grown up Guy. No bloat ware, Battery capacity. I give it a 3.5 star for one tricky; I forgot type of a mistake Google made. There is no File Explorer! The third most useful app in any phone. Reason is simple. Google is forcing you to sign into Play store. And from there on you become a product.  The bread and butter of Google is the play store forget the device itself.  I believe omission of file explorer was not a mistake. Otherwise the hype is real.

Moto X Pure Edition Unlocked Smartphone, 32GB Black (U.S. Warranty - XT1575)

This is the best smartphone I ever had and I would never part with it. I had it unlocked, rooted, replaced unlocked boot logo, installed TWRP recovery, and Xposed all on the very first day I had it. The screen is huge, a pleasure to view, even in bright light, it "feels right" in my hand. It comes with a removable external SDCard, I purchased the 64 GB card for external use.

If you get it with Lollipop Android 5.1.1 like I did, you will want to take that OTA Marshmallow Android 6 update as soon as you can. First run on Marshmallow and you will be asked how you wish to use the EXTSDCard. Removable or remains in phone permanently. If you keep it in phone permanently, all of your internal sdcard just "goes away" and the external sdcard becomes the ONLY card on the phone. Which means that extra sdcard space I purchased is flushed down the toilet and I can never remove my 64 GB card. I am sure you can figure out which option I took. I want to actually "use" that 32 GB of internal sdcard space, plus use the external 64 GB of card space.

The specs for the phone blew me away, this thing has power to burn, man. No more struggling with apps like "Facebook Lite", it never slows down, an can multitask like a mom with twins making dinner, changing diapers, and baking a cake all at once! I get in the car and use the Bluetooth to AUX jack plug for my car stereo, then stream music or news from anywhere in the world, I tap my appointment in Google calendar address and navigation takes me to where I want to go, and then the phone rings, I take the call and the phone does not even break a sweat!

Grab Windroid and unlock your bootloader, then download and install the Clark logo fix to get rid of that ugly unlocked bootloader screen. Also use Windroid to install TWRP recovery and MAKE YOUR FIRST TWRP BACKUP NOW! The phone will never be this clean, and close to new ever again, you want and need this backup in case you lose WiFi during a root attempt that did not work, simply restore the backup and try again.

Rooting is easy but IMHO, there are NO good, custom roms available for it. But that matters not. First thing to go is the Google Now launcher which will tolerate little to no modification and replace it with a good launcher like Nova Prime. Now you have complete control over the desktop and app drawer. Now you want to install Xposed for Marshmallow and add the few modules you need to get pretty icons on the status bar, change the quick tiles layout and contents, add cursor keys in pretty colors, Advanced Power Menu for uber nice Power menu for Off, Reboot to recovery, reboot, soft reboot, or bootloader. The things you can do with Xposed modules is almost endless but do not make the mistake I made installing all of them at once the first time. Many are experimental in Marshmallow, don't work, have bugs, or can cause issues on the phone. Install Xposed modules one at a time, testing for days in between, and if you suffer no ill effects, install the next one. If you do notice any problems after installing an Xposed module, double check the configurations, read the warnings you will encounter, and if it cannot be setup to run harmlessly, remove the module.

I did purchase the SVOX Victoria UK female voice and installed her on my Moto X. Now sultry Victoria speaks the driving instructions and answers my Google questions. A feature I cannot live without is the Moto Voice Commander. I actually use this feature every day, for months, long after the novelty wore off. The Moto voice commander is not only useful, I cannot live without it. "Set alarm for 7 AM" "Okay Paul, setting alarm for 7 o'clock AM". "Remind me to buy milk at Publix supermarket" and when I am at or near the store, Victoria reminds me to buy milk. (Victoria is a paid for SVOX artificial UK female voice, the phone comes with a variety of languages in male and female, no need to buy one.) "Play Led Zeppelin" and of course, Moto X does. "Send text to Paula, I will be a half hour late but have something you will love", "Message sent to Paula Pelleteir". "Call Jean Claude Mobile" "Calling Jean Claude mobile phone" and I take the call with Bluetooth in my car speakers. "Navigate home", "Navigating home." Previous voice commanders were toys or slow, Moto Voice is anything but. it is essential, fast, and incredibly accurate. Voice command is often faster than I can do by hand. Not to mention the astonishment on my friend's faces when I use it. Moto Voice will operate all of the hardware on the phone and apps, then defaults to Google for anything it cannot answer directly such as "Where is the closest Mexican Restaurant?" Thus Moto Voice is superior to Google Voice as you get Google Voice anyway, plus being able to control all of the hardware and apps on the phone itself. ...did I mention it was fast?

The cameras on the phone take the biggest, most gorgeous pictures I have ever seen from a smarphone. With 2 flashes on the back and one on the front facing camera, you have all your photo and video needs right there, in the palm of your hand. Typical front facing camera photo is 5344x4008 21.42 MP!

With all of this heavy modification capacity and everything you need is included or can be installed, who needs a custom rom anyway? Marshmallow does include Layers so you can theme the phone with layer themes from play store. I am not crazy about the layer themes because they are really "app skins" for each app or interface on the phone. And, as beautiful as they are, no developer can possible create a skin for every app ever to be made or every function or UI you may encounter, so the layer themes suffer a big loss of continuity when coming from a beautifully skinned Main Menu to an ordinary Hangouts app. I love this phone and would not sell it for any price. And if you are a rooter or love to customize and modify your own phone, this is for you, man!

I've only owned this phone for 2 days now but let me start out by saying that this phone fits my needs and then some. I am someone who wants a zippy phone that can be rooted and bootloader unlocked. I enjoy the latest and greatest version of Android as long as my phone is stable. So far, this has been that phone for me.

The features that I most enjoy about this phone (Pros):
1. Screen - beautiful screen and I believe it is QHD
2. SDCard - SDCard slot so phone storage is expandable
3. Vanilla Android - Pure Android and not much else
4. Speed - This phone is very fast, while not the best processor
5. Front Facing Speakers - These speakers are very loud. This is surprising in a phone. It can scare you at times if you open an app that has a opening sound and the speakers are cranked.

Cons to this phone:
1. Glass - The glass feels slightly cheaper than other high quality phones I've used such as the Note 4, almost flexy. I got used to it very quickly and a glass protector might rectify. Just don't buy the Pleason for this phone.
2. Google Now Voice recognition - At least for now it appears as though you must use Moto app for voice recognition with the screen off. While this isn't a huge deal, it seems to be against the grain as far as pure Android experience.
3. No removable battery - I'm sure I could manage to replace the battery if I had to but I would rather not have to. Why is this not included in phones now? I am not taking a star down for this as this is now the norm while not desirable for power users or any consumer for that matter. Seriously, give me some screws in my phone if that is what you have to do. I don't mind.

Pros that don't apply to me:
1. Can be used on any carrier. I'm on Verizon (via StraightTalk MVNO) but I like the fact that I can use this with anyone. Also a great resell point. All phones should be built this way. Why should I be locked down to any one carrier?

Other phones I've used that are similar:

Moto X Developer Edition
Samsung Galaxy Note 4 Developer Edition
Samsung Galaxy Note 3 Rooted and Safestrap
Samsung Galaxy S4

Of the other phones I've used, only the Note 4 DE comes close here. The main difference there is that the N4 was not a pure Android by default though it could be loaded on the phone (possibly with bugs). The N4 had a slightly better screen and did have the "Google Voice from any screen" option built in and it worked.

As you can tell, I really like this phone. I couldn't find anything to warrant a negative star. I will update my review as I use the phone in the coming weeks.

Ever since December of 2014, I have been using a Cloud White 64GB Nexus 6. I am going to list the pros and cons of the Moto X Pure in general, and also compare the phone to the Nexus 6. I have included a Winner to each section, which sums up my points. Just in case you don’t want to read my entire review. Hopefully this will help many others who are thinking of making the same  switch that I did. That being said, let's get this review started!

Moto X Pure vs. Nexus 6:

Display: LCD vs AMOLED
I originally was scared to go back to an LCD, I loved the deep blacks of the AMOLED and got used to the saturated colors. After using the MXP for a bit, I genuinely prefer the more natural colors of the LCD. The LCD is also capable of getting much brighter than the Nexus AMOLED, while also getting darker. The Nexus 6 can get almost as dark, but at the lowest setting the colors turn red. Some people may prefer the over-saturated colors and deep blacks of the AMOLED, but I find the LCD blacks are extremely good, and it gets much brighter. The LCD seems to be sharper to my eyes. Keep in mind, the Nexus wins for viewing angles. The MXP viewing angles aren't as bad as people make it seem, but they are not the best.

Winner (in my opinion): MXP. I prefer the brighter LCD, sharper picture and more natural colors.

Size:
If you are not used to a bigger phone, it will take some getting used to. Both the Nexus and MXP will be big if you are coming from a sub 5.5" display phone. That being said, the MXP is much easier to use. I personally have extremely large hands (all of my friends and family say the Nexus looks like a normal phone in my hands), I did not find the Nexus hard to use. Without a case, the Nexus gave me no issues. Once I put a case on it, I had issues comfortably using it one-handed, mainly because of the width of the phone. The MXP is significantly narrower, and is also not as tall as the Nexus. The MXP being narrower makes it much easier for one-handed use, and I honestly find it quite small now, because I got so used to the huge Nexus.

Winner: MXP. I prefer the bigger screen of the Nexus, but once it is in a case, the width became an issue for me. I have no issues with the size of the MXP.

Camera (MXP has 21MP Back and 5MP Front, Nexus 6 has 13MP Back and 2MP Front):
The Nexus camera was a huge improvement over my Galaxy S4, at least in the picture department. Anyone with the Nexus 6 knows how poor the video quality is. The OIS does not work reliably, and it has trouble focusing during video. The picture quality was better than my S4, but the OIS and focus made it worse than my S4. The MXP does not have OIS, but it has software stabilization. This works much better and more reliably than on the Nexus 6. I made a video of me walking with the MXP, and it barely moved compared to the Nexus 6. The MXP has more accurate colors in both picture and video, and it is a much improved camera overall. The MXP takes much more detailed pictures, and it captures images in HDR faster than the Nexus in non-HDR mode. The wide angle front camera of the MXP is amazing. It has significantly more detail (double the megapixels), more accurate colors, lets in more light, and captures much more in a shot. I used the front flash once, and it's a flash. Not much else to be said. I have no use for it, but for people that want to take selfies in the darkness of them doing weird stuff, you can do that now.

Winner: MXP. The back camera is more accurate, more detailed, and higher quality in general. This goes for both pictures and videos. The software stabilizes videos better than the Nexus 6 OIS. The front camera has a flash (useless to me but could be useful to you), more detail, more accurate colors, and is extremely wide.

Hardware Design:
Both the MXP and Nexus 6 have a very similar design. The aluminum band and button layout are basically identical, except the micro USB charging port is upside down in the MXP compared to the Nexus 6. The back of the phone shows the main differences. I prefer the ring flash of the Nexus, as it gives off a softer flash with a nice oval shape. However, the MXP flash gives off a much more natural color. The dimple placement on the MXP is not as bad as I thought it would be. I thought it was going to be too low compared to the Nexus, but I am used to it already. I personally prefer the bigger dimple of the Nexus, but I still enjoy the MXP dimple. The front of the MXP is different, as it has multiple more sensors compared to the Nexus. These are for Motorola’s software features, which I will get to soon. Both phones have front facing stereo speakers.

Winner: Tie. I prefer the white front of the Moto X, while I also prefer the ring flash and bigger dimple on the Nexus 6.

Software:
The software on both phones is virtually the same, except a few things. The Nexus is the only device that uses Google's Dialer, which lets you search for businesses within the dialer. Also, if you have your data on and receive a call or place a call to a business, Google will show the contact name for that business when you call. Motorola has its own software that many people have already talked about. You can use Moto Voice to do voice actions with your phone, and you are able to set a custom command. I don't want to waste your time reviewing the software as they are similar except for the Motorola software.

Winner: MXP as it adds many useful Motorola features. The Google Dialer is the best dialer to me, but the useful Motorola software is even better. The Nexus will get updates first, which is the biggest reason I got the Nexus in the first place.

Customization:
The Nexus has two options: Midnight Blue and Cloud White. The Moto X lets you choose different textured backs, including leather and bamboo. I always loved the look of the White Front and Bamboo Back Moto X, so that is what I got this time. I love it. The bamboo looks great, and is extremely soft and grippy.

Winner: MXP. The Nexus doesn’t really offer customization.

Speakers:
Both phones have front stereo speakers. The Nexus 6 speakers get louder, but they sound quite similar overall. The MXP speakers can crackle at very loud volume on certain notification ringtones. I have not heard cracking during video though. I am not sure if this is hardware or software related, but it has not made me want to return the phone.

Winner: Nexus 6. The speakers are louder and do not crackle.

Battery:
The Nexus 6 has quite poor battery life overall for me. I mainly use LTE, and I get good signal on Verizon. The Nexus can last me a day, but not much longer than that. So far, the MXP gets better battery life for me. I will have to test this more, but it seems that the battery is significantly better. Yesterday, I used data for quite a while, texted, called, listened to music while studying for 10 hours. The phone was on for a total of 21 hours, and I had 2 and a half hours of screen time, with 30% battery left. I could have easily gotten 3 hours of screen time, and this was with heavy usage for me. The Nexus would have 100% been dead in a similar time frame for me.

Winner: MXP.

Overall, I prefer the MXP. The customization was a huge selling feature for me, as I really loved the White Front and Bamboo Back. The battery, camera, and display are all improvements compared to the Nexus (at least in my opinion). The screen size is still quite good, while being a lot narrower than the Nexus, making one hand usage much more manageable for many of you. My personal recommendation is that the MXP is a superior phone to the Nexus 6. Granted, it is guaranteed not to receive updates as fast as the Nexus, but I am confident it will be a close second. Only time will tell. I plan to update this review if anything in my opinion changes. I also will update the review once my phone receives the Android 6.0 Marshmallow update.

10/06/2015: I have added some photos that I took here. Amazon most likely will lower the resolution. The colors of the photos are very accurate, and each photo has a very large amount of detail.

10/31/2015: I've taken a lot of front camera photos now. I never really used the front camera on my previous phones, but the higher megapixels and wide angle lens really makes me want to use it. The photos always come out great, and I actually have used the front flash multiple times. It does not blind me, which was my biggest concern with a front flash. I have done some 4K video footage now, and it stabilizes just as well in 4K as it does in 1080p. The stabilization is not the absolute best when compared to other phones, but I find that it works great. I still stand by everything in my review. I currently am using the Incipio Octane Clear/Frost Case, and I highly recommend it. I'll be sure to keep this updated if anything changes.

I am now using a Case-Mate bumper case, as I wanted some protection but wanted to feel my Bamboo back. Otherwise, everything in my review still stands. I have dropped the phone twice with no damage at all, which is great. It seems durable so far. If anything changes I will be sure to update my review again.

Upgraded from 2014 Moto X and the improvement is huge! This phone is probably one of the best android phones out right now, taking into consideration the aesthetics, comfort in hand, and specs. I grabbed this during the sale and definitely made the right choice. No carrier versions on this phone is a HUGE plus and being able to take complete control of the phone is a wonderful thing. No more issues where carries don't care to keep the phone updated and no more locked phones! Although a step below the Nexus 6p in some specs and has a larger development community, I still would recommend the Moto X over the 6p, because it is more comfortable in hand, better aesthetics, the camera quality is still fairly close (in good lighting, not in poor lighting), and also Motorola has included some very nice features in the software, such as Moto Display and gestures (such as chop for flashlight).
I am still learning how to use it. But so far so good.

I have been watching this phone for a while. To be honest, I was not too thrilled when it comes to Motorola, since they history past StarTac hasn't been all that great (great, just know how old I am now)

But playing with multiple phones in the last few years, I think this phone is a pretty good deal, with a few points to take into when considering this phone.

1. Size. 5.7" ain't for everyone, especially for those with smaller hands. I played piano for close to 10 years and can stretch 9 octaves without a problem, but sometimes I find this phone a handful. The back of the phone is craved and a dimple is made of the Motorola mark, but still, it can get kinda hard to hold sometimes. I am still waiting for a better case to arrive, since the one that comes with it is very flimsy, and I have dropped it more than once already and it ain't day two yet.

2. Speed. Granted, not top top-of-the-line, but really, SD 808 is more than enough to handle what I throw at it. Social media, mail, work, game. I did notice that after maybe 30 minutes of gaming, the top part of the phone would get kinda warm, not hot, but noticeably warmer. But performance doesn't fail even if that happens. I only had the Google Calendar FC on me once when I was putting in an appointment, but hey, they are bound to hiccup once in a while, right?

3. Battery life. I know people would kill over this, but I think 3000 mAh is more than enough for a full day of use, assuming you are not working with your phone all day. I can unplug around 8am and still have roughly 36% by 11pm, which is pretty much unheard of. Ok, maybe unheard of before quick-charge (TurboPower charge) came along. The TurboPower charge is something that I find very interesting. I used to work with mobile devices, and I know that if you try and juice it more than it can take, you are blowing it. But after using it a couple of times, not only did it charge fast (I can get from 5% to full in under 1 hour, since I left it there and took a nap), but I don't see any sort of electronic damages, yet. But given what the technologies that are out there now, I think we should be fine.

4. Carrier. As much as I hate to say this, I hate to be "tied" to a certain carrier, not that I switch that much, but I travel internationally quite a bit, and having the freedom of just popping a local sim-card and be on my way is pretty awesome. Motorola X Pure Edition gives me that freedom, since it is unlocked!

With all things, not everything is all glitters, there are some drawbacks, too.

The grip. Make sure you get a case that has a good grip, I just don't see how people are able to use it without a case and still manage not to drop this phone.
Space. I know, this goes both ways, but hey, at least it supports micro SD cards, so go pop a card in and you are fine for your pictures and videos.
Camera. This, again, is personal, but I think the Motorola Camera app is way too bright and the pictures are not as sharp as if I were using a Google Camera app. But, make it what you will, I have both apps and considering a third, just to try it out. I know this might be a deal breaker for many, and right now, I am still adjusting to it.

All in all, I think this is a solid phone, for a good price (how I wish it under $399). If you hate paying to the carriers for your phone, pick up an unlocked phone for your sake, and give this phone a try if you like big phones!

I was very excited about getting this device and the major flooding in SC caused a one day delay in it reaching me and selfishly that irritated me but you're getting it I could not have been more pleased. I previously owed a Moto X 2013 phone and really loved the interface and usability of it. The best thing is that unlike other phones, i can activate voice commands to call someone else without turning on mobile data or wifi. For me who was on a limited data plan, this is one of Moto X's appeal. Google Now or Siri would have required an internet connection to work. Considering all those,  when it comes to switching to a new phone, the Moto X Pure Edition naturally came to my mind.

I've been using the phone for a month now, and I'm quite happy with it. Now, let's get right down to the Pros and Cons:

Pros:
- User experience - I multitask a lot and this phone handles switching applications flawlessly. I can run heavy apps on here with no problems
- Brightness level - I only have this at <30% but everything is still as bright as day
- Colors and interface - apps, images, videos and colors render sharp and beautiful. No complaints here.
- It's huge - This is both a pro and a con for me. I love using the phone because of how big and clear the text and images are. Watching videos is great on here as well. My SO kept asking me to trade his phone for mine lol. Also, the phone is wide and tall but feels really slim in my hands due its thinness.
- MicroSD card slot - 'nuff said
- Turbo charger - LOVE this. Don't know how many this has saved me, but this thing gets you up and running in a pinch. The way it works is that it allows for more electricity to flow into your phone (while still keeping it at safe levels) to fast charge your phone to around 50% in 30 minutes. Then, to preserve your battery, it charges at the regular speeds until full (but still faster than regular charger)
- Active Display - this is something unique about the Moto X. You can wave your hand over the phone to check the time and notification. You can twist your wrists twice to get the camera running. It will read text messages out loud if it detects that you're driving. You can also do the chopping motion twice to turn on flashlight, but that doesn't work for me all the time, personally.
- And as mentioned above, a great perk of this phone is that certain voice commands (e.g. "Call my cat (provided yours has a phone)," "Find my phone"...) are possible without mobile data or wifi. This feature rolls under Moto X's Active Display

Cons:
- Call volume - The phone's speaker is loud for all things... except calling. I read somewhere that it may be a software thing rather than hardware, and that a future update may fix it. Not sure if that's true, but currently, I can play music or watch videos on high volume; but with phone calls, even on max speaker, it isn't that loud. This is a minus for when you're in noisy places or on the road.
- It's a phablet - yup, the phone is big. There's no way I can text with one hand on this phone. It's not a big deal anymore since I don't do it that often, but that would have been nice.
- Battery - nothing to write home about. I get a good day out of it with medium/heavy use.
- Heat - the phone can get quite hot if you're running demanding games

In conclusion, I would say this phone is a great purchase. I did a lot of research into different phones and finally settled on this one. Its pros outweigh its cons and there are so many pluses about it. I did have to return my first one bought here on Amazon because the screen got wonky on me in the first week. I ordered a replacement and have been using this for a month with no problem.

I hate giving this phone a 1 star rating, but I am left with no choice based on what was delivered by Amazon. The phone was sold as a new phone, however what was delivered was clearly not new. The packaging had been relabeled, and re-taped shut, not factory sealed. The box was also dirty on top.

Despite the obvious issues with the packaging, I opened the box, hoping for the best. You see, I really want this phone! Inside I found a phone without its original plastic screen protector. The screen had a small blemish that was not dirt, but physical damage. The front flash was not flush with the screen, but stuck up above the screen surface. And finally, both power button and volume rockers were loose to the point of rattling when the phone was shaken or it vibrated.

Clearly the phone is being returned, and no replacement requested. This is not my first time through this process. A couple months ago I attempted to purchase the same phone, but has similar difficulties. Both 1st and 2nd phones appeared to be new and were in factory sealed boxes, but has a problem with static noise in through the handset earpiece when on calls. The 3rd phone, like this one, was not new, and happened to exhibit the same loose power button and volume rocker issue.

In total that is 4 phones through Amazon, none of which were defect free, and two not even new. Very disappointing since the Motorola Moto X Pure Edition is such a nice phone at a very fair price. Given the large number of happy MXPE owners, I know this poor quality issue is not a given. But it seems that Amazon is dealing with less than normal quality stock in addition to selling "not-new" items as new.

The attached photos show what was seen from sealed box to freshly opened. The blue paper cover over the bumper was actually crooked as shown. Who knows what was going on with the labels on the box.

This is an edit of my original review, now with insight on the overall experience with the MXPE after a month of usage. A lot of it is copy and pasted because much of the device's initial strengths did not change. Here's what a month with the Moto X Pure Edition looks like at a glance.

Design/Build:
Silver frame and bamboo back cover, as I said previously. It does feel awkward in the hand at first, but after a couple days you begin to really fall in love with the size of the phone. It being mostly screen lends more support to that claim. The bamboo is actually grippy contrary to popular belief, and the aluminum frame is shiny and premium (really the only visually premium aspect).

Display:
Its 2560x1440 LCD screen is phenomenal. Crisp and vibrant colors pop even in direct sunlight, and the stock Android OS looks oh-so-beautiful in qHD resolution. The LCD gets far brighter and dimmer than the AMOLED display, and has more natural colors to it. I actually prefer it now. The Moto Display also doesn't light up a room. It may not be "true" black, but hey, it's still black. It won't be an eyesore in the middle of the night or in a dark room. All-in-all it's one of the best screens I've ever seen and used.

Hardware/Performance:
The Snapdragon 808 hexa-core and 3 GB of RAM is still unbelievable. This phone is blazing fast. I've had it now for a month, and it hasn't even shuttered, lagged, or froze for any reason at all. It handles anything I throw at it, from graphics-heavy games, to opening Facebook, to replying to a text, and then right back to where I left off in said game.

Software:
After putting the MXPE up next to a Nexus 5 and 6, I noticed something: they look, feel, and operate the same way. This is basically a 5.7" Nexus device. That being said, Moto Voice is much more intuitive than Google Now. You can set the phrase to whatever you please...no more "OK, Google." Now it's "Hey, What's Up Moto" or, in my case, "Gouvia to Enterprise." Gestures let you flick your wrist to launch the camera, chop twice for the flashlight, and lift the device for discreet, in-ear voice commands (for those who feel they look silly talking aloud to their phone in public). Be weary though: the gesture functions don't work perfectly. If you don't get the motion down JUST right, they simply don't work. But I've noticed they can be SLIGHTLY lenient in how the gestures are performed. The software behaves as pure stock Android is meant to, with a few very impressive additions from Motorola.

Camera:
The initial impression was positive, and the current impression is...well, still mostly positive. The back camera packs a 21-Megapixel punch and photos in broad daylight are beautifully shot. Indoor shots though...I've noticed that they really only require patience. If you're looking to snap something amazing in front of you at that moment, and the lighting isn't good, then well, good luck. But 8 out of every 10 desired shots came out wonderful for me. The front camera is 5-Megapixels with its own LED Flash and honestly, if it isn't absolutely black in the room or outside, don't bother with the flash. The slightest bit of lighting renders it useless being so close to the subject. But hey, it should ne nice to know that it does well when it's absolutely needed.

Battery:
Not bad at all: with 3000 mAh, it started at 9:00 AM and went 12 hours of constant use, ending at roughly 35%. And the best part: TurboCharging. This bad boy can take you from 1% to 50% in maybe just under 20 minutes. With a battery safe enough to handle quick charges like that, who cares how long the battery lasts through the day? 15 minutes on this cord will get you an extra 6-10 hours no problem.

Consensus:
At one month in, I can say one thing about the Moto X Pure Edition that I could NOT say about any other phone I have EVER owned: it shows no downsides. I can't find a single hardware quirk, or software issue/bug, or inconsistency with what Motorola has indicated. In fact, if your device does have any of those, it's probably a faulty model and I implore you to return it for another, because this phone in many ways is a Nexus to compete with the current Nexus. Side by side there's no difference, and like I said, the Moto enhancements actually make the experience...better. So for $400=$500 you get a largely unrivaled software experience, a very personalized device, a microSD slot, carrier freedom, and a budget device you can actually show off to your friends...and you're giving what up? A fingerprint sensor and a USB standard that isn't yet standard? This device might as well be a flagship killer, and might as well be Motorola's best work to date.

 Motorola Moto X Pure Edition - Unlocked - 32GB White & Bamboo

This device is great for the price. After a month of use the things I enjoy most are quick charging, QHD screen, Moto Assist, front facing speakers and the overall smoothness of the pure Android experience. The battery life is average at usually 3.5 hours of screen on time but the thing I love most about this phone is how little drain there is over a long sleep period. I wake up to a drop of not more than 3% over about 6 hours of sleep time. That plus the quick charging capabilities makes for a better battery experience than I had with my old OnePlus One.

The built in Moto features are great to use and I like how they are unobtrusive in the way they operate. The gestures to launch the camera or the flashlight are pretty intuitive as I've never had to use their respective apps.

The camera is well above average but not in the league of the LG and Samsung 2015 flagships I've tested. Honestly, every phone outdoored this year is capable of taking great photos but the consistency on the average user's auto mode is what sets them apart. Since I'm not a camera person the extra $200 for accuracy doesn't cut it for me.

I don't like the fact that the phone charger isn't a two piece USB and brick type. This makes it impossible to connect the phone to a computer for data transfer or charge.

Although the sound from the speakers remain high quality at high volume levels I've noticed a crackle from them when notifications come through. It doesn't happen when I watch videos though so I'm not sure if it is a hardware or software issue.

The 2015 Moto X Pure Edition is an amazing phone, especially given its price.  I'd already ordered a Sandisk 128GB sd card, and when my phone showed up, I was immediately up and running with around 190GB of storage!  I do a lot of photography and videos, and space wasn't something I wanted to worry about.

In this review, I am focused on video.  The Moto X Pure Edition has PDAF (phased-detection-auto-focus) which is a fluid and fast technique to auto-focus.  The technology behind it relies on detecting phase shifts in light as they appear in the sensor (actually special sensors embedded and spaced throughout among the normal sensors).  Based on that, its able to find contrasty things in your photo or video to focus.  When recording video, you don't want to fumble with the phone; you simply want to hold it steady and record.  I shoot a lot with the Canon 5D Mark 2, and even on a prosumer dSLR like that, there is no PDAF!

I'd also recommend a tripod with a head allowing you to tilt and pan.  What I found useful is to not tilt and pan too quickly.  Otherwise the video naturally becomes choppy.  While Motorola states no OIS on the phone, hand-held footage seem to be stabilized somehow and very usable.

Anyways, I spent a day filming in San Francisco around the Golden Gate Bridge, and the result is absolutely amazing!  This video, which contains raw footage directly from my Moto X Pure Edition, was shot in 4K.  (In order to upload to Amazon, I had to shrink it down to 720p.)  Besides speed-ups or slow-downs, there was no retouching of the color, exposure, or any sort of post-processing.  This is raw footage from the phone!

I love this phone!

You can also see the video in 4K in my Youtube channel (as well other footage):
https://www.youtube.com/user/dli2020/videos

Back to Moto X pure. While I love this phone the main complains comes down to:
1. Battery life
2. LCD Display
3. Charger

Let me explain.

The battery life simply sucks. The problem is not so much the battery itself but the LCD TFT display. While it is a nice natural colored display, it consumes over 40% of battery life. Another negative of LCD TFT display is, it's hard to see under sunlight. They really should have used AMOLED display instead but I guess they chose LCD to keep the cost down. Large display makes it as a great tablet substitute, but the short battery life requires you to ration the screen on time.

For example, If I use the phone for web browsing, texting, emailing or whenever I use the display constantly, the battery lasts may be 4 hours. If I use it as a mp3 player or listening podcast with headphone with display turned off, the battery lasts entire day.

25w Turbo charger charges super fast. That's great. But it's kind of hard to find the replacement charger. You are pretty much stuck with Motorola's OEM charger if you want the Turbo charge speed. Worst thing is it seems like there is no compatible battery power bank. Since the battery life does not last a whole day, battery power bank would be a life savor. But it seems like that's not an option for Moto X pure.

Pro:
- Works with Ting (T-mobile) flawlessly.
- Fast
- Great Audio quality (far better than my macbook air). Front facing speakers.
- Love the "shake on" camera feature
- Turbo charger super fast charge.
- Pretty decent photo quality.

Con:
- Short battery life
- The screen is too dark under sunlight
- Turbo charger wall adaptor is somewhat hard to find.
- No compatible battery bank (as far as I know)
- Large
- Motorola is now owned by Lenovo

First of all. I am not going to sugar coat anything folks. I've had this phone for 3 days and was insane enough to test its durability with a case purchased from Amazon. It is an expensive phone to purposely drop. But I can rest assure you that I have extensively let this handset fall onto hard wood. Marble and the screen and phone itself were remained undamaged. I've dropped it into the snow and wiped the snow from the display and kept using it without any issue. And the phones display is made of Corning gorilla glass according to my research. so those that spoke of a cheap screen may have gotten a bad batch. I've had straight talk issues after switching to this unlocked phone. It's not the phone. It was my service. The phone works great in overall functionality. The speakers kick ass at sound quality. The rear camera is very clear and crisp as well as the front facing. I bought the phone from best buy at destiny USA. I felt the need for a new dependable phone after switching from LG for 2 and a half years of their excellence. So this phone needed to be put to the test. I purchased it after the Android marshmallow update. Which I just said heck with it and installed. The update works fine. And overall I'm loving this device. I will be sure to keep an update as time passes. The upper speaker distortion that has been mentioned has not been an issue to me. You can hear it but you need your ear close to the phone. I think it also depends on what you are listening to that makes the crackle noticeable. I've had the phone call voice mail and send a text from my pocket. But I had a Google chrome page open that spammed a few pop ups and must have woke the screen up. No issues since then. I've seen a review on here of a owner that has had the phone a year and had no issues. That's quite reassuring. For anyone who has garbled in call issues with the person on the other line. Try turning off the 4g LTE enhanced mode in >settings>more>cellular networks. Even though it's a recommended setting. It fixed the issue for me. Another issue I have ran into was the fact that Facebook messenger notification sounds seem to ascend like ringtones for some strange reason. Making it impossible to hear a notification on messenger's default ding sound. I found a workaround. If you have upgraded to marsmallow, Unfortunately you need to disable chat heads or disable permit drawing over other apps within Android. You should hear it just fine after. The only drawback is that you will receive an Android notification in the notification drawer instead of a pop-up chat head. For quicker access just put messenger on your home screen.

My phone is in warranty. Moto X Pure Edition Unlocked Smartphone, 32GB White (U.S. Warranty - XT1575)

I like the phone for the most part, except for it being a phone. Call quality goes in and out. I'm waiting for my third phone to see if the first two phones had issues. When I received my new Moto X PE, I found that the screen was damaged. It then took over an hour of raised blood pressure and arguing with Motorola customer support to get reimbursed for a new phone. Love it! Coming from the 2014 version of this phone on Verizon this is a pretty big step up. The micro SD card slot is becoming more and more rare on new phones but is always a welcome inclusion. The screen is LCD which had me worried because of the Moto display having to turn on the whole screen instead of only the white pixels with an AMOLED screen but it really isn't noticeable and battery life hasn't been a concern (especially with the turbocharger included).
