This Motorola is AWESOME. I set up in few seconds and in less than 15 minutes I transfer all my contacts, pictures and install all my 34 application that I used on my iPhone 5s. This phone is amazing. Hope to work for a long time and better than my iphone 5S.
Thanks

I was really stuck between the Nexus 6P and the Moto X Pure Edition (MXPE).  I ended up order the MXPE and have not regretted it at all.  I thought I would really enjoy having the fingerprint scanner on the 6P, but having expandable memory is a much better tradeoff.  The Moto X has a smartlock feature which really makes the finger print scanner unmissed, as you can add a location or bluetooth connections as "known" places to not lock the device.  I have a MXPE for both my wife and myself and we are both happy with our switch from Samsung to Motorola.  The MXPE is hard to beat on performance, price and features.
Awesome phone!
Súper phone ,excelente machine 100% cool!!!!
very pleased - old school Motorola quality. Amazon quick ship etc.

I got this phone as a gift for some one and they loved it, so I decided to buy one myself. I love the device and the pure android os but the phone constantly restarts on its own. I researched the issue and I see its a common problem I tried all the remedies but nothing worked. I will be going back to my Note 4.

I have had this phone for more then a week and it's been lovely. It is super fast and smooth. The camera is great with a lot of detail. The battery is good enough to get through the day and if you're a heavy user and use up the juice, the quick charger is crazy fast! 30 minutes of charging does it wonders. An hour to fully charge the phone is great. This is a nexus phone with great additional features. I can't wait for the fast updates. I reccomend anyone this phone because the value of what you're getting can not be beat!

So far so good. Purchased this as a replacement since I dropped and busted my screen on first moto x pure. No customization but needed it in a hurry and Amazon delivered. Worked well right out of the box with Verizon. Keep in mind it needs a nano? Sim card in order for it work. I had my dealer punchout my micro sim so it fits. Only thing is that it needs wifi for marshmallow update - if you don't have access to it find a Starbucks like I did and settle in for a bit.

Purchased the phone during the Christmas $100 dollars off sale.  I did not have any problems adding to Verizon.  Battery life with Marshmallow doze feature has its advantages when the phone is inactive and still, especially with Greenify app.  The biggest drain on the battery currently is cellphone standby and leaving Wifi scanning with moderate use.  The turbo charger is amazing!  Recommend glass screen protector and a bumper case due to screen size and narrow bezel.  The only downside so far is a lack of notification LED.

This is a great phone!  Awesome display and very quick processing.  The only drawback for me is the phone, and all phones this size, is heavy.  All the cool balancing tricks you had mastered with the smaller phones is out the window.  Just really think if you need and want a big phone.  Even some of the car mounts can't support the bigger weight.  Get a case for it since you'll drop it often.  Otherwise, I honestly love this phone!

Just buy it. If you want "pure" Android and latest updates and patches then go with this device and has the Snapdragon 808 (DecaCore 64 bit) instead of the 810 like a lot of newer phones which are throttled down to prevent overheating and produces lag, which is where the 808 performs better and a lot of benchmarks.

I had the Nexus 6 (Snapdragon 805 Quadcore 32bit) before jumping to this device and I like this device better seems to be snappier and with the SD card slot and the Marshmallow SD functionality where it merges your SD and internal storage into non removable storage it turns this phone into a storage beast so I have 64GB internal + 128 Samsung EVo Pro and I think this will last me quite a while.

Becareful buying PNY SD card both card had mounting issues purchased from Amazon I purchased the EVO pro from BestBuy on sale.

If I could have anything that is missing it would be the fingerprint sensor, and maybe Qi chargind.

Otherwise a superb device!

Currently 5 days in with this phone and absolutely love it. Very pretty and large display. Finger touches don't leave smears that you can see while using it. Camera is as beautiful as the display with 21 mp's. Lots of things I haven't even explored. I'm surprised by the battery life. Turbo charger is awesome, don't have to plug it in at night anymore. Night and day from this phone and that unreliable Sony xperia m4 aqua. Stay away from that phone, save your money and get this one!!!

great phone. i was deciding between this and a Nexus 5X (i previously owned a 5, and a galaxy nexus) but the PURE has it beat on pretty much every level. the only question is whether the screen is too big for you (it's the same size as a samsung note) but i like the screen size.

the only other weird thing is the phone/shooting app, which is un-intuitive.

Great smartphone! It works great! Wonderful performance! This phone has a really great camera, battery in normal use lasts two days or sometimes even more. Its screen is great! It feels nice in my hand!

On par with Samsung Galaxy S6 edge, screen is excellent, battery life above average and turbo charge is very nice feature. Being a Google voice user, can't explain how happy I am with its ability to use any of the big 4 carriers. I switch carriers monthly based on where I'm working, so it's much appreciated, so far have used it with TMob Verizon Cricket (att) with superb LTE coverage on all of them.  Screen is bright and sharp, was considering the nexus 6 but so far happy with the decision, although I wish it had the ability for dual sim cards. 9/10

The customer support on this device has gone down the tube.  They used to be the best, I don't know what happened, they currently have my phone and have basically lost it while I'm still paying for it. They're do not address the software problems they have that cause the battery to not accept a charge or the defaults in build quality.
I think it's one of the best android phones out there, and for a good price too.

Yes, it is possible to activate this on Verizon without previously having an account with the carrier. Like many others, I checked online, then called VZW customer service and then was sent to tech support. The first two told me that the device was not in their system. Tech support instructed me to visit a store, have them activate a new nano sim in a different phone, then pop it in my phone. I explained this to the rep at the store and it was done in all of 10 minutes (minus the wait time) in the store. I've had no problems since.

FYI, for all of you up in arms about VZW not being prepared for this phone, they put a press release out yesterday saying that they would have the device in their system by Friday.

Good luck!

Regarding the phone, I purchased it because of the near-stock Android and the microSD slot. I'm coming from a Nexus 5 - which is a great phone in many ways. I want to use my phone to play downloaded music (and store a lot of it) thereby saving money on data (not to mention, listen to my music anywhere). Finally, I can. The phone is a little big. But, it's not too big. The screen is gorgeous. I think the battery life is good - especially with the ability to charge it rapidly whenever. But, maybe my expectation for battery life is a bit low, given my transition from the Nexus 5 (which had a horrible battery).

very very sad, after a year of using my Moto X 2nd gen phone I had problems and sent it to AT&T for repair, to my chagrin AT&T cracked my screen and sent it back loose in a box and tried to charge me 560.oo for someones used Phone. so with my Italian anger problems I told AT&T togo FN hell and closed my account.

So I got this aWsOmE email the next day from Moto for the Pure, I received it with my name on it and I was doing a happy dance that I now have a bigger screen, it came unlocked so no ties to the evil AT&T. BUT to my dismay the phone would get hot and loose its charge and go dead while talking to my husband. Moto will take my 1month old phone and replace it with someone's remanufactured phone. The honey moon was dead and I was left with a  cold wet spot and alone

I bought this from the Motorola site- price is the same. I have Sprint and didn't get the SIM card from Motorola. If you buy this phone, contact Sprint directly ahead of time and have them send you the proper SIM. They will do so free of charge, and your phone won't work otherwise. I went to 4 different stores and bought a SIM for Nexus 6, as directed by the corporate store. That SIM did not work. I had to wait to use the phone because Sprint customer service and the stores don't know what they're doing. If you're thinking of getting this phone, just get on Order Support chat on the Sprint website and ask them for the SIM for this phone. They WILL send it to you, and when you get it and contact tech support to activate it, they WILL get it working for you. It generally doesn't work with the SIM right out of the box, but contact tech support through the chat and they'll activate the phone for you. If anyone tells you otherwise, hang up or walk out, and recontact Sprint until you get someone who will. I dealt with a lot of idiots when trying to get this phone working.
The phone itself is great- I love the look and functionality. The camera is amazing and fast. You can customize your voice activation phrase. There aren't any garbage apps taking up memory like with the Samsung phones. You can also download the Moto Migrate app, which will bring everything from your old phone to this phone- apps, pics, etc. The screen is large, and the brightness and color are all customizable. There is a function for the phone to select optimum brightness depending on lighting in any given situation. it has a lot of features like smartlock, which will allow you to store trusted places so that you don't have to unlock the phone each time when using it at home, for example. There are a lot of voice activation features, which are easy to use. The camera opens with a shake of your wrist. It really is a beautiful phone, kind of heavy and not so slim, but easy to handle. I can generally write texts etc and manage it with one hand.  I love it so far and hoping I get more than a year out of it since that's about all I've been getting with my Galaxies before they start going downhill. I got the 32GB phone, and it stores a lot. You also have a space for a memory card for additional storage of photos and things like that. I haven't tried to save anything other than photos to the external memory card yet.
Overall, a lovely phone that's customizable in a number of ways.
Just take my advice if you're a Sprint customer and get the SIM from Sprint ahead of time.

Best phone I have tried this year, it fast, has few random slow down, battery drain in heavy use but with normal use lasted me trough the day, it disables hotspots leaving in hands of the carrier. has the neat feature of flicking your wrist to turn on camera or change from a front facing to back or viscera. Also a double chopping motion triggers flashlight​.
Great phone

Nice solid phone.  It's about time somebody gets serious about making phones more affordable.

VERIZON users:  Don't get too discouraged by trying to get this going on VZW.  I spent an hour at a corporate store yesterday trying to get this activated.  No luck (and I only ordered the phone AFTER checking with both Verizon and Moto).

The problem lies with Verizon's antiquated activation system.  Their system, designed obviously to keep customers and make choice and variety as limited as possible to keep you in their ecosystem, cannot register a new SIM to a phone not in their system (they don't sell the Pure).

The work arounds:

1. Talk to CS and have them send you a Nano sim for your phone number.  That "should" work.  They won't do this in store (they aren't trained to), but getting on chat got me one shipped immediately.

2.  OK I decided I didn't want to wait until next week for the Nano SIM.  My current phone is a Galaxy Noote 3, it has a Micro not a Nano.  Hmmmm.  I took some scissors out and cut that down to fit in the Nano slot (yes, this is a normal procedure, Amazon even sells cutters for this purpose).  Guess what?  Viola, fired up just fine and is working perfectly.  Of course if your current phone has a Nano then you're good to go without doing anything.

I'm liking this phone so far, chose it over competing models solely because of it's natural language processor.
Good solid build, a bit large for people who rather a phone they can use with one hand.  32GB model is great with 3GB RAM so it's fluid.  I haven't had any hardware or software issues (other than what I'm about to describe below).

For me, this is why it didn't get a 5-star.  Out of the box,the product was HORRIBLE.. why? Erratic screen flickering / ghost touch. Contacted Motorola who said they could only replace the phone and that I should ask Amazon to process a refund or replacement. Little tinkering around online and I found out that I should downgrade to Android 5.1.1 and ever since, no screen flickering issues.  Apparently the screen issues will be resolved with Android 6.1 update, but for now, the phone is functional on 5.1.1 and I'm satisfied so far.

Also, why is there no USB data cable? It comes with a wall charger... not a 2 in 1 wall-charger / detachable data cable. Smh.

UPDATE:
The screen issues came back up and now the phone is completely unusable. Seems I got the 1 out of 10,000 or so that has a manufacturing defect. Some guy suggested it's an inherent issue with TFT screens, so from my experience, I'd recommend AMOLED. Loved that phone... but... :(

Having been a solid apple user for 3 generations this moto x pure is shocking good. This is only my second Android phone. First one was a HTC and drove me away from Android. I am very happy I gave it another go for the Moto X Pure with no bloatware runs great. Other than the weight, this phone is almost perfect and I am used to smaller phones. Great power and package for the money, it makes buying a unlocked phone worth it for the cheaper monthly plans. Plus you can use this on any carrier.
A tad on the large size but i actually love it!
I love it. One of the best if not the best phone I've had. And the price is amazing. My last phone was HTC one M8.
This is a awesome phone,

Soon after I turned the device on it began to get really warm. The general consensus online seems to be that phones get hot when you are first setting up so I thought this was normal.

However, over the next few days it would start to get really warm. The phone would be inactive for hours but would get hot within a few minutes of me surfing the internet or watching YouTube videos. I understand that phones get warm but 30 seconds of a YouTube video shouldn't be enough to make it get warm especially if it hasn't been used for hours.

My phone would get hot around the top half of the screen/earpiece and on the back around the M dimple. It made it very unpleasant to hold the phone with or without a phone case.  The fact that the earpiece gets hot worries me because it could hurt someone who holds their phone to their ear when they make phone calls.

There are other people who seem to have this problem (a google search shows a few threads on other websites discussing this issue) however most reviews I have watched or read do not report this.

My phone may have just been defective but I decided to return it. Hopefully the return process goes well because my experience with this phone was unsatisfactory. This was meant to replace my 2nd gen Moto G but I will have to look consider a different company.

I love this device. It works well has a nice camera and plenty of features to keep me happy. Activating on Verizon was a little bit of an issue but from reading online message boards I knew to go to a Verizon corporate store and not an authorized retailer.

The best part is it has none of the bloatware that Verizon phones a full of.

They screen is not as good as a Samsung but is more than acceptable.

I selected the 16 GB version because it take SD cards up to 128 GB. I put in a 64 GB card and have more storage than I'll ever need.

If you are thinking of getting any motorola product,then you should be ready for the most heart breaking and disappointing experience of your life. I feel they pay people to come write positive reviews here because nobody I know had a great time using their substandard products. From their customer service, to escalations to shipping, all are out to take your money for stupid reasons without giving you value for your money.

I first bought a Moto x gen 2. It started resetting on its own making me lose files. I sent it to them and paid $125 in November of 2015! I haven't still received the phone till now 2016!!! I stupidly still bought the pure edition and that by far is the worst. Poor camera quality, overheating, the phone resets itself and doesn't back up my files even after I do and this is barely three weeks after buying it. Now, the phone doesn't receive network service and keeps going off on its own.

I have called their customer care service virtually everyday and they are so lackadaisical and rude. One even sniggered over the phone while I was explaining how unsatisfied I was with their product. I wish someone told me before getting into this horrible mess. The money and time spent could have gotten me a much better phone.

My husband purchased a Moto X Pure directly from Motorola and had enjoyed the phone for approximately four months.  One day the screen no longer worked in that the icons jumped around and pushing an app icon wouldn't open the intended app, but would sometimes open a different app altogether.  He received a return label from Motorola fairly promptly and was told that a replacement phone would be shipped within 1-to-2 business days after they received the phone.  A follow-up call to Motorola revealed that they needed to send it to their technicians and that a repair would be made, taking 3-5 days.  After 5 days, there was still no phone or word from Moto.  He then calls 8 days after he sends it in and hears that the company will be sending him a refurbished phone and that it should take 7-10 days.  We are not holding our breath.  It is remarkable that such a large and internationally established company has such poor training and process control issues.

I love this phone. It's faster than my iPhone 5S. I like the moto voice feature. I love being able to speak and have it write exactly what I say the first time much better than siri. The screen is so crisp and clear. The colors are vivid. I'm glad I waited until the 32 GB model was $50.00 off.

I upgraded from a Galaxy S4 to the Motorola X Pure on Verizon. I had no issues activating it with Verizon. I love this phone so far! Near-stock Android, no garbage or bloatware, blazing fast, charges very quickly, and it has an Micro SD Card slot (in my opinion, there is no reason to get the 32GB or 64GB -- just get the 16GB and buy a 128 GB Micro SD Card for $59.99 here on Amazon).

The camera is good -- better than my wife's iPhone and comparable to any phone camera I've seen.

Battery life is comparable to my S4 when it was new; but the TurboCharger is extremely fast. It went from a 10% charge to fully charged in under 40 minutes. I could see the battery meter counting upwards.

When I took it to the Verizon store to get a new SIM Card, the guy that helped me was so excited to see it he brought two of his co-workers from the back to admire it. They were raving about it, calling it things like "extremely responsive", "perfect amount of grip on the back", "wow, you don't even need a case if you don't want one", etc. I've never seen a group of people at a cell phone store rave over a phone like this.

For $399 you can't beat this phone right now, in my opinion.
This phone is truly amazing. This is seriously my favorite phone I have had. Must buy

When it was time to consider switching platforms, I did tons of research on the pros and cons between Android & iPhones.  Being a diehard fan of unlocked Blackberry devices since 2005, I knew I wanted an uncomplicated and clean installation experience.  Sadly, this would exclude both Samsung Android and iPhone devices.  The extreme bloatware/TouchWiz on Samsung and the locked down features of iPhone (especially if you’re a Verizon customer) led me to Motorola’s Moto X Pure Edition.  I am extremely pleased with my purchase (purchase was made at BestBuy.)

Without a doubt the best phone out there. Half the price of competing Apple or Samsung products with expandable storage, an OS that gets out of your way.

I get questions all the time and an proud to say it's a Motorola when someone thinks it's an iPhone or Samsung!
Amazing amazon :) Amazing device! Cheer to Motorola for making this device and amazon for delivering on time :)

Switched from note 4.  Absolutely love this phone.  Android should be experienced sans carrier and manufacturer bloatware.  Stereo speakers up front that get loud. Very nice.  Customization with leather and embossed name in it... Very cool.  Decent shooter? Yes. As good as Note 4, no. Note's 8X zoom really cool... If note 5 had SD card support, would have gotten that. Actually glad they didn't... This is more responsive than the note 4... Pure is a perfect name..os feels light. Two nice features... Love the chop activation of the flashlight and the twist to launch the camera. Really nice.
GOOD!

Nice big screen, excellent sound from stereo front speakers, even at higher volume. Generous amount of RAM so that applications function efficiently. No problems with Bluetooth or Wi-Fi. Cellular radio functions at high speeds on most bands, allowing great choice in carrier. Motorola is generally good at updating Android software, as well as its own (minimal but useful) additions. Especially appreciate the motions to start up flashlight and the camera. Good camera, and it has enough pixels so that extensive cropping (even on the phone) is possible while maintaining a good result. Stereo audio and video sound recording.

Battery life has not been a problem, and there is an effective battery saver mode if I'm going to be away from a charger for a long time. Also comes with a high-speed charger for quick top-ups. I generally have avoided devices with such large screens, but the very narrow bezels and other proportions make it feel smaller in the hand. I also use a TPU case to minimize accidental touches to the screen (due in part to the narrow bezels), but if that's not a problem for you, the standard back is a "grippy" rubbery plastic, which helps the phone feel more secure in the hand. Does not have a fingerprint sensor, if that's something you need.

works well on verizon just activate your nano sim by sticking into the left corner of the sim port of your old phone, mine was a lg g3, the activate it over the phone. after that it will work fine in the pure after 2 power cycles.

volume buttons are loose.

I have been using my Moto X pure for a little over a month now. I ordered it customized through MotoMaker and got the 16GB model with black front, teal back, and metallic blue accents. First off, I love the phone aesthetically. My phone before this was the original Moto X, AT&T carrier locked. I had a Moto X Phone Case, SUPCASE Unicorn Beetle Series Premium Hybrid Protective Bumper Case for Motorola Moto X Phone, Frost Clear/Black [Free HD Clear Screen Protector, Bubble Free Installation Instruction Included], which covered the majority of the accents (the power button and volume rocker), and the supposedly clear back hardly showed my customized phone. I have a Casemate bumper on the phone now, which allows you to actually see the back and the accent around the camera and dimple.

Second, I thought the 5.7" screen was going to be too big for me, but I was wrong. I tried handling the Nexus 6, which was the closest thing I could find comparable in size, but the X Pure fits perfectly in my hand. I've had to use my old original X for a couple things recently, and it feels weirdly tiny now.

As for storage goes, I upgraded from 8 GB on my old phone to 16 GB here (along with a 128 GB microSD card) and my new phone was already having problems with lack of storage space, so I've had to make sure to keep moving apps over to the SD card. But that will be solved with Marshmallow being released.

Speaking of which, Marshmallow just popped up on my phone, so I'm excited for that.

The Moto X Pure Edition is a great phone. Don't get me wrong, but there are a few small things where Motorola can improve. Starting with the speaker. It is a game changer moving from a phone that has back facing speakers. If the sound quality the gave was better, it would be a completely different story. The top speaker seems to have some issues. You can hear the sound cracking at high volumes or even during calls and it can get very annoying. I also noticed that on my unit, the power and volume rockers seems to be a bit on the loose side. You can feel where the buttons move around inside the the phone. Other than that everything runs like a breeze. Stock Android feels as good as ever and with the included 3 GB of RAM, nothing goes wrong. Other than a bit of lag here and there but this is a great choice for a smartphone.
Great phone!

The best part about this phone is the box it came in. Otherwise, the camera is still not flagship quality. The battery life is not much improved from the previous version. However, for the price, this may be the best phone you can buy compared to the OnePlus 2, Asus Zenfone, HTC One A9, and other midrange devices.
The longer I've owned this phone, the more I enjoy its capabilities.

Moto X Pure is by far the best cell phone I have owned. Previously had Carrier branded Samsung devices complete with all the unwanted bloat. This is the first phone that I have liked straight out of the box. Minimal pre installed Moto and Google apps. Twice the battery life of my S5 Active and camera will amaze you.
Lots of custom development for this device will ensure long life even after Motorola stops OTA support.

I wanted to like this phone, but I cant! The display is painful after viewing it for a while, I adjusted many settings but it's just how it is. I understand they went with a tft display on this phone but something is off about it. Secondly this is a single radio phone so if you have Verizon in an area without really  solid 4G you have to choose between constantly dropped calls,bot the loss of HD calling and calls and data simultaneously. I also can't stand the factory Google launcher and never did find a third party launcher I was happy with. Overall it's a great concept but it had too many issues for me.
Awesome phone!!!
Great cell phone for low price.

Motorola XT1575 Unlocked Moto X Pure Edition 32GB Phone (White)

For starters, I am not tech savvy. Before this phone I had the Nexus 6, but I ran into a string of problems. My first Nexus 6 was fine but after getting it replaced the phone kept getting too hot (108 F), especially the screen. My fingers would burn every now and then and that was my cue to put it down. My poor Nexus 6 got stolen, so I ended up buying this phone.

MIC
What bothers me about this phone is the mic quality. It is slightly better than the Nexus 6, but people still cannot hear me. I have a soft voice, but if my lips are almost touching the mic and people are still complaining that I'm not loud enough then this phone needs to get its priority straight. For that I am taking off one star. Furthermore when setting up my special phrase for Moto Voice I ended up putting my mouth to the phone when it told me not to. My phone could not hear me.

However, after finishing the set up, Moto Voice responded when I called to it from across the room... what gives?

TEMPERATURE
Earlier I complained that the Nexus 6 at 108 F burned to the touch. This phone gets up to 110 F and yet I can hold the phone without my fingers getting burned. I do think the rubber back somehow helps or maybe Motorola designed this phone better (well it is new). I'm just glad I am not getting burned anymore.

BATTERY LIFE
I want to say the Nexus 6 battery life is longer than this phone because I can go up to 8 hours on one charge. What I do on my phone is text, browse the web, YouTube, Netflix, play music, use the maps app (30 minutes a day) all while my location, Bluetooth, and data is on. That phone was never resting unless I was eating or showering (Hmm maybe that's why it got so hot).

The Moto X Pure has about 6.5 hours of battery doing the same activities I've mention above. However, I did read that because of the way it is built the battery life will be around 6. Therefore, I can't complain since that is how it is. I do feel the battery drains faster than the nexus 6 when playing music and using the navigation at the same time, I suggest to leave it plugged into your car.

CHARGING
Do charge this phone when it is at 10%. Because it will take an hour to charge. For some reason when I charge at 70% the phone takes about 1 hour and 50 minutes. I am not sure why, but I learned to wait until the battery gets really low. Also, don't even think about using a regular charger. That will take ages. And invest in a good car charger because my battery life stayed the same when I was using navigation or playing music.

SPEAKERS
Like the other comments, the speakers are louder than usual. I feel the audio is too loud when the volume is near zero. I haven't run into a problem with the top speaker yet.

MOTO APP (Has nothing to do with my rating. This is an observation since I am new to Motorola)
This is for anyone who is new to using the MOTO app. The phone is designed around it. If you turn Moto Display the phone the phone will light up when your hands get near. The whole point is to save on battery life so that your phone does not accidentally turn on when it is inside your pocket or bag. With the bumper case attached, the power button will not be accidentally pushed. I like it and have it on all the time.

Next is Moto Voice, just like "Ok Google" Motorola has it's own voice command. I don't have it on anymore because when I play YouTube or Music on the phone, the thing always activate. I am not sure why but it seems to do it at random because when I play back the audio of when the voice command pops up the phone doesn't react. It can unlock your phone when you use it which I thought was useful at first but then annoying if my phone unlocks if I am playing audio. Hopefully this gets improved. For now, I am fine with Google's voice command.

The others are boring and not something that I would rave to anyone about. There is a "Chop twice for flashlight" (I guess this is useful if you don't want to unlock your phone and click on the flashlight button), "Lift for Moto Voice" (this still needs working on. You place the phone to your ear and Moto Voice comes up. I have this turned off), and "twice for quick capture" (I have this on but I don't use it because I'm afraid I might accidentally fling my phone across the room).

I guess these features are nice if you want to be discrete about certain things. But again, not a necessity. Some of these features do need improvements though.

BUMPER CASE
Yes, it does come with one. It's made out of plastic and easy to put on and take off if you follow directions.

FINAL THOUGHTS
I only had this phone for about two and a half weeks. If I run into a problem or have more thinks to say, I will edit this. The reason why I rated it three stars is because of the mic. If I am going to spend $500 on a phone the mic needs to pick up my voice. In addition, a three star rating means I would not buy this phone again nor would I recommend it to anyone because there is nothing new. It is an okay phone. If anyone is on the fence about getting a new phone, wait until the new Nexus 5 and 6 2016 comes out (I apologize for not knowing their exact names). Maybe those will be better. This is not a "OMG I NEED THIS NOW" phone. However, please note that I am an average phone user and perhaps do not know this phone's full potential.

What I look for in a phone is storage, RAM, and the ability to disable useless apps. I do appreciate being able to open multiple apps at once without the phone freezing or the app crashing. Never had I have this happened to me on this phone.
Awesome phone! Had a defective one at first but Amazon was kind enough to give me a replacement. The sound during a call was very choppy. The new one is perfect.

What a BIG phone! And I am not talking about its size. Well, sure, it's 5.7", but it is super grippy (I have the rubber version) and because of the dimple and its form I can easily hold it. Even one handed use for typing is not  a problem for me. Now, I think I have big hands. But still.
The phone fits in my jeans, which is good too. Does not feel that big at all.

The speakers are SUPERB and reach the levels of an iPad air 2. Good basses too, which a nexus 6p lacks for example.

The screen is really good too. Nothing I can complain about. Everything looks just great on the 1440p.

The camera... It does not have IOS, but the digital stabilization does a very good job. So video no problem. Also, 4K recording works, though a  little laggy. Also, it seems a bit grainier than 1080p! 1080p is enough, anyways. So no big deal.
Front facing flash? It's REALLY good. And much nicer than Apples solution with flashing the screen for a moment. Looks much more natural.

Performance is very, very smooth. All works well. The snapdragon 808 does a great job. The phone does get high while downloading a lot or intensive apps, but not too hot either.

Fast charging is great too. It's very fast!:)

The build is premium. No protruding camera, metal rails, well shaped, glossy front panel.

Overall, just a great phone. Especially for its price. 64GB was 544 euro. Unbeatable.
Awesome phone!

I waited a whole month to review this phone, because I think it's important to take time to figure out all its nuances and such. I purchased the 32 GB edition for $349, so overall, it was a decent deal. My review will briefly cover overall performance, battery life, connectivity, camera, and value.

Performance: it's very quick even though it doesn't have the latest Qualcomm chipset, but the 3GB of RAM definitely helps. I have not experienced any lag at all, and I have zero complaints. I didn't do any benchmarks, as those are readily available with a simple online search, but to be fair, I don't play a lot of games. I have played video at 1080 with no problems, and the screen is quite nice as well. The screen is definitely a step up from my Lumia 640, but I can't really see the difference between it and my old Samsung S4. I suppose some people play games and there are faster chipsets available, but for me, it's almost perfect on the performance level. The near-stock Marshmallow experience has been amazing, and even the Moto apps are usable, especially the twist Camera feature. Unfortunately, there is no fingerprint scanner, which I would have liked. 10/10

Battery Life: I usually unplug the phone in the morning at 6:30am and plug it back in at 11:30pm, which is about 17 hours. However, I am not allowed to use my phone at work, so even though it's on, the screen is rarely used, resulting in 70% battery life remaining at the end of the day. That's pretty good, but again, if you are a constant user, I expect it to be much, much lower. Also, the TurboCharge feature is awesome since I can charge my phone quickly. The downside is that not all QuickCharge chargers seem to work with it. I'm not sure what that's about since it's Qualcomm-licensed technology. For reference, my Lumia 640 (low-res screen) used to lose 15% in the same amount of time and usage. 7/10

Connectivity: I looked at all the available unlocked devices with minimal bloat and CDMA/GSM connectivity. I have not tried CDMA networks, but on T-Mobile, it's mediocre. I was supposed to receive LTE Band 12 with the Marshmallow update, but it never connects to a B12 antenna. The Lumia 640 had B12, and it was phenomenal. I am only getting a B4 LTE connection, which is mediocre due to T-Mobile's blah network. I am looking to switch to AT&T with the hopes that B17 LTE will be up in my area. Motorola antennas are known for being quite good, and I don't really have a reference to go from, so I'll concur for now. I know it's probably a T-Mobile issue at this point. I do have issues with Bluetooth in my car, as it will fail to connect some times, causing me to go through the whole "forget, unpair, and re-pair device" process. It has happened twice in a month, so that's not great. Wi-fi performance has been fantastic - it usually has a faster connection than my iPad and Chromebook. 6/10

Camera: I mainly switched from my Lumia 640 to this because of the camera. So far, it's pretty good, but I actually prefer the camera on my Samsung S4. The Moto XPE's camera does not have any modes for situations like Action. That means a lot of blurry shots. If everything is still, it's great. Maybe I can find an app to fix that, but for now, it's not very impressive. 5/10

Value: For $349, it is a decent value so far. If it stays operational for 2 years, I'll be happy since I don't have to be on a contract and I can switch from CDMA to GSM whenever I want. The annoying Bluetooth connection losses are my only major qualm, with the lack of a fingerprint scanner as a minor one. I just recently found out about the Blu Life One X, which I would have liked to try first, since it's only $150 (but only GSM unlocked). If Band 12 LTE ever works for T-Mobile, I would probably go from "liking" this phone to "loving" this phone. Right now, I'd give it 6/10 overall.
An awesome phone worth its price. I am simply loving it.

Excellent phone. Long battery life, unlocked and have been using it in USA and Viet Nam with no problems. Doesn't heat, the camera is great, and processing speed is superior. I'm very happy with this purchase!
Really satisfied.
excellent

It worked great for two weeks until I unexpectedly found it dead one afternoon.  It was then stuck in a boot loop.  After troubleshooting and doing a factory reset Motorola offered to either do a standard return with a 5 day eta, or I could let them charge my card full retail and expect a 4 day eta.  I returned it to Amazon since it was still within 30 days of purchase.  Amazon did miss their delivery date of the original order due to "order processing."

Finding TurboPower 25 chargers locally was a bust, but as always - Amazon to the rescue.  Same with screen protectors and cases.

I upgraded the phone to Android 6.0 Marshmallow upon first unboxing it (over WiFi). The Moto X Pure was provisioned easily at a Verizon Wireless corporate store (for no charge).  They even put on my screen protector.

Call sound quality on the phone was excellent.

My previous device, an original HTC Incredible, ran 2.3 Gingerbread.  I was still adapting to the Marshmallow experience and larger screen before the phone stopped working.  I had yet to unlock the bootloader, so AFAIK I was unable to try loading a new software image since my guess is that the problem was just software related. My only option was to send it in.

I appreciated being able to buy a contract free phone not limited to any one carrier.  I think the Moto X Pure is a good phone with lots of potential.  However I am going to try something else as a replacement.

The MXPE overall is the best multimedia / phone device to date:

1.  Great build
2.  Great sounding front stereo speakers
3.  64GB model for $500
4.  SD slot that works fine with my 200GB micro sd card (formatted exFat)
5.  Very good sound quality from headphone jack
6.  Great cell radio and wifi reception
7.  Great display
8.  Plays 3D heavy games smoothly
9.  Camera is great with mid to normal ambient light
10. Charges fast
11.  Smooth performance
12.  Battery life is good, but like all LTE devices, can have weaker battery life if using in weak signal areas.

I wish the battery was replaceable and there was an LED notification light, but the positives IMO outweigh this.

Note:  If your display is yellow instead of white- return it, since the display as per reviews and most others on forums, the display is and should be WHITE.

Absolutely perfect in every way.
An absolute joy to use.
Turbo charging.. WOW. 80% in 20 minutes sounds incredible and IT IS.
Excellent Phone.  Very easy to configure. Very good and fast. Moto applications free hands excellent. battery, with average usage last for the complete day.

Bought at Best Buy, not amazon.com, same price. They offer nice warrantees. Just a snazzy fast working phone with a great camera if you want unlocked, SIM cards, and durability (I got tired of the phone I bought from the carrier conking out three days before contract was up). NOTE: The screen light hurts my eyes so I downloaded a Twilight app I used on previous phone to block blue lights (promotes insomnia) and the app softens the tones of the regular daylight screen to a perfect level for me. The non filtered day screen made my eyes hurt in the first five minutes. Hope that helps someone.

Really missing the wireless charging.  Got the Android 6 update rather quickly.  2 weeks before my wife's Sprint branded LG4.  Battery life is so-so.  Charge is pretty quick, moreso if you use their branded usb charger wart.  Quite durable -- I've dropped it from couch height a few times already, and I haven't noticed a single nick on it yet.

In hindsight, I could have skipped the bamboo back.  It has a few blemishes in the veneer, which while looking authentic, detracts ever so slightly from the aesthetic.

I got this phone from Motorola.com. I am so happy with this phone. It is beautiful, and so easy to use. Really, you won't be disappointed! No bloatwear whatsoever! I had to take the phone into a Verizon store to get a nano sim card, and I had no issues with set up at all. This phone charges super fast.
Excelent

The phone I absolutely love. Its the Amazon Warehouse Deals that I'm upset with. The description indicated the box is damaged and the items is used but very good condition. When it arrived, the Motorola box wasn't damaged. It was just really dirty and had a lot of tape on it. When I opened it, almost everything was out of place. The phone was very dirty. Smudges and finger prints all on the screen. The camera lens was VERY dirty and actually a little difficult to clean off. Also, the phone and contents were very dusty. Power supply was just thrown into the box dusty and dirty not wrapped up. Tons of micro scratches on the screen and 1-2 deep scratches.

So all of this, I can clean up no problem, the main reason why I am in the process of returning the phone is what happened when I turned on the phone. There is a pretty large white pressure spot on the screen. Very noticeable. I was hoping it would go away in a few hours, unfortunately, that is not the case.

I definitely going to buy this phone again. Just not through Amazon Warehouse Deals.

My favorite phone! I'm a bit of a phone nut (currently have 5). If I could only keep one, this would be it (Nexus 6 would be close 2nd). It gets fantastic reception, has no bloatware so it's snappy fast, incredible speakers, etc. I would highly recommend this phone to anyone.

Awesome phone.Beautiful display .Super fast charging.
Excellent Sound Quality .
Feels great, runs fast. Great product all around at a perfect price.

Great phone thusfar... Being able to have a Verizon phone without the standard Verizon bloatware is fantastic.  Relatively affordable and the phone itself is super fast, expandable memory is an awesome feature.  If I needed to come up with criticism it would be the change away from AMOLED screen.  Whereas on the previous moto x it only really used the dots on the screen it needed to use and the rest was true black, now it is backlit and you can see some illumination of black occasionally.  Not a major criticism but something I noticed and wished they hadn't changed.

This phone was going to be a replacement phone for Moto X Gen 2 but it is being returned because it will not work with Republic Wireless and sold as a unlocked phone for all networks.  I can do a quick compare and the screen is 5.7 versus 5.2 of the gen 2 and has a very snappy processor compared to my old phone.  My old phone has very poor speakers and short battery life and I was looking forward to the bigger battery and new turbo charger in this new phone.  I was also hoping that it worked better with Apple products because my present phone does not and lots of the people that call me have the Apple phone and have a hard time hearing.  Thank you Amazon for returning the case,screen protector and additional chargers I ordered to go with it and if you order this phone be sure it works with your carrier before ordering accessories.

This is a great phone for so many reasons, (just read/watch trusted reviews) I am not here to do another review because there are so many of them out there.
I am so sad I have to move on to something else... I had it off and on for two months because the screen could not survive the slightest fall. Had it replaced once already, and can have it replaced again, but I have seen enough. I had a good screen protector and case on it, and I have never broken a phone before this and have owned at least 3 different smartphones.
The edge to edge glass means that if it falls on one of those edges, chances are the impact will crack the screen beyond belief.
I will be moving unto something else as much as I love this phone. My phone will fall. It's just the reality, but they are always small drops. If this phone cannot survive a small drop from say a very low side table to a rug/carpet? Then even with all it's glory, it is not worth it (for me).

Ordered A Custom Moto X From There Website. Love The Phone Design In General. Feels Great In The Hand. The Qhd Display Is Beautiful But The Only Negative Is The Battery. I Say The Battery Is Average. Not Terrible But Not Good. They Did Make Up For It With A Turbo Charger That Charges Crazy Fast.  So If You're A Power User Just Plug It In On Your Lunch Break & Your Good To Go. The Regular Qualcomm 2.0 Chargers Work Well Too. The Camera Is Great As Well. Word Of Advice Switch To Manual Mode Though. SD Card Is Great... So If You're Not A Heavy Gamer You Can Do Fine With 16 Gb Storage & A 32 Gb 64 Gb Micro SD Card. I Downloaded All The Social Networks And Main Shopping Apps & Still Had 3 Gb Of Storage Left. Plus With The New Android 6.0 Update You Can Use Your SD Card Just Like Regular Onboard Storage. The Phone Itself Is Fast &  Not A Lot Of Lag. No Phone Is 100% Smooth So I Would Say The Moto X Is Somewhere In The 85%-90% Range. It May Have To Do With How Buggy Lollipop Is. Multi Tasking Is Seemless Though. Well If You're Looking For A Premium Phone At A Budget Price Pick The Moto X.
Not bad at all. Decent battery life got pics to prove it
It is really a good phone, big phone, also has a good look, but the phone's details are not perfect, I like it.. I will buy moto x 2017
Not nearly as easy to use as the SAMSUNG Note 2 it replaced. If I could go back in time, I'd spend the extra $100 and buy the Samsung.

I originally had a Moto X 2nd generation and it was a great phone. I decided to try out the Moto X Pure and I have been extremely disappointed. In the 7 months of owning it, I have had volume issues, bluetooth issues, and now half the screen has faded to yellow from white. From day one I felt like it was a downgrade from my previous Moto X, not sure why as the hardware should be superior. On top of that I had purchased the Moto Care since they advertise they will send you a like new phone before you ship yours off for repair. They have since changed this option (6 months after I purchased) and will not honor what they sold me. Great customer service. I decided to get a prorated refund of the remaining "Moto Care" and will send off under the 1 year warranty. Obviously I have to find a back up phone first. Once I get the Moto X "Pure" repaired I will be selling it. Needless to say I believe this is my last Motorola product. If you search on line you will find the issues I stated as somewhat common. I highly recommend you look elsewhere for a phone, otherwise buyer beware. Motorola can change their policy as they see fit and at the expense of their customers.

I highly recommend this phone. Its features leave me questioning why I ever locked myself into expensive contracts to get 'high end' phones.
Probably one of the best phones in the price range and just as good as phones which cost twice as much. Compared to my friend's S6 and my sister's Iphone 6 plus I would say this easily competes in every category I care about and at half the price.
My wife who is a photographer, prefers the camera on this phone over her Iphone5s for for the quick pictures where a high end camera is not needed.
The battery thus far tends to last about 2-3 days under moderate usage, a drastic improvement over my last phone which often wouldnt last even a day under light use.
The phone is very zippy for all applications I have used it for.
I purchased the 16 gb version and added SanDisk Extreme 64GB MicroSDXC UHS-1 Card with Adapter (SDSQXNE-064G-GN6MA). The OS allows you to use the card as embedded memory to store anything you want on the card as if it were internal memory.
I used to purchase new phones every 2 years on contract and usually I would be either dissatisfied with the service or the phone long before the contract is up. with high end phones often costing $600+ to replace and contracts expensive to break, I found myself often dissatisfied with the contract deal.  That mixed with the fact that I have noticed relatively few substantial improvements in the smart-phone industry over the last 4 years meant I saw no reason to continue with expensive networks to get 'the best phone'.
The Moto X Pure works very well and is very fast on Ting's GSM network.

I previously owned the Nexus 4 for almost three years. After debating over the Nexus 6P and the Moto X Pure for several weeks (as another excellent review breaks down in great detail) I decided on the MXP. After three months with the device, here's what I like so far:

* Price. After the Nexus 4, and prior to that a Trac phone (don't hate), I knew I wanted to stay on an unlocked device. I also needed a serious hardware upgrade (read: much better camera), but didn't want to wait for the 6P and fork over the extra dollars. For $400 plus tax and about $50 for a glass screen protector and 64GB micro SD card, I feel like I made out.

* A truly pure Android experience. After using Google Launcher on my Nexus 4, I knew I would never submit to bloated carrier-ware on a contract-bound phone — like, EVER. Motorola simply and decisively stays out of the way on their G and X products, only inserting themselves for some practical features that I find myself using daily (i.e., twisting the phone to open the camera, 'chopping' the phone to turn on and off the flashlight, saying 'Hey there, Moto X — play [song title]' while cooking or folding laundry). I'm a firm believer in their strategy to stick to the basics, and it makes for a clean and satisfying user experience.

* Screen size. This was something I was initially skeptical about, as I have small hands. I was so attracted to the clarity and contrast of the screen, however, that I couldn't resist. I find this phone remarkably easy to hold (the circular divot in the back guides finger placement), and would challenge those who are wary of phablet-style devices to give this a spin — I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.

* Picture quality. A big plus of the MXP is the 21 megapixel camera. There are plenty of reviews that break down how this camera stacks up against the iPhone 6 Plus and Nexus 6P, and it's clear each has their strong suit (the iPhone 6s Plus, for example, has lower megapixels but reportedly superior aperture). I've found the camera to be excellent in outdoor settings, specifically; photos are clear and lighting appears natural, if not slighter higher in contrast. Many reviewers take issue with the minimal camera interface, but I'll argue again that Motorola did this intentionally, hiding the features from view until you need them. Tapping anywhere on the screen (except the focus 'circle') takes a picture, as does squeezing anywhere on the volume buttons. You can also use your customized voice command (mine is 'Hey there, Moto X') to say 'Take a picture' or 'Take a selfie'. It's a elegant solution and a refreshing change for quickly taking high quality pictures without missing the moment.

* Front-facing speakers. Although I'm no sound expert and mostly listen to music through a bluetooth pairing feature in my car, sometimes you just need an impromptu kitchen dance break. For these important moments, the sound is better than any phone I've heard in recent house-party history. If you find yourself without a decent speaker system and want to share a song or YouTube video with someone 'like, right now', the sound carries with impressive clarity. Turn down for what.
Probably the best phone I've ever owned. Power, speed, looks, what is there not to love?

I needed to upgrade from a Moto E due to memory issues and am completely satisfied with my Moto X. Copying apps and contacts was quick and painless. Immediate update to Android 6.0 was a pleasant surprise. Activation to TracFone' s BYOP  plan was flawless after buying a sim card. I never thought I would be a fan of big phones, but I am liking the size of this one.
LOVE THIS PHONE

I really love this phone. I changed from a Samsung Galaxy S4 and I can say this phone is trully amazin, it's pretty fast, the sound from the Stereo Speakers is simply amazing.

The only thing I kinda don't like is the screen that sometimes it turns on (one of the Moto functions), but you can easily desactivate that option.
Great phone for the price.

Had this phone 3 months. Love it. Super fast and user friendly. I would definitely buy Gain and recommend this phone. You can use on Verizon but you have to use an existing sim card from a different phone. You have to cut a micro sim down to a nano sim size. I did it and it works great.
Very good Celular, the truth is the best we've had, it works perfectly, fast, good front and rear camera.

Great phone. Between the availibility and the price it doesn't get better than this. From a note 4 that was almost $900 last year this phone blows it out of the water. Excellent display, camera is good and sweet vanilla android fluidity is never a problem. Do not hesitate if you're in the market for a lower priced flagship.

This is a great phone, especially when considering the price point.  I was reluctant to switch after my old iPhone 5s finally bricked, to an Android device with such a large screen.  However, after using this phone, I doubt that I will ever go back to iOS or to the smaller size screen.  I do have some advise if you are switching from iOS to Android.  Turn off iMessage on your iPhone before switching the sim card to the new Android phone.  To do this I had to put my sim card in another iPhone to turn that setting off.  This can cause issues with text messages sent from iPhones, if iMessage is not turned off prior.  Other than that, all you have to do to activate this phone on AT&T is change out the sim card.  You can still import all of your contacts from your iClound account.  It just takes a few extra steps.  I actually ended up buying two of these phones, as my wife wanted to switch after she played around with my Moto X.

Buying unlocked phones is the way to go.  I can't believe what a terrible deal that AT&T next plan is.

I upgraded from a Moto X to the Pure. At first I was terrified I would drop it as it is slippery and MUCH bigger than my old Moto, but once the Supcase was put on, it is much better grip for my small hands. I LOVE the fact that it is basically "pure" without all the bloatware my old phone came with. I had just gotten the Lollipop on the old phone, and this one shipped with same, plus option to upgrade to Marshmallow. Holding off on that a bit till I read the release notes a bit more. This phone is beautiful, the pics/sound quality is awesome, and it is FAST!!!
Best phone I have ever had.  Upgrade to Marshmallow out of the box.  Calls are nice and clear, GPS and pretty much everything is smooth.

I've had the phone for a couple of days.  It's been a mixed bag.

First, activation.  I love the fact that the phone will work with any carrier.  If one buys the phone direct from Motorola, one can pay $5 and get a carrier specific SIM card; SIM cards are apparently used for both CDMA carriers like Sprint and Verizon, as well as GSM carriers like ATT and T-Mobile.  You can then activate the phone yourself, at least on Sprint, which I use; this is what my son did.

If you buy the phone from Amazon, like I did, you need to get a SIM card on your own, Amazon doesn't seem to sell these.  You're supposed to be able to get a SIM card at a carrier store, for me my local Sprint-owned full service store.  I called my local store, twice, and was told this would not be an issue, I should just come on in.  I did, and of course it was an issue, the store personnel had a tough time finding a compatible SIM and activating my phone.  But finally they did.  Since the service model of buying a phone online from a third party like Amazon and then activating it with a carrier, at least a US CDMA carrier like Sprint or Verizon, is new, it's not surprising that many Sprint store personnel have technical problems.  Hopefully Sprint and Motorola will get the glitches out, and things will work more smoothly in the future.  SIM cards have been part of the process for GSM carriers for years, but are new to Sprint and Verizon.

The more important issue for me is that the Bluetooth on my phone does not work reliably, and is so far unusable.  I wish to use the phone with my car radio; Bluetooth worked perfectly between my car's Clarion radio and my old iPhone 4S.  Not so with my Moto X Pure.  I could get the phone to pair, and then to connect, but the connection was unreliable, and the phone wouldn't reconnect when I restarted the car, without a lot of futzing, as it should.  For sure my iPhone did.

I checked the owner forums on the Motorola web site, and a lot of Moto X Pure customers are having this and similar issues, both with Bluetooth enabled car radios, and with Bluetooth headsets.  These owners seem experienced with Android and technically savvy, and their devices worked well with other phones.  So, it appears there is a major problem with Bluetooth on this phone.  I put in a support request on the Motorola web site, but so far the responses are generic and do not seem helpful.

So, it remains to be seen whether or not  Motorola will solve this issue.  It's possible that I am doing something wrong - I'm new to android - but I don't think so.  If I get it working  I'll post here.  If not, I'll probably return the phone.

That's that bad news.  The phone is gorgeous, and for most things I have tried, seems to work well.  Generally, very fast, much faster (as expected) than the 3G iPhone 4S it is replacing.

But until I get the Bluetooth issue solved, I'm going to have to go with 2 stars.

The devices was decent.  Nice screen, snappy, decent camera and the latest Android OS.
I took excellent care of the phone, however, within a few months, I started having multiple issues.  Phone calls had so much static that I couldn't understand what the caller was saying half of the time.  Calls were fine when using bluetooth, but the not being able to hear out of the main ear piece presented problems.  The phone started dropping calls at random.  My previous phone never did this when using it in the same locations. The phone then started to get extremely hot, even when idle!  I could set it on my desk with no apps open, not charging, screen off, and it would become so hot it would almost burn my hand.  I could feel the heat coming through the TPU case.
When I finally contacted Motorola, things went from bad to a steaming pile of ****.  The customer service I received was so atrocious, that it alone says RUN AWAY!!  I could never check the status of my repair.  Calling them was a joke, as no one could ever give me a status on the repair.  It was constantly the repair team is gone or the system is having issues at the moment.  I finally got a shipping label emailed to me, but then never received my phone.  The tracking label status just stayed at "created".  This tells me the phone is still sitting at Motorola.  After calling (multiple times) they acknowledged that it was over their limit for turn around time, and I was promised that the device would be sent out and I would have it within 2 days.  Surprise, surprise... NO Phone.  So again I called, got disconnected and called back.  Run-around and run-around some more.  I had to demand a manager because they apparently do not know how to escalate issues.  They would rather feed you some line and get you off of the phone than to actually assist you.  Once I finally talked with a manager, the best they could tell me, without telling me, is that they lost my phone and have no clue where it is at.  Their solution is to have me order a new phone which will take 2.5 weeks to be delivered, and that isn't even for a custom design.  I have to ask myself, if I wouldn't have called (and called, and called) to the extent I did, how long would they have allowed me to go without a phone before acknowledging there was an issue?  Apparently being without one for over a month is fine in their eyes.  So unless you're someone that considers themselves lucky and will never need to utilize Motorola repair services, I would look elsewhere.  The headache is not worth it, trust me!

I've had this phone for about a week, and I can honestly say its amazong. At first I was a bit let down with the battery use but I quickly got over it because how fast it charges. But obviously the battery drained quickly with me because , I don't know about you but when I get I new phone I spend the majority of my time admiring and tinkering with it for the first few days. But now with regular use, I can get through a whole day, but just barely. I let it slide because of how fast it charges. The camera is great . obviously it won't compete with the likes of the galaxy phones but it can surprisingly hold its own against them. For me the camera is perfect, especially for just 400 $ you can't ask too much from the camera, but like I said the higher end phone cameras don't completely blow it out of the water. In a fair fight it would last a few rounds with those big guys ;) (galaxy s6 , note 5, lg g4, etc etc). As for the software, I'm loving the near stock is, its as smooth as butter, and I personally haven't encountered and slow down or stuttering, and it can play any game the app store can throw at it. The screen is gorgeous! That 2k screen amazing, obviously is not amoled like some higher end phones, but its still gorgeous none-the-less!! I'm blown away at the fact that you can get 2k resolutions on a 400$ phone . (besides some of the cheap Asian phones that don't get 4g in the united States, and sacrifice camera and build quality for it). Another great feature is the expandable storage! Something manufacturer's are leaving out in the hopes that you'll pony up more dough for larger internal storage. There is one thing that does bother me though, and that's the temperature this phone accumulates during extraneous use. It gets pretty hot, and that surprised me considering the snapdragon 808 processor was supposedly cooler than the 810. But I've had experience with both and they get to about the same temperature. Dont get me wrong, its not to the point where you cant hold it but it does get annoying and i do find my hands get a little sweaty after holding it for long periods of time. But it only happens if I use it while charging , play demanding games or am installing multiple applications. All in all , for the price, this phone is amazing. I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a decently priced phone with good specs that won't empty out your wallet.

Just got my Moto X Pure Edition directly from Motorola (I used the MotoMaker to design my own).

First, I couldn't find any description of what's included anywhere (not even on Motorola's website). I even asked Motorola customer care and while they answered my question, they gave me wrong information. Here's what's in the box:
1. The Phone (obviously)
2. Turbo Charger
3. Sim ejection tool
4. Clear polycarbonate phone bumper
5. Quickstart guide and warranty information

The included Turbo Charger is a single piece. This means that there is no USB to disconnect to use the cable portion of the charger as a means to connect to your computer. If you need to connect your phone to your computer, you'll have to use a different cable.

Build Quality and Feel:
The phone really feels solid in my hands. I like the 5.7" screen size, but I'm not fully used to it yet coming from a smaller 4.8" screen. I'm sure after a few weeks I'll think my old phone is too small. This phone still fits in my front jeans pocket without problems and doesn't feel "too big" like I thought it might.

Hardware:
Still haven't had a chance to take too many pictures but the ones I have taken look awesome in medium to well-lit scenarios. Photos in low-light (as mentioned by others) aren't stellar. Mine were blurry (despite holding as still as possible) and had low detail. This one shortfall of the camera is something I can deal with. Otherwise, the hardware is snappy and very responsive. Using AnTuTu benchmark I scored 48598 in 32-bit mode. While not the highest score, I don't believe this is taking into account some other processes that Motorola offloads onto other engines making the actual Android experience snappier and quick. I am still conflicted on the location of the volume rocker. I like it now on the right side so that I can watch movies in landscape mode without accidentally touching the volume rocker, but as a creature of habit, I'm still used to it being on the left side of the phone. The power button has a nice texture that allows you to easily distinguish it from the volume rocker without looking.

Software:
About as pure of an Android experience as you can get without a Nexus device. Plenty of other review out there about that. I purchased the 32gb model and from the factory I have 24gb of free space. With all the apps and other cached data after a few days of use, I'm down to 18gb of available space. I feel that the 32gb version is essential unless you plan on storing all of your photos/videos on an SD card.

Odds/Ends:
Others have complained about the proximity sensors being on all the time and being able to see them in the dark. Yes, I can see them in the dark, but no they do not shine on the walls or ceiling. Even when I hold objects close to them, they are not "projecting" light. These sensors do not bother or annoy me and are extremely difficult to even detect. I haven't noticed any issues yet with the speakers at full volume as others mentioned.

Will update with more detail as I before more acquainted with the phone.
The glass does not fit well, the case is big and heavy and it doesn't fit well either. The cables work fine

Overall it is a nice phone for this price range.Display - It is good, but not as good as AMOLED displays in galaxy phones
Performance - Using it for last 1 month, didn't notice any lag. Similar to LG G4
Battery life - good enough for 12-16 hrs of moderate to heavy use
Size - I feel comfortable holding this without using both hands.
Android - no bloat ware - almost close to vanilla android  experience. There are few customizations done by Motorola, but they are all very use full
Sound quality - it's ok , not exceptional.
Call quality - good - can't really comment on this because of the patchy T-Mobile network
Charging - turbo charging works perfectly
Cons - No support for Google FI network, no finger print reader.
it's value for money

I've been using this phone for about a week or so now. I could write a huge, lengthy review about its specs and performance and how it compares to other phones. But you can easily check that information out for yourself on sites that do just that for you.

My smartphones to date have been the Droid X, Galaxy S3, HTC One (M8), and now this phone. Sometimes knowing this helps you get some perspective on what I'm used to.

Hands down my favorite phone was my HTC One. I loved the feel, the sound, the screen (quality and size). That said. this phone is quickly growing on me, though. It's super quick, I've never had it stutter. Network and WiFi signals are always coming through strong (I'm in a NY suburb outside of NYC on T-Mobile). Objectively, I'm giving this phone 5-stars because it performs exactly as I expected it to when I ordered it. I'm getting everything they've advertised so far. I've had no problems setting it up, no hardware or software glitches - nothing. I'll update this review if any of that changes, but until then assume it's working great.

Pros and cons are subjective, so they may not matter as much to you. My rating is not based on these factors.

Pros:
+Good sound
+Great screen
+Clean, stock Android
+Only a couple of lightweight, Moto apps that are helpful.
+ Seems like Android updates are quicker than most other manufacturers.
+ Expandable storage (which seems to be going the way of the dinosaur lately).

Cons:
- Seems like phones are getting bigger and bigger. This one is significantly larger than my HTC One M8, and that's without a case on it.
- If you want the very latest Android version as fast as you can get it, consider Nexus.
- No fingerprint/biometric access.
- Non-removable battery.

Positives: Good clear screen.  Customizable home screen.  Easy camera access by shakinig.
Negatives: My phone won't sleep.  I come back an hour after using it and the screen is still on.  This causes batter drain.  Ringer is the way up, but makes no sound with an incoming call. (Really bad when you can't find your phone so want to call it).  It thinks select cell phone numbers are home phones and will not allow texting to those numbers.  Screen locks and won't scroll.  Cool voice activation where the phones listens for your catch phrase, doesn't actually work. Shaking the phone to activate camera works 50% of the time.
The worst is calling customer service twice spending an hour on the phone each time and they tell you they will send you a replacement and you can send the phone back to them... for $25!  So they make money off of your phone not working.  Um, no thanks!

Very fast and responsive with a beautiful display. Fits in hand nicely. Its a big phone compared to my previous phones. Love the bamboo back and the quick charge feature.  Occasional difficulty getting the Bluetooth to connect in the car when multiple phones are synced, but this could be the car system not the phone.
Everything ok

I'm 100% happy with my purchase. Beware, this is quite a big phone. I have quite big hands, and still I have some trouble handling the phone with one hand. However, the tradeoff is worth it, since this phone is fast and clean and the big display is very welcome. There's basically no clutter (being basically 95% or so pure android) and after being a Samsung Galaxy user, I'm glad I switched to a "purer" android phone.

Now I don't know if it's usual on this brand or just my particular phone, but one thing of note is that the phone rebooted itself after 1 or 2 days of use out of nowhere. The clock went insane and I couldn't make it sync automatically so I had to enter that data manually (it went back to jan 1 1980). It also asked to update a bunch of stuff that I had just updated the night before. It was weird and it freaked me out. Thankfully it hasn't happened again and later that day I could make the phone sync the time automatically and everything's been ok ever since that hiccup. It might have had something to do with me updating it to Marshmellow, but who knows.

I am writing this review for the unlocked 32GB version of the Moto X Pure Edition smart phone. I have had this phone for a little less than 3 hours and can attest to the following...

Pros:
- OS: As the name "Pure Edition" states, this phone comes with a clean version of Android without any bloatware.
- Bluetooth: I was able to get my Jabra BT2406 paired up with the device, and working in no time.
- Camera: As nice as they claim it is, has HDR so that's a plus.
- SIM: The phone came with a SIM ejector tool I was able to use for easily installing my card.
- Phone: The voice was crisp and clear, both through the phone and over my BT headset.

Cons:
- Video: Can't do more than 30fps at 1080p.
- Charging: Took roughly 90 minutes to get to a full charge (from 0% to 100%) but this was on the first charge, will update if better in the future.

I have been an HTC loyalist since getting the Droid DNA in 2012. I liked the build quality, and I was even more impressed with the HTC One M8. The speakers were phenomenal, the design was solid and distinctive, and I felt that the Sense Android skin was the least intrusive at the time. After upgrading to Lollipop, though, the phone struggled and over time got progressively worse. I had skipped the M9 after the lukewarm upgrades, and hoped the A9 would be the next big thing. Unfortunately, it just seems like an iPhone clone, and a poor one at that. No more dual speakers, no new ideas in the design, it was just the end of the line for me. I figured that I should just go unlocked, but the new Nexus was simply too big and untested for me. That left Motorola, who I’ve had a number of people tell me had really improved their phones, and bonus! Had a dual speaker setup. I decided to pick up the Moto X Pure Edition.

Let’s start with the toughest metric to quantify, the experience of using the phone. So far, the MXPE has been a fantastic phone. It’s amazing how great it is to have the option not to install the standard carrier bloatware. The only carrier app I’ve installed is the hotspot, which means in my case I’ve shaved 16 useless apps off my list. Just on that basis alone this was a smart move, but that’s not the only massive improvement. The Moto actions are a great benefit, and while I’m not as all in on voice commands and letting the phone run my life as others may be the fact is I’m finding more utility from these features. The voice recognition seems better, the response is quicker, and in general it just seems more usable. Overall, I’m just enjoying using the phone. In the end, tech specs and marketing don’t matter, you have to like using the phone if it has any chance at success. For me, the MXPE passes with flying colors.

After experience, hardware and software come into play. It would have been great if the speakers on the MXPE could match what HTC had in their Boomsound hardware, but I knew going in that wouldn’t be the case. Still, the speakers are pretty good, and while they lack some of the HTC polish it’s nowhere near enough to balance out the other deficits. The overall sound quality is very good, the vibration is enough to notify me of an alert, and while I know there are better displays on other phones I’m very happy with the image quality of the MXPE. The camera takes great pictures, although like others I am still trying to adjust to the actual controls for it. They’re not terrible, but they are pretty unique so it’s a little more of a learning curve than in the past. The speed of the phone is great, no stuttering or sluggishness so far in using any apps. I was able to simply move my SIM from my M8 into this phone and was in service within 5 minutes, no calls to the carrier or configuration in the website, which is a first and a welcome change.

In summary, I’m very happy with what Motorola has produced here. On paper it may not be the most amazing phone in the world, but in my day to day use of the device I have no complaints. Whether you are looking to try Motorola as an alternative to what you have now like I was, or you just want a phone that’s enjoyable to use, the Moto X Pure Edition is an easy recommendation.

I got it 45 days ago, I was watching youtube when it suddenly turned off by its own. I thought the battery died and I went to charge it and it never charged.
