I bought an iPhone 6s and after a month I don't want it. I miss Android. I had about 25 different Android phones in the past 4 years. Not even kidding. I tried the iPhone 6s because I haven't had an iPhone since the iPhone 3g and wanted to try it out again. After deciding it's not for me, I did some research into some of the newer Android phones. My last phone was a LG G Flex 2, had a G3 before that. I was debating on getting the g4 since it's only about $400 on Amazon brand new. I had the HTC One M7 & M8 and loved the front facing speakers on them so I wanted to get something that had front facing speakers. After much research it was between the Moto X Pure and the Nexus 6. Obviously I chose the Moto X Pure and unfortunately it's going back for a few reasons.

I bought this from Amazon Warehouse. I've bought from them before and had both good and bad experiences. After chatting with a rep I decided to buy from the Warehouse and received it a couple of days later. The packaging was all there, and everything that was seen in unboxing videos were also in the package and everything seemed in good shape. It said there were marks on it but I didn't see it and I have an eye for seeing any imperfections.

I fired it up and put it on the quick charger because it was about 15% full. While using the quick charger and setting up the phone, it fully charged in about an hour. Of course it was incredibly hot on the back of the phone, most likely from all the inside components working simultaneously. Setup was easy, especially since I was used to Android to begin with. About an hour after I set everything up, the phone froze and reboot itself. I thought it was weird, because I don't remember any phone of mine freezing and restarting on it's own. Unfortunately that was not the last time it happened. I used the phone for a few days and it kept randomly rebooting itself. I personally did not root it, and I don't know if the person before me messed around with anything but it's unlike anything that has happened to me before.

The freezing and random reboots, along with Moto not releasing updates in a quickly fashion made me want to return it and I am returning it tomorrow. There's some other quirks. The battery is kind of terrible. After taking it off of a charge, it loses 1 % after about 10-15 minutes of not even using it. My old G3 had 100% battery for about 1.5 hours before it would lose 1 percent and that was with a battery that was well over a year old. The screen on this phone isn't that good either. For some reason I have a bad time typing on it. Never had that issue before. Even with the good specs it kind of lags.

I am going to order the Nexus 6P, and if that doesn't work out I'll return it get a G4, if that doesn't work, return it and get a G3 again with Kit Kat. That was one of my favorite phones of all time and I was able to root and add custom ROMS easily. Not necessarily looking to do that now, but tinkering with rooting and Xposed yields excellent results for both battery and performance.

Bought this through Motorola. I was more pumped to get this phone than any other. Got it, and man, what a letdown.

* The good
Near stock Android is great.
Feels very good in your hand. A little narrower than the Note 4, but feels quite a bit smaller.
Price is fantastic.

* The average
Camera is solid in good lighting. Pics look sharp in natural light. But not even close to cameras on Samsung or IPhones.

* Growth spots
Speakers get crackly too often. They peak too soon. If sound is low, you're ok. Turn it up and I hear that crackle.
You're kidding yourself to think your battery will make it through the day with moderate to heavy use. Battery is a significant letdown to me.
Camera interface is awful. No button, you just touch the screen. No touch to auto focus.
Screen is OK. When coming from AMOLED or a retina, you will see a difference. For me, it is comparable to watching a blu Ray and a DVD. Not terrible, but enough to where I could notice a difference.
The OS feels a little hesitant to me on numerous occasions, not as zippy as an unlocked, just out of the box phone should feel.

I so wanted to love this phone. I've been so hyped for it ever since the Moto X came out and couldn't possibly see myself not owning it for years. But actually having it in hand, using it, putting it through the daily rigors, I can absolutely,without hesitation, say that i am disappointed in this offering to the point of returning it. It feels like a step down to me from what I was on simultaneously, a Note 4 and am iPhone 5S.
If you buy this expecting true flagship phone status, be prepared to be let down. I'm not an electronics snob by any means, but this phone does have notable shortcomings that push it into mid-range territory, not along the lines of a high-build Samsung or an iPhone. If you view this as an above-average phone, and not a flagship, you'll be fine. But to expect a Samsung or  iPhone performance from a phone at half the cost is unreasonable.

I bought 2 of this to replace a Nexus 4 and a Nexus 5. There was nothing wrong with both of the Nexus; I just wanted to replaced them.

I ordered a 32GB Black and a 32GB White. The black one had absolutely no problem at all on T-Mobile's network. The first White one that I received had a bad radio--it would not reconnect to the new tower after travelling. It would say I have full signal, but when I try to go online or make a call, it will just not go through.  Fortunately, Amazon was able to replace it for me and now everything works as it should.

If you are buying this phone now, you will receive an Android 6.0 update.

The camera is very good for a $400 phone. It is not as good as a the Samsung S7 but I certainly would not be embarrassed to show it to other people.The battery life on this phone is incredible. For me, it will has at least 8 hours with about 40 minutes of web browsing with constant refreshing (I read manga/comics online), 10-20 minute of YouTube at 1080p, and moderately heavy texting. All of this is with adaptive brightness set to 50%.

The only downside to this phone is that you will only have a handful of accessories. You are not going to have much choices in case makers. I found only about 5 brand name companies that makes cases for this one: Incipio, SUPCASE, Diztronic, Casemate, Poetic, and Imak. So if you are one of those people that love to accessorize, then this phone is probably not for you.
Such a good phone for the money. Worked perfectly out of the box. Highly recommend .Great look and feel, runs fast and smoothly, super camera, good battery life, fast charging. Overall excellent!

This is my favorite phone that I've owned or used (I will be sure to edit this review if I ever have reason to feel otherwise due to reliability and such).  For reference, I am coming from an LG G2.  I really loved many features of the G2, such as the double tap to wake feature and the buttons on the back, and I was afraid to lose those features.  However, the G2 was just a nightmare phone from the beginning (and to make things worse, LG is a terrible company to work with and they have serious quality control issues).  I wish I could say it was an isolated issue, but my wife also has the G2 and has had similar persistent issues.  Anyway, it was time to move on, and I am so glad I did!

What I love about this phone:
• The Moto enhancements.  It’s crazy that just a few simple additions to Android could take the OS from good to great, but that’s exactly what Motorola has done!  I almost never have to push the power button to wake my phone because it just knows when I want to turn it on.  Good bye tap to wake – I don’t miss that feature at all because this is even better!  And how many times have you pushed the power button just to check the time on your phone?  All you have to do is look at the MXP and it’ll show you the time.  Very cool!  And then there’s the twist motion that pulls up the camera – genius and awesome!  It’s very fast and has made my phone that much more convenient to use as a camera.  I also love being able to turn on the flashlight with a chopping motion (though it’s not as reliable as the camera motion, but I may just need to re-calibrate the gyro sensors).  I never want to be without these features again!
• If you read reviews about the MXP’s camera, you’ll see many comments about how it’s not as good as Samsung or iPhone cameras and many will downplay the camera app on the MXP.  It may not be the very best camera out there, but it’s very good and I am happy with it!  I like it much better than the camera on my G2 (which was a camera that received a lot of good reviews and praise) – I got so many bad/pixelated photos with the G2’s native camera app that I never used it and downloaded a third party camera app.  With the MXP, I’m very happy with the camera app and have little use for a third party app now.  The MXP's camera loads very fast as well.  And, again, I love being able to twist to open the camera, which makes it possible to pull the phone out of your pocket, twist on your way up to position, and have the camera ready almost as soon as you are physically able to take a picture.  This is far superior to having to unlock your phone and tap on the camera icon, or even swipe the camera icon on the lock screen.  The most important thing with any camera is the ability to take great pictures, and as far as I'm concerned, this camera does just that.  Even in lower light situations, which many say this camera does poorly with, I find the pictures to be good.  It's also very capable with close up shots - I was testing the camera by taking pictures of my 3 year old daughter and she came and climbed right on top of me so that the camera was mere inches from her and it focused great considering the range and constant motion (both my daughter moving and me trying to keep the camera still despite being jostled by her practically tackling me).  And that was indoors with nothing more than light from a window.
• I’ve seen complaints that Moto Voice isn’t as fast or reliable as Google Now, but this has not been my experience.  The only issue I’ve had so far is that Moto Voice doesn’t work for very many things if I don’t have WiFi on (I don’t have data with my plan, so this issue really won't apply to very many people as most have a data plan), but I’m pretty sure I just don’t have something set up right on my phone because I think it’s supposed to be able to make calls with or without a data connection, and that’s the main thing that I haven’t been able to do.  Regardless, I like Moto Voice – I love being able to have a custom phrase; it’s fun and I was able to pick something easier to say than “OK Google” (there’s something about saying that phrase that just doesn’t roll off the tongue very easily).  Also, Moto Voice works whether your phone is awake or not.
• The customization is fun.  I never really cared before what the back of a phone looked like and never understood why everyone made such a big deal about how “premium” the back of a phone was.  You’re going to cover it up with a case anyway, so why does it matter?  Well, when you can make your phone match your style as you can with the MXP, it suddenly actually does matter.  For once in my life, the back of the phone is a big deal to me and I found myself immediately seeking out a clear case that will show it off.
• This is a “minor” thing, but a detail that I really appreciate and didn’t know about until I got the phone – the camera lens is recessed a little below the surface of the phone.  Every other phone I’ve owned had it flush with the back of the phone and it got finger print smudges on it and was more prone to getting scratched.  With the MXP, I don’t get finger print smudges and I worry less about scratches because it’s recessed, and that holds value to me.
• I love the screen size (I think I would actually like to go to a 6” screen with my next phone).
• Front facing speakers are something I’ve wanted for a long time, and I can now say that it truly is the way to go and I’m thrilled to finally have them.  And these speakers are good, to boot!
• The turbo charger is fast.
• Water repellent – for a little peace of mind.
• Pure Android – nothing added to bloat the system.
• Expandable memory.  With Marshmallow, this feature has reached new heights as you can add an SD card and have the phone adopt it as internal memory.  That means you can go with the base 16GB model and just buy an SD card to get however much memory you want for less than the cost to go up to a 32GB or 64GB model.

Nitpicks:
• I wish the battery had a larger capacity, but it’s sufficient for a day’s use (at least for now as a brand new phone – it could become an issue a year or two down the road as the battery loses capacity…).  If the battery was user replaceable, that would be an ok solution (not that I would actually carry around an extra battery, but I would like to be able to replace it when it starts losing capacity to go all day).
• I wish Moto Voice had more functionality without a data connection, or that I could figure out what I have wrong in my settings if that’s the issue.  I see no reason why I shouldn’t be able to get Moto Voice to make a call for me without a data connection.  But, this may just be a problem on my end and not actually a problem with Moto Voice.
• I didn’t like how big the icons were, but that was an easy fix by installing Nova Launcher.
• I can't tell the difference between QHD screens and 1080p.  From the research I’ve done, QHD apparently isn’t much more of a drain on the battery than a 1080p screen (contrary to popular belief and what I believed), but it does tax the battery a little more and I don’t see the value in it.  Also, from what I've read, while it doesn't make a very big difference in battery life, it does make a significant difference in all around performance of the device.  Whatever the case, I would rather they put a standard screen on there and put the investment toward a bigger battery capacity.  But, alas, QHD seems to be the new norm.
• I don’t get the dimple on the back - it does nothing for me.  I just keep thinking I’m touching the camera lens (you’d think coming from a G2 that wouldn’t be the case, but that was a different kind of feel than the dimple…).  But I know many people love the dimple and find it useful. *Edit: As I have continued using the phone and have gotten used to the dimple, I am finding that it does help a little, so it's not as useless as I originally thought.

If you are looking for Android pure edition this one is one of the best phones on the market. Absence of a fingerprint reader is a negative but for the rest it is a well designed and made phone. Thank you Moto

I bought this phone for my girlfriend. The phone itself is wonderful unfortunately the microphone Cuts in and out. I've been unable to reach anyone in customer service to exchange the  defective phone. That's the only reason I'm giving this a one star.
Great Product

I bought it because I needed a new phone asap. I wanted to get a Nexus 6P instead but I couldn't wait. At first  I wasn't sure about this phone, I've been using it for around a month and I love it! It's snappy, no lags whatsoever, the screen look good! The only 2 things that would bother a bit, would be the battery life, it's not great, it isn't bad, it's just fine, but it charges fast so it's ok for me; the second issue would be the camera, pics look great! BUT it has a really hard time focusing, an option it's just to use another camera app.

For the price this is amazing. I love the few tweaks moto added in. Although I noticed the moto actions still has a few bugs I hope they can fix this soon. It would also be nice to have the moto voice working without data even just to send text message and set alarm, reminder. The bamboo looks really good and this stock design variation I think is the best design combo. I heard a lot of bad reviews with the free bumper that came. Personally I love it, I think it really goes well with the bamboo and the white front; as a matter of fact I think it looks better for some reason. My only regret is that I should gone for the 32 gb since lollipop takes almost 30% of the 16 gb capacity. But I think Ill have to go now for a quality microsd.

Cons: MOTO assist tho very great and useful I think needs to be a little more polished and honestly I think theres alot more potential applications than what is available at the moment. such offline moto assist for some of the voice commands. Lastly if we could only customize moto gestures like say launch a certain app with the twist gesture (dont get me wrong but I really love the twist camera but I would have loved it more if I could launch a different camera app instead of the stock)

Best Android experience to date!! I am coming from the Note 4 which had slightly better battery and took better pictures (once you got the app open). After the Lollipop update my Note 4 started to stutter and was never the same although stuttered less over time. The Moto X Pure Android experience is far superior to anything I've tried in terms of response and fluidity. Also the features that Motorola adds like the double twist to access the camera and the double chop to turn on the flashlight are incredible. I can capture pictures much faster and won't miss as many moments compared to the length of time it took to get to the Note 4 camera, to me this makes up for the slight difference in camera quality. Also I have heard a few people talk about the build quality not being up to par with other flagships. I completely disagree, coming from the Note 4 the black base model I purchased on Amazon feels sturdy and looks clean with the edge to edge display and no physical button. I also like the width compared to the Note 4 which is slightly narrower and easier to hold in the hand. Also the curve in the back when holding with one hand makes it easier to grip vs the Note 4. This would be the perfect phone if it had a camera on par with the Galaxy flagships and longer battery life, although quick charge is nice and the phone should last a day under normal use. For $399.99 this phone is a steal, especially compared to the cost of a iPhone or Galaxy device. The ability to use this phone on any carrier or use it globally by swapping out the nano sim is also an added benefit!

Only reason this is not five stars is that no less than 12hours after purchasing the price dropped significantly. Was extremely pissed but the phone is pretty badass though I should have waited to save a few bucks

It says unlocked. It does not work with t-mobile prepaid sim card. It says can not complete the call. Called T-mobile. I was told the IMEI of the phone is not valid and the phone itself is blocked. Further explained to me that it could be that the phone is not completely paid for. Contacted Amazon. I was told the best way is to call Moto. Called Moto I was told the best way is to call Amazon. Finally I decided the best way is to send the phone back to where it comes from. By the way to be fair I love the phone. It does everything perfectly except making a phone call.

Two months later: Amazon gracefully exchanged the phone for me. This time it is really unlocked and T-mobile prepaid card working fine!

But ... yesterday it started doing UNTHINKABLE things. First the text messaging keyboard does not pop up. Then I found out any app with an input at the bottom does not popup keyboard. Just as I was wondering what's going on, the phone started many apps one after another. One of the apps it opened was the camera. And it started taking pictures and I can not stop it!!! It then even turn the camera from back camera to front and shot my face! It then attached the picture and sent it through text message to a person in my contact! OMG!
The phone itself is totally totally awesome, but beware the customer care service at Motorola is the worst I've ever dealt with.

I bought the moto x pure edition 2nd generation 64Gb directly from the Motorola website. The phone features are fine, very little bloatware. But the hardware quality is poor given the price. After a month the headphone jack started giving me some trouble. While listening to music I would notice that the bass would go off, or the singer's voice. Very strange. I complained to Motorola and they sent me a new one (they charge your credit card for the replacement and then refund you when they receive the old one, which is great). No complains on customer service. The replacement worked fine for 6 months and now the headphone jack is giving me trouble again. If I move the cable too much the music app thinks it has been disconnected and the song pauses. Very frustrating.
On top of that my screen is now cracked. I droped it once. A couple of my friends have the same phone, and their screens are cracked too. I had a nexus 4(made by LG) before, which I dropped many times and it never cracked.
When you pay for an expensive phone you expect quality. This is not a quality phone, no matter how fancy the features are. I'm pretty sure I'll never risk buying Motorola phones again.
Great phone!  Seems extremely high quality and at a great price.  I love the turbo charging.  The camera quality has also been extremely impressive so far.

IMO a great phone for the right price.  The camera could use some improvement wrt color accuracy, but this is a minor
nit.  The display is just about perfect, audio is very good.

Love it.  Came from Galaxy S3 and this thing is a good bit bigger, but not ridiculously so.  Still fits in my dedicated phone pocket with plenty of room to spare.

Software is great, close to Google's vision.  Hardware is solid, nice responsive screen, great sound from stereo speakers, good battery life.  Unlockable bootloader is a must for when vendors stop officially supporting the hardware.  Gives consumers options.

Only minor gripe was no included earbuds.  Maybe I'm spoiled, but I can't remember the last time I bought a phone and it didn't throw in some mic/earbuds.  Motorolla is missing out on a chance to have people walking around with a big M in each ear.  It's a great phone, but nobody recognizes it by looking at it.  It's a great phone, brag a little.
Excelent!

I purchased a Moto X direct from Motorola in December of 2014.  Less than two years after purchase the screen has gone none responsive.  I take immaculate care of my electronics, and the phone was being used as normal (work email) and the screen stopped working abruptly.  You can see the lock screen, but cannot activate it.  Likewise all moto gestures fail. The limited warranty of course covers only 12 months, so I'm SOL.  However I thought people would be interested to know this model has a known problem with the screen going unresponsive, and unrecoverable by any means including factory reset.  I will certainly never purchase a Motorola product again, and will advise anyone I know to look elsewhere.  Back to my old Nexus 5.

Big screen (5.7” Quad HD), nice look, powered with hexa-core processor and 3 GB RAM it's worthy for that price. One of the best features is the front camera: 5 MP with Wide-Angle lens and flash, so you can take the best selfies. If you order it directly from Motorola online store you can personalize it (on-screen hello message, engrave your name on the back side of the phone, change colors and choose if you like soft grip, wood or letaher backcover) but it will take more than a week to deliver. Works with the following frequency bands:

- GSM/GPRS/EDGE (850, 900, 1800, 1900 MHz)
- UMTS/HSPA+ (850, 900, 1700 (AWS),1900, 2100 MHz)
- CDMA (800, 850, 1900 MHz)
- 4G LTE† (B1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 12, 13, 17, 25, 26, 38, 41)

In ECUADOR: Claro and CNT Mobile (LTE Band 4, 1700 MHz); Movistar (LTE Band 2, 1900 MHz), so it works fine here in Ecuador (already working in CNT Mobile).

Box Content:
-1 phone (obviously)
-1 pick to open SIM card slot.
-1 Wall charger (cable it is not removable, so you can nnot use it as data cable)
- Owners manual
- ANYthing else!

Yes! Doesn't ships with a data cable or earphones, so you must buy them separately.

Hope this help.

Every phone should be like this. Twist for the camera, tomahawk chop for flash light, knows when I'm driving then reads texts and takes verbal replies. I'm sure in 2 years Apple will copy these features too.

I pre-ordered this phone directly from Motorola, using Moto Maker and I just received a few days ago and I'm very happy with it so far. The phone is big but it fits nicely in your hand and the silicone material is soft and smooth. I'm not sure what Motorola did to the silicone but I haven't gotten one stain on it or marks or fingerprints on it whatsoever. The battery life could be better but hey, I can get through a whole day with it without having to plug it in but I am not a real heavy gamer or user. The turbo charger that Motorola includes does what it is suppose to and it charges this phone quick. It charged from 30% to 100% in about 18 minutes. The bumper that came with it, is fine , nothing really special or bad about it, just your average bumper. The 808 in here is snappy and responsive. A tiny bit of lag every now and then but it is so miniscule that I really don't even think about it. I really haven't taken that many pictures with this camera but from  the pictures that I did take, the pictures look pretty good and clear. But I'm not really a camera expert so I couldn't really tell you the finer details. But all in all, fantastic phone for a great price .

Battery life is the achilles heel of this phone.  As a light user, I can barely get through a day without topping up.  It uses 3% battery during night when I left on the table when screen is off.  So the android system is still using power even if I set to sleep mode.

The screen itself also uses a lot battery power.  There is no need to use 2K screen for a phone with less than 6" screen, 1080P would be more than enough.  The higher resolution screen uses more battery power.  A 5.2 inch 1080p with 3000 mAh would be better for moderate user.  With current screen, at least a 3600 mAh battery is needed.

The size of the phone is also on the too big side.  A 5.2 inch screen would be better for barely one hand use.

The front dual speakers is the main feature for me to buy this phone.

Like the overall shape of the phone, has very good hand fell.

MicroSD card reader is a very positive plus.

I purchased used. It arrived without a tool to open the sim card. Due too the fact I owned several Samsungs and one HTC, had d to understand why Motorola design made it complicated to access the sims. I returned it and never had a chance to use the phone. Went back to Samsung.

It has it all. I won't go into specs u know that already what u really want to know how is battery life how camera performs how display and front facing speakers expendable storage turbo charge build quality vanila Android moto apps works ?
All more than impressed with whole package.
 Battery 4 hours screen on time I get trough the day no problems. I'm so happy with camera performance pictures are great. Display is super bright I don't know why people want amolet this thing is crisp sharp full of color. Build is solid speakers wow expendable storage is great and turbo charger charges my phone super fast. When people complain about this phone there is something wrong with them. And than $400 unlocked works on any network win win WIN.

Do not buy!!!!!!!! As soon as i got this phone it started to over heat more than any other phone I've ever had. It heats up while web surfing, or email reading. I called motorola and it been over a month since they said they were gonna send me a replacement phone. and the say there out of stock.
when my co worker ordered one after i called them and he received the phone in 7 days. thats why this phone is so cheap remember you get what you pay for. never buying anything from this company ever again. I'm going to report them to the BBB.

Everything they say about this phone is true, it's a great phone for the price.. However, my unit seems to have a serious over heating issue, my phone is literally making me sweat. I have no choice but to assume that this is a defective unit, will be returning.

Motorola does it again!  This is one of my favorite phones of all time.  Just buy one already you will not be disappointed.

PROS
+ Quick Charge can charge the phone very quickly.  No need to sit by the wall plug
+ The phone is fast and snappy.  No lag and apps load quickly
+ Finally has an expandable micro SD slot for additional storage.  Don't get me started on other manufactures who are not including this only to have you spend more money on higher internal storage.
+  No bloat wear installed on the device
+  Quick updates due to the stock nature of the device.  Already on 6.0 marshmallow.
+  Best bang for the buck smartphone on the market at this time.
+  Unlocked to work on any GSM carrier including BYOD plans like Cricket and Straight Talk (Will save you a ton of money)

CONS
- Motorola decided to go with and IPS panel and abandon the AMOLED screen on the previous generation.  This results in a good screen but lacks the pop and inky blacks of its predecessor.
- The camera is good but is outshined by others, but at the cost of a much higher price

Overall the phone is the best price vs spec device on the market.  I just wish they would have kept the AMOLED display from the previous generation.
So far so good , nice phone , a lot better than my galaxy was .

I have the original Moto X (2013 ). It still is a great phone. I wanted a bigger screen . Pure edition fits my wish.  Moto's unique software is the major reason to come back to Motorola.  Pure edition is a major upgrade for me.  Delighted to have Micro SD. Camera is a major improvement over the 2013 version. Beautiful screen. Nice stereo speakers.  Quick Charger. Battery is good and will last all day depending on your usage. Price is icing to the cake.  Highly recommend it.

This is a Nice phone, very fast, you can take beautiful pics, light, the only problem that I had was the battery, it runs out very fast, I contact with the vendor and the support department help me, They are very professional but I decide to return the item.
Thanks a lot

Coming from the HTC One M7 and being underwhelmed by HTC's 2015 offerings..I decided to ditch my brushed aluminum 5 inch One M7 and go in the opposite direction with the 5.7 Bamboo and White Moto X Pure!

Pros:
Great Price
Beautiful Screen (saturation and color gambit is perfect in my opinion..)
Beautiful Bamboo Back (THis is REAL woods and you can tell once you touch it for the first time. Astonishingly nice..!)
Loud, Clear Front Facing Speakers (Nicer than the speakers on my HTC One M7..so definitely an upgrade in my case)
SD Card Slot (Self explanatory..)
Quick Charging (Awesome, Awesome..Awesome..!!!)
The Motorola Features -- They're all simple, useful and seamless!
Clear Bumper Case Included --- I have no idea why clear bumper cases are not more popular. If you want to protect your phone a bit without covering up the beauty/design of the phone..the included bumper case is more than sufficient. I like it a lot!

Cons:
Phone is Large -- This phone is large. No way around that. I knew it was large..but since you cant see it in person..I was a bit shocked when I received it. After you get used to using two hands to control and the extra weight/bulkiness that it adds to pockets..you'll begin to appreciate the larger screen screen instead of seeing it as a burden..
Headset Sound -- The headset's sound is low and hard to hear. It's a real issue..but it's not one that presents itself unless you're having a conversation outside or in a noisy environment.
The Camera App -- The camera app's design is ugly and non-intuitive in my opinion. I hate it. Lack of manual controls..and is weird. BUT, it works..so I'll just have to get used to it.

Overall..I am VERY satisfied  with the phone. I think that the processor, the ram, the camera and the customization options make it a flagship and I hate that it's considered by some to be a upper mid-range phone.

Purchased it from Amazon..it arrived two days later and I walked into a Tmobile to activate it..and I havent looked back since..!

Hope someone out there finds this review helpful..as I to used reviews to help inform my decision to purchase..

It's been a month since I've used this phone. It's worth every penny, but I wish it came with a fingerprint sensor like the nexus and other phones have. Waiting for the Android Marshmallow update. The battery doesn't last me the whole day, so I have to be aware of the on-screen time. But it's a bargain, you can plug the turbo charger to boost the battery. I'm not a gammer so I don't have heating issues. The Camera is amazing, I like the 16mp widescreen shots taken in auto, its better than having a point and shoot imo. Haven't recorded 4k video, but the other features like slo-mo is good. The main reason why I bought this phone was for the pure Android experience. Motorola is known to deliver stock Android with a few helpful Moto apps. I like the assist functionality as it is accurate in reading my voice most of the times. The display is gorgeous but not helpful in direct sunlight. The call quality is good, had some minor hiccups with At&t though with a few call drops. WiFi sync is fast and webpages load faster. Love using Instagram on this phone, the pictures come larger than life with the on screen vivid display. And 16gb is more than enough because you can expand your memory. This is a huge upgrade coming from a Samsung s3 mini, because you don't see phones with decent specs and pricing.  This phone is definitely a 700$ smartphone killer. People who use phones need to think wisely about their daily use of mobile applications and the utility benefited from it.

A very nice phone for a very great price. This phone has a wonderful durable feel to it and a beautiful design. Purchased the 16GB to save money, and bought a microSD card instead for a way better price on memory. The screen is large and beautiful, and for a 5.7" screen, it's still comfortable to hold. The facial recognition unlock is wonderful to use (a bit weak in low light situations) but none the less is an amazing feature. Turbo charging is perfect, and takes about an hour and a half to complete, which is great if you're somewhere where you can plug in the charger. Screen responsiveness is 5/5. Camera is quite decent, not amazing like Samsung or Apple flagships, but for the price it's pretty damn good and you will not be disappointed. I.. really am quite surprised I haven't found a flaw in this phone because I'm extremely picky about everything.

I have had this device for about a month now and I certainly enjoy it. What you get in the Moto X is what you've always gotten in the Moto X. Very well-done hardware. Performance unencumbered by useless software, and what customizations there are truly are useful. Moto X Pure Edition isn't a huge departure from last year. The camera's better, a good bit better, but even then it's not necessarily leaps and bounds better. But for a camera in a $400 smartphone? I'd take it any day of the week, especially given what most of us do with our pictures anyway. Facebook doesn't need perfect. It needs good enough, and it needs easy.

Performance of the new Moto X is more than adequate. It handles things as they should, and without heat concerns. "All-day" battery life depends on your day. It's mostly been good for me but not spectacular. However Quick Charge makes up for that, for me, anyway. The software stays out of the way. And what it does add continues to enhance the experience.

My first Motorola, but really an amazing phone that feels like a high end model at a mid-level price. Beautiful, large screen with almost a pure vanilla version of Android. Too bad all manufacturers don't produce unlocked models without bloatware. This is the way to go as I can jump to any carrier I wish without being tied to a contract. I can honestly say I do not miss TouchWiz on my Galaxy S6. Can't wait to see what Marshmallow does with this phone let alone the custom ROMs that are and will be available. Motorola has a true number one contender here if they keep the Android updates coming.
Excellent!

I absolutely love this phone. I'm in I.T. and use my phone for work and personal use every day. This phone has the horsepower to handle heavy multi-tasking, and still has some battery left when I get home in the evening. The camera isn't quite as good in low light conditions as the Nexus 6P in my opinion, but that's about the only down-side. The MicroSD card slot makes up for that shortcoming and then some. The "Pure" Android experience, without added bloatware and customizations (Looking at you, Samsung and Verizon...) is also a big benefit.

I truly fell in love with this phone when it launched. I had many doubts about getting either this or wait until the new Nexus comes out, I was scared that it would turn out a rather disappointing. It hasn't. This phone surpassed so many expectations and I love every little detail about it.
My biggest complain with it, and I haven't heard this from others so I don't know if its for my unit specifically, but after heavy use and after a quick TurboCharge (I love the fast charging) the phone does get quite hot, almost to a point that I have to leave my phone on a table for a while because I can't hold it.
Still this phone is fantastic and I've had no regrets of buying this over a Nexus. (Those new Nexus still look pretty cool though)
I really love it.
This is the most underrated phone out right now. Pure android experience with a few awesome Motorola features.. It doesn't get any better than this. Love this phone!
When I received it, and I found its been used. There is also users information there.

This phone arrived on time and that was the only positive experience. I set it up without the sim card. It got extremely hot on the downloads. After placing the sim card in the battery drained in 3 hours of light use.. I had screen brightness at 20'..The phone arrived with fingerprints all over it, clearly a returned phone.  Probably returned for a bad battery then repackaged and sent to me. Sadly someone else will be sold this phone... Shame on u Amazon!!

I've had nothing but problems with this phone. I've had 10 or more android phones and never had a problem.

50% of the time I go to a website(it doesn't seem to matter which one) it will load 80% of the page and freeze. Eventually the "browser has stopped working, would you like to close" popup comes on and sometimes it will unfreeze, sometimes I have to restart. It doesn't matter if I'm on WiFi or 4g, what browser I'm using, I've power cycled, closed other apps, everything is updated,etc. The phone is just garbage apparently.

This is a great phone for people who miss dial up internet or have an Internet addiction they are trying to break.

I switched from the Samsung Galaxy s5 and i have no regrets. I really love this phone including the increased size. The price of the phone went down right after I bought it which amazon gave me the money back for, plus :). Only issue with this phone as other ppl have mentioned is the overheating. It's physically warm to touch when the battery gets low. Other than that I'm in love!
Love the phone but cannot get it attached to my Sprint account. what network are other purchasers using?
Well worth the price!

Moto X Pure Edition is good phone but there are major drawback for T-Mobile customers:
1, If you are T-Mobile customer it doesn't support wifi calling
2. When you make conference call, it heated
3. When charging it gets hot
4. When connect to your  WIFI network, battery drains very fast
5. You can use third party USB but it takes double time to charge your phone

I am thinking to return it if I have seen something else.

Let's start with the bad:

The camera takes picture very fast. The picture come up nice when there are enough light. However, this is a different story when the picture is taken indoor where light condition is not optimal. The picture come out too warm and in general, blur. I have tested it side by side with S6 edge and the S6 crashed the Moto X in this condition.

The other bad is there is no hard key. I find it really annoying to tap on the screen to get the soft key appear.

The good:
This is the best phone I have ever hold in my hand. It just feel right. Although it is a 5.7" phablet, I have no problem with 1 hand operating it. Sure, i still have to use my other hand to reach to the top of the opposite top corner, but i have no problem reaching the opposite edge with my thumb. I cannot do it on my Note 3, which is at 5.5".

The speakers is simple amazing. It blow both of my Note 3 and S6 out of the water.

I was looking for a phone with a larger screen to replace my iPhone 5. I did a great deal of research into the newer iPhones but had real concerns about spending $650 - $850 for a phone (carriers offer no real discounts for their existing customers). So I started looking at Android devices. I had Android devices for my first 5 years of smart phone use, so I didn't think it would be a big deal to switch back. There are a lot of larger screen Android phones out there! Many cost about the same as the iPhones. I focused my search on the following features and functionalities:
- bright, high quality screen with good color accuracy of at least 5"
- decent battery life
- good camera
- good voice quality
- at least 32GB of memory (or expandable with a SD card)
- dual front firing stereo speakers
- integration with Outlook calendars and contacts
- reasonable price

I did a great deal of research, including Android forums, Consumer Reports, other blogs and articles and Youtube reviews. I chose the Moto X Pure Edition as it scored very well in almost all categories and was $100+ less than any current option.

I have used this phone for about 3 weeks.Here are my observations: The quad HD screen is bright and beautiful. The stereo speakers are great for watching videos or listening to music. The battery lasts me all day and then some. It charges really fast with the included rapid charger. The SD slot allows for expansion if I need it down the road. In good light and outdoors, the pictures are incredible. (Indoor low light pics are not the greatest). The call quality is exceptional, both in regular and speakphone mode. It syncs well with my car (though a little strangely at times). And I can actually receive and make phones in the office building I work in, something I was never able to with my iPhone. The near pure Android experience is great, along with the excellent Moto features.

I am still getting use to Android and am now at the point that I seldom have to think about how to do something. The phone is large and heavy - all 5.5"+ phones are. A slightly smaller phone, say 5" to 5.2", would be easier for me to handle, but others have told me I'd get used to this in a couple months. (My iPhone 5 was only 4".) Was hoping there was an "iTunes for Android" app, but I have to convert my music using a different app. And lastly, I wish it would sync and integrate with Outlook calendar. I have decided to move to Google Calendar, which works flawlessly.

Price wise, this phone is very hard to beat. It was $100 less than the new Nexus 6P (seriously considered this phone) and still less than the new Nexus 5X (also seriously considered) with the "deal of the day" Amazon price. It was less than half the price of an iPhone 6 Plus or 6s Plus, and hundreds less than a Galaxy 6 or Note 5. Very happy with my purchase and the great "deal of the day" price on Amazon!
Perfect except the screen comes on every few minutes during the night.  Quite bright in a dark room.  Probably some setting I haven't found.
Muy bueno!
top 3 android phones I have ever owned. Narrower than the Nexus 6 so it fits into my hand better.

Very happy with this phone and can easily do whatever I need on it. It is not perfect but had it for a year now and glad to not be paying a monthly fee to my wireless carrier. By the end of 2 years I will have saved $200 from what Verizon would charge for monthly payments for the same 2 years.
This is the best phone I've ever had!

I absolutely love this phone. I've never purchased an unlocked phone until now and I am so glad I did. There are no carrier apps trying in futility to replace  functionality of perfectly good native apps already included in Android. The entire user experience on this phone is exactly what I've expected but never received from every previous mobile I've owned. It's going to get an update to Android 6.0 and I won't have to wait for AT&T QA to approve all the patches Motorola will be pushing out after, since the updates go direct from Motorola to my phone without intervention from my carrier.

The nerd in me also likes that I can enable the developer mode in Android and with two taps have the bootloader unlocked like I'm an OEM. This saves a lot of time messing around trying to exploit the boot image to flash custom firmware on the phone.

The Moto app actually does add functionality to the device that I actually want to use. That is probably the first time I've ever been happy about a vendor or carrier app coming pre-installed on my phone.

For the first time I feel like this is actually MY phone. Motorola earned a new fan with me. Thanks!

Very unhappy with the screen. Colors are too light and it makes me dizzy to look at the screen too long. Will most likely be returning this phone and getting one with an oled screen. Very disappointed.
Motorola is back!
Great phone love it!

I upgraded my phone from Sony Xperia Z Ultra to this phone, got it for under $300 for 64GB version so I recommend you to wait a little for around this price point (you can also check other colors) if you are not in a hurry to get it.

Below are list of pros and cons after using it for 1 month.
Pro:
1. Fast device.  This is a flagship phone so it runs fast and it will handle any games you can throw at it.
2. Stock Android.  For people that doesn't like the bloatware the comes with the major brands, this is your next best choice (not 100% stock because of the Moto app but it is as close as it gets unless you are getting a Nexus phone).
3. Supports SDXC and reads exFat format, which means you can also choose a smaller storage version and get an 128GB or 64GB SD card to get the space needed.
4.Splash proof.  Note that this is NOT waterproof so a little water is fine but you should not submerge it under water.
5. Moto gesture. You can twist the phone twice to get the camera on, very nice.  For some reason, I couldn't get the chop chop flash light gesture option to work.
6. Android update.  You can upgrade to Android 6 immediately after you get your phone.  I been having some issues with some of the games that I played after the update so you might want to consider before upgrade.

Con:
1. I read a lot of reviews that says this device use Snapdragon 808 compare to Snapdragon 810 so it does not run as hot as some other flagship phones.  I have not tried other devices that use 810 processor but this device does run very hot when using Turbo Charge or run games for a period of time.
2. The 3000 amH battery runs out faster than my 3000 amH battery Sony Z Ultra, most likely due to the 2K screen.
3. Camera is decent with sufficient light but not very well under low light, quality is not bad but not as good as Sony or Samsung flagship phones (which you pay almost twice the price)
4. I didn't know this before but stock Android does not display battery % to you by default, you have to enable developer's mode and do some research to get it to display. (This is actually google's fault)
5. MTP data transfer.  This is my biggest complaint after the android 6.0 version update.  You CANNOT change the default USB connection type from just charging to anything else.  I think most people that connect their phone to PC will want MTP instead of power charge and an option to choose default connection type would be nice.  Again, this is more of google and not the phone's problem.
6. Not USB Type-C.  If you want the newest USB connector, you will have to go with Nexus or wait until 2016 new phones release.
I bought the phone for my and he really enjoys it. Thank you Amazon!

I bought this phone as a replacement for my T-Mobile LG G3. It offers the stock android experience, without any carrier bloat, and is unlocked for all GSM carriers and will work on Sprint and Verizon with the proper SIM cards.

I am very pleased with my purchase. I will echo all other reviews here regarding construction, design, practicality, speed, camera, etc.

However, there are some things you should take into account before making this purchase that have not been address on other reviews.

First is Motorola's (Lenovo) update policy.  As a general rule, Google and carriers commit themselves to offering 18-24 month software updates of their phones. Motorola commits itself to "at least 1 upgrade" in that period. This means that you shouldn't be surprised if this phone gets Android 6.0 Marshmallow and that's it. Related to this issue, LTE Band 12 for those that use T-Mobile is disabled and the Stagefright 2.0 bug fix has not been incorporated into this phone so you have to wait for a future update.

Second is battery life. It is possible to achieve around 4.5hrs of on-screen time with decent standby times with moderate use, but only if you disable a lot of apps, specially Moto Display, Moto Voice, etc. Because of their always on feature and this phone using an LCD over AMOLED display, the native Motorola apps drain about an extra 20% battery life compared to them being off.

Last is third party accesories support. Compared to other devices, this phone doesn't have a lot of options regarding cases and screen protectors. So, it might be a bit difficult to find the right accessory for you.

All in all, this phone is an excellent purchase for the money and, if seen as a top mid range device, will keep you satisfied for as long as you have it.

motorola and sprint should do a better job of registering the imei's on sprint's network.  also, motorola should detail which sim card the phone needs.

as for the for the phone, it's nice and not too big.  the number is trash.

Really awesome mobile.

This phone is a keeper.  I went the Amazon route to get the phone quicker.  This is my first white phone.  The bamboo back is quite nice but unfortunately is covered with the holster I bought.

Last night I could have gotten 6 hours of screen on time with this phone.  I had 5 hours and 30 minutes of screen time with 21% of my battery left when I went to bed.  I am not a gamer and not a heavy user.  My average day is some text messages, a few phone calls and checking some forums and news sites.  I always have plenty of juice before bedtime.

The QC 2.0 quick charge funcion is great.  You can easily top this phone off if you do run low.  A 10-15 minute charge will add a few hours of time to the phone.  I bought a TechMatte backup charger for a cruise we recently went on.  It did a great job of quick charging this phone.  I really like this feature.  Be prepared for the phone to run hot when you first use the quick charger.  The battery has to settle in for a few days to get good battery life.  Mine took 5-6 days then leveled out.  I only use the quick charger for quick charges.  I use a regular charger to slow charge my battery overnight.

This phone is unlocked and will run on all major carriers.  Motorola is testing for band 12 approval with T-Mobile so don't expect it to work initially.  New updates should fix this once it is approved.  I'm on Verizon, so I am not affected by this.

Are their better phones on the market?  Yes there are.  Are there better phones at this price point?  No there isn't.  For the price this phone is a great buy.

Many manufacturers are doing away with external sd card storage.  Not Motorola.  You can add up to a 128Gb micro sd card to store tons of music and videos.  This is a must since all the cell phone carriers are charging ludicrous amounts for data.  Save yourself some data money and store your own music.

Edit:  I left out the fact of the excellent reception you get with Motorola phones.  This was a big reason I went back to Motorola.  I live in a bad cell area but can always get a signal when people owning Samsung's cannot.  You cannot beat the reception on Motorola phones. :End Edit
It was wonderful for my son just plug and play. Life is easy with this phone.
Just a awesome all-around phone

Great phone. The size is perfect when I thought that it may be too large. The build quality is fantastic and feels premium. The bamboo is beautiful.  Sound quality with the front facing speakers is incredible and can go LOUD! A lot of people have concerns about the screen being LCD and not AMOLED. I really haven't noticed much of a difference. This phone is pure Android. Best phone I got in a long time. Way better then the Note 5. Battery is good enough.

Thought I'd offer a few insights amongst the glowing reviews.

Phone calls:

After using the phone for about 3 days, I have noticed that there is static in the ear speaker when on a phone call. The other person sounds loud and the call is clear apart from the light background static. Obviously, this is pretty annoying and really shouldn't be a problem with a $400 cell phone at this point. I will have to test further to see if the problem persists. However, I researched it and there have been reports of this happening so it's not just mine. The speakers however are good.

Screen:

The screen on this phone is YELLOW. It looks like everything has a stupid Instagram filter on it. (It doesn't get any better when changing the settings.) Yeah, it's that bad and definitely noticeable even without putting another phone next to it. I don't know if I can deal with that. Also, the minimum brightness of the screen is very bright which is harsh if you read on your phone before going to sleep. Even with an app like Lux which allows for negative screen brightness, it is still very bright and the on screen buttons stay brighter than the rest of it. It does work better for outside viewing however...better than the S4 or Oneplus One. On the subject of on screen buttons, the configuration from left to right is "back, home, recent apps". This really should be customizable.

Battery:

Battery life is pretty poor. The Quad HD display is crisp and easy to look at, but the viewing angles aren't great and it eats through the battery super fast. I'm hoping that Android Marshmallow will help with the battery life by allowing the ability to disable apps from running in the background. This has definitely helped with the Oneplus One battery life with CM privacy manager. Another thing to mention is that the phone gets very warm (116 degrees F) when performing simple tasks such as browsing news articles and checking email.

Charger:
The charger that Motorola provides does not come as a charging brick with a separate cable. So, if you want a longer cable, you have to use/buy another charger and cable. Using the provided charger when you want to use your phone at the same time is a pain anyway because the phone gets super hot and your hand will be sweating trying to use it.

Active display:

I find the wave hand over notification screen very annoying. Of course, due to ambient light changes or movements anywhere near the phone, the notification screen comes on. And if you have to pick your hand up and wave at your phone, you might as well pick up your phone. Not to mention that unless you're looking at the phone directly above it (assuming it's sitting on at table), it's extremely hard to see anything due to the phone having an LCD instead of AMOLED display. I would much prefer a notification LED.

Actions:

The double twist for the camera app and double chop for flashlight are beyond convenient and a real asset to the phone.

Speed:

The latest phone I have to measure against would be the Oneplus One. The Moto X Pure is only very slightly faster than the One and if measured purely on that, would not be worth the upgrade. The benefit of not ever having to deal with Oneplus again, IS worth the upgrade.

I will be testing the phone to see if some of the issues improve and if not, it will likely be going back.

Best Android phone I have owned to date. Very smooth, fast and the speakers sound good, but not quite the sound quality of the HTC One (M7, M8, or M9), but close enough to make me not miss mine. The speaker volume is about 50-75% louder and I actually find myself turning down my phone when listening to music or watching a video through the speakers. The included turbo charger is a great bonus for when you need to get a quick charge. If you're getting ready to leave for the night and your phone is at 50 or 60%, plug it in while you get ready and in 30 minutes it will be at 100%.

Waiting on another update may take months and I think Motorola and Google out to work better together on bringing best updates to the phone in more timely manner.

Fulfilled my expectations..

This phone is great.  I'm coming from a Note 4, so I'm going from a flagship to slightly less of a flagship, in terms of cost.  Having unlimited data on Verizon, I've got to buy phones full price.  The Note 4 cost me $750 after tax last year, while the Moto X cost me about $300 less!  I love the fact that I can finally buy a phone that's NOT from Verizon, and have peace of mind knowing that if I ever leave, I can bring the Moto X with me to any carrier.  It's amazing booting up a phone with absolutley NO Verizon software!  All I had to do was use a sim cutter on my micro sim from my Note 4 and pop it in the Moto X...it connected to the network immediately.

Only issue I had was I wasn't getting simultaneous voice and data.  Every time I made a call, LTE would drop.  So I looked into it, and found out that you have to have Verizon activate Advanced Calling (HD Voice) on the phone on their end.  Then, you have to go into the hidden phone menu by dialing *#*#4636#*#*, then go to "Phone Information," scroll down and toggle "Turn on VOLTE provisioned flag."  After you do this, reboot your phone, and now you've got simultaneous talk/data!

Other than that, the phone does tend to run a bit warm, but after seeing many reports of this phone running warm, it's just something with the processor/gpu I believe.  No, I don't have a faulty unit which is what everybody seems to run to the second you mention a warm phone...it's just how the phone is.  Both of my S3's ran warm, my S4 and my DNA.  Even my G2.  Even my Note 4 would run warm in certain circumstances, but the Note definitely runs cooler than this.  Who knows why, but it's not that bothersome.

The speakers sound great.  I love it.  Many people will complain of a "popping" noise after the notification sound plays, and then suggest you return the phone....DO NOT listen to these people.  The popping sound is the software/amplifier shutting off.  You will notice this on low end PC soundcards as well.  It's nothing you can do, it's not a hardware problem, and it MAY be able to be fixed with software updates, who knows.  But it's not something you should return the phone over, because every one does it..other phones do it, too.  We just never notice it because the speakers aren't on the front.

Battery life is going to be a bit meh on this phone.  My Note 4 gets some pretty awful battery life lately, and this Moto X will get me about the same it seems.  Nothing I can do about it until I root it and maybe install Greenify, but until then, the battery seems like it'll maybe get me my usual 15 or so hours off charger at 2 to 3 SOT.  We'll see.
What my son wanted for Christmas.  Totally happy with it.

T-Mobile apparently does NOT work with this phone!  It is unlocked, and is advertised that it should work on all networks. During the calls, there is a crackling sound.  Data (emails, photos, weather information, etc.)  cannot be retrieved unless connected to wi-fi!!! Notifications do not show up! I've been to the T-Mobile store 4 times x 2 hours for assistance and they cannot explain the difficulties with this phone!!

Fantastic device. Very quick, awesome screen and speakers, incredible camera. Stock Android is fantastic. The battery isn't phenomenal, but the phone charges very quickly to make up for it. All for an amazing price.

I am coming directly from using an LG G3, which I loved PRIOR to the Lollipop update but after that it was too buggy for me to want to deal with anymore.  First off, The Moto X Pure is a well built phone.  The buttons feel nice, the phone has a nice weight, and it doesn't feel overly huge.  I'm not a large guy (5'9, 180lbs.) and I have no issues using this phone with one hand.  The screen is EXCELLENT, especially compared to the G3.  The G3 matches the X's resolution, and since the G3 has a 5.5 inch screen compared to the X's 5.7, the G3 has slightly higher density.  Honestly though, comparing the 2 isn't even fair.  The X has much brighter colors that are prettier to look at without being overkill like most Samsung phones.  The G3 looks washed out next to the X.  For me, the SD card slot was the most important item I was looking for in my next phone, as a lot of manufacturers are going away from offering one.  That in my opinion is asinine.  I bought the 16gb X knowing that I was not limited to the internal memory.  I've only been using the phone for a few days, but I can say that battery life is to be expected.  It actually is going slightly better than my G3 was when I stopped using it.  Currently I've been unplugged for over 9 hours and I'm still at 66%.  Keep in mind I'm using it in a work environment at the moment so it has mostly been just pushing emails and the like, but I spent my lunch break playing with it.  Overall I am very pleased so far and will give updates in the future.  I'll list the pro's and con's below.

Pro's
-Screen is GREAT, best I've seen on a Motorola phone
-Battery life isn't bad so far.  If I can get through a day without stress I'm happy, because with my G3 that wasn't the case.  It charges real fast with a turbo charger anyway, and you can get 3rd party ones for 15 bucks on Amazon.  Look at the Anker model.
-The front speakers are LOUD and sound pretty awesome.  No more cupping my hand around the back of the phone.  (Sorry G3, no more reacharounds........)
-Build quality is nice and solid and the phone feels adequate but not cumbersome
-Stock Android is the way to go, and you won't get much more stock unless you get a Nexus.  Plus, the Moto apps aren't too bad.
-A clear plastic bumper comes with it.  You may not want to use it long term, but it's a nice addition until you decide if/what case you want.
-I don't know if it's just luck or what, but it seems to me that this phone is getting better WiFi and cell reception than I'm used to getting.  At work I have a cheap WiFi router that has a really short range, but it appears to be stronger using this phone.

Cons
-I like the texture on the back, but since it's rubber-ish/silicon-ish, it likes to pick up fingerprints.  If you don't wipe it down regularly it appears greasy.
-It would have been nice to see USB-C on this phone considering it has the turbo charging, but then again I'd have to buy more cables.  I guess I'm grasping at straws......
-It wasn't free?

-Build quality feels nice and solid
excelent price quality phone

awesome phone! super fast, bright screen, awesome camera.

Love the Turbo Charge, that charges the phone from 0%-100% in just 1 hour. The best thing is that the phone is also compatible with normal micro USB chargers as well. What I disliked: I don't like the fact that the Airplane Mode option does not pop up on long pressing power button but instead comes in the pull down menu. I owned a Moto-X (Gen1) previously so switching from that habit is not easy.

Overall I feel it's a great phone, fair price! (Would rate between 4.5 - 5)

$400 and you own a high end phone. Its no amoled display, but hey, you dont have to worry about burn-ins. However, the viewing angles are terrible. VERY BAD. Youll have to look directly at the phone for best viewing or turn off adaptive brightness and max the brightness if you want a better viewing angle . I came from the first gen moto x w/ a 720p amloed screen and you definitely get better saturation and supurb viewing angles. You can barely see moto display if its laying down on a table and view it from an angle in a bright room. However, this is quite an upgrade to a 1440p res screen. Its beautiful and I even have the color display set to normal instead of vibrant because I like my colors accurate. I got used to it, its fine.  Stereo speakers are very loud and clear. However some sound causes popping and the start and end of it. Ringtones and short sound effects will make the poping sound. Its weird.

  Camera is fantastic. Don't knock the camera because it cant shoot well in low light. All cameras have a challenge for low light. Thats why we have cameras with bigger sensors like DSLR and more expensive mirrorless cameras with lenses with a F1.8 or lower aperture to capture dark scenes. Shoot during the day or turn the flash on. Find the light to put your subject in the frame. Go buy a $3000 Sony A7R II mirrorless camera if you want to shoot in low light and pitch black. If theres plenty of light, your shots will rival that of more expensive cameras. One thing I wish motorola would do is give us more manual control over the camera. I dont like the fact that you can not do 1080p60 recording. Why not give us that option? The processor is more than capable since the LG G4 can do it. 4k recording is very cool! I never thought i'd ever have a phone to shoot 4k video for a little over $400. Anyway, Motorola, please give us more advanced options for the camera app. Keep the simple stuff, but have the advanced options available for us photographers as well. Im gonna emphasize this again..Please give us a 1080p60 frames per second video recording option. More information, more smooth, much better for capturing action shots and its just overall pleasing to look at. More camera options!

Youtube app no 720p60 no 1080p60 options? What? Huh? I dont know if thats an issue with a phone or YouTube, but I hope this gets addressed soon. Should've been no issues for that.. ( UPDATE: As of 10/23/2015 YouTube now supports 60fps for the phone.)

You can customize this phone on Motomaker to make it the phone you want. How cool is that? I love the bamboo back and white front. Thats unique and you can only get that from Motorola.

Im not complaining about battery life. Im always near a plug to use the included turbo charger, which is crazy fast. I'll have full charge within an hour. Nobody should complain about battery life. Nowadays you should have a 2.0 QC battery pack to take with you if you know you;re gunna be out an about, a  2.0 quick charger for the car. No excuses on why your battery should be dead by the end of the night. They're realatively cheap on amazon and go on sale all the time. Dont want to hassle with all that? Aukey Quick Charge 2.0 10400mAh Portable External Battery didnt work at first, but now it does. Make sure you research on 3rd party external batteries that'll work with this phone.

  Expandable storage! I got a 64gig samsung sd card for $20 on Amazon and my 16gig model is now a beast for storage. Why in the world would you even get a 32+gig model? Marshmallow is comming and when it does, you can put everything on a SD card and itll work just the same.

  This phone is bang for your buck. It up there with the big boys. 5.7"  crystal clear display. 6-core processor 808 Snapdragon 808( phone does get a little warm!). Media heaven. Just work on the camera app more and you're golden, Motorola. Maybe next time give us an option in motomaker for a AMOLED screen. ram configurations, cpu, screen size. Thats the future, I think. Customize the phone not from the outside, but the inside as well.

Simply the best phone out there in terms of performance, functionality and value. The battery lasts forever and charges very fast with the turbo charger. No bloatware apps besides Google which are easy to remove or block. The best part is it works on every network, great for those who travel a lot.

This phone is DYNAMITE!!  Does everything I need it to do.  Very snappy.  Performs great.  Just a smooth solid piece of engineering. Although I am a little peeved that the phone is now available for a $100 less than what I paid not too long ago.
Excellent phone, smooth experience till date. Camera is a huge improvement from earlier versions.

This phone puts checkmarks next to all the features of a high-end phone.  It's heavy and bulky.  At three months of use, I'm very worried about how rapidly this phone is wearing out.

It has all the LTE bands you need for multiple carriers and traveling.  While the phone is fast, there seems to be a bug in the CPU speed governor that makes it lag and stutter constantly during interaction.  No applications scroll or animate smoothly.  From the factory, the phone is loaded with all the Google shovelware and a few minimal standard Android apps.  Google Launcher and Music are awful apps that you'll need to replace.  Most of the other Google apps need to be disabled to reduce battery drain.  The screen is bright and clear but incredibly fragile.  It's curved glass doesn't fit protectors and a mere 24 inch drop onto dirt cracked the curved corner off my screen.  The rubber back starts looks worn quickly - your fingernail or a comb can cut it.  The cameras are excellent as long as there's bright light.  Photos are blotchy in moderate light and completely black in low light.  The front-facing stereo speakers are strong and clear.  While this phone does have a notification LED, Moto won't let you use it.  You must use "Moto Display" which flashes the screen when there's a notification or nearby motion.  Overall, Moto Display has been a buggy hassle of flashing in the car,  not flashing when there's a notification, or killing the battery because the screen gets stuck on.  Battery life is 24 to 48 hours with light use and Google Apps disabled.  Heavy use leaves you with a dead battery by the end of the day, which may also result in you reaching the 300 charge lifespan of a LiPo battery in just one year.

Moto's warranty leaves much to be desired.  Screen cracks are $125 even if they seem to be from a manufacturing defect.  Having a replacement during the long mail-in service process costs $25 extra.  Many have reported Moto illegally refusing warranty services on rooted phones with unrelated manufacturing defects (usually a stuck volume rocker).  The back cover and battery is glued in.

I'm totally delighted with my decision to purchase the Moto X Pure Edition.  The phone has performed flawlessly so far and I've had none of the issues (although rare) I had with my Droid Ultra.  I believe the price/performance cannot be beat.

I'm concerned because the screen has a bright spot near the top of the screen since it arrived.  Right now it is shooting but I am concerned that it might grow.  Considering returning it but I don't want to be without a phone.

Great phone. Way too many things to list that I like. So, I'll cover what I dont like since that list is much smaller. :)

Everything is great except takes a NANO sim card. My sprint phone has a bigger sim card which won't fit. Sprint gave me the run around. I switched to Verizon and shipped correct size card. Had to pay sprint a bundle for cancelling on them early.

all ok

Realized I haven't left a review for this beauty. Well, 5 stars!! The display is beautiful, quad HD goodness with accurate colors at that. Another thing is the wonderful screen to body ratio on this phone, the side bezels are very thin (and the top/bottom ones are also relatively thin) making this 5.7 inch monster way smaller than what I was expecting when I took it out of the box (Good job Motorola).

The software was one of the main reasons I got this phone, near stock is beautiful performance wise. With 3 GB of RAM this phone does not lag in what ever situation I find myself using it. Plus updates will hopefully come fairly quickly. I replaced the default Google now launcher (which is by no means bad) with Action launcher so I could have a nice uniform icon pack. Also,the included moto features are very helpful, I use the motion gestures quite a bit especially to get into the camera and turn on the flash light. Attentive display is also a nice moto assist feature that helps me manage my notifications.

The overall build quality is nice, the back is not slippery (and I absolutely love the feel) and the contour helps with balancing this baby in your palms. I was initially worried when I saw 11.1mm thickness (and actually screamed lol) but I decided to trust the description that it was contoured and true to their claims it really has a wonderfully natural overall grip. I use no case and no screen protector (that's just how I use my phones although I am extremely careful with them) so the included bumper just sits in the cupboard. The bumper itself is a bit flimsy and hard to put on but I tried it a couple of times and it did just fine.

The cameras are above average especially in decent lighting conditions. The rear camera takes beautiful pictures and records surprisingly stabilized videos too. I don't take pictures too often so they both serve me well. The front flash works well too, it doesn't turn the entire picture white nor does it blind you when you use it at night. The 5 MP pics from it are also wonderful ESPECIALLY IN DAYLIGHT. They come out crisp with a lot of details.

The battery is average I guess, it lasts for about a day with average use but the best part has to be the quick charging. Boy, the first time I thought the phone was just playing with me when it said 20 mins left to full charge when I put it on the charger (at 65% or so) haha. It's just superb, it completely makes anyone ignore the average battery life, in less than an our, I usually always have a full battery.

For $399, this is about the best you can get.
I love this phone. It works great and is super-fast.
the phone is the best, fast good performance, excellent!

Bought this phone for the speakerphone and sound quality. For that it worked well - except for one bug that completely makes it useless.

When you're on a call, and the screen turns off, something goes bad and the call often (not all the time but regularly) goes jumbled and wonky. I've had two of these now (returned the first one) and they both have the same problem on a regular bases. Screen on it's fine - screen off and the call gets jumbled and garbled (on my end, apparently not on the other end). It makes it go from an excellent phone and speakerphone to a terrible one.

Do not recommend unless they fix this.

The Moto X comes with grippy silicone rubber back that feels great, aluminum frame that looks beautiful in a clear case, and a gorgeous 1440p screen.  Speakers are loud and accurate (not as great as BoomSound in the HTC One, but still very impressive).  The Moto features, and front-facing flash are also great bonus features.  Bought it as a gift for my mom and she loves it!
Amazing phone. Snappy processor and plenty of RAM for day to day use. The 5.7" QHD screen is gorgeous. Very difficult to find a flagship level phone with a SD card slot these days.

Wifi antenna was so weak out of the box that it could not maintain a connection. I bought this phone because the wifi had gotten so bad on the Moto x 1st gen I had. Voice assistant would respond to songs, and would not turn off when the settings were set to 'off'. Plan to return to seller.
