Great phone! Had it on at&t and now Verizon through straight talk. Don't let them tell you its not compatible... It is! Screen size is great and the gestures for the camera and flashlight are great. Already rooted with a custom rom :)

So far, I love it. I had a Samsung Galaxy S4 before. It's really nice to have a phone without all the junk pre-loaded Verizon apps. Verizon activation at the store went great. Walked in, told them I needed to activate it and needed a nano sim. Nano sim in, the guy scanned the box and the sim, waited a couple of minutes, and it was up and running.

When I bought it just before the Android marshmallow update the system worked fine. Not the fastest device but worked fine. Now with Android 6.0 there are a bunch of issues, one big one is I can no longer receive images from any one other than from email. Web searches are incredibly slow ( chrome browser and my WiFi is over 100megabytes) I don't have many apps installed and have changed very few settings. I even did a complete factory reset and started over and same issues. I won't buy a Motorola again.

I used to be an Apple iPhone evangelist, until i decided to give Android a try in 2013 (mostly due to the many red tapes and hassles that Apple used to enforce and the continuous jailbreaks to get the features I needed on my smartphone).

I went Moto-Maker on this (Ebony Wood - 64GB - white front and gold frame) although my 1st choice was natural leather - I just didn't like this year's natural option (especially with white front).  It came out looking awesome! I am pretty happy with the build quality from Motorola.

The screen is pretty bright and vibrant enough, although i am not such a big fan of the whole backlight lighting up with the Moto Display (pretty annoying in the dark).  The camera is pretty decent in medium-low light settings and awesome in the natural daylight (probably one of the best).  The 4K recording is great feature too - especially with an external SD card capability.

Performance is also pretty great.  I haven't noticed any lag so far.  All transitions are pretty smooth. I am a pretty heavy user (2-3 hours of screen time every day).  The phone lasts the entire day, although i am yet to travel with this so I will reserve the final words once I have traveled with this.  The 25W charger was a huge surprise - although i am pretty disappointed that i could not find one anywhere else as the performance is pretty phenomenal - my phone goes from <10% to 100% in ~60 minutes.

The software additions are the best features of Motorola phone in the last 2-3 years and i really cannot imagine Android with bloatwares - whether from Carrier or OEMs. This is truly how Google envisioned Android and their reasons for continuing with the Nexus series.

Overall, I am super happy that I got this phone.  I'll try to add more bulk to this review later as I've used it for 2-3 months.
Just love it!
Great phone, SUPER FAST UPDATES!
This phone is so awesome
Unlocked smartphone moto is an average device we can just use it not more than a long span of time. Not reliable but yet useful.

Just bought this during Thanksgiving 2015, after comparing different models for four to five months (mainly vs. Google 6P, iPhone 6S Plus, and Samsung Galaxy 6 & Note). Was waiting for Motorola to provide a steep Thanksgiving discount, which did not happen unfortunately, though understandably, given the device was already a very good value for money at $450. Nevertheless, Amazon provided a $50 rebate for a limited time around Thanskgiving, which was enticing enough for me to make the purchase.

To be honest, I am **more than really glad** that I bought the Moto X Pure. It is really snappy with stock Android, has very good camera, features a beautiful and ergonomic design, and most importantly, I enjoy the very smart software that Motorola embeds in its phones, which makes using the Moto X Pure a very enjoyable experience (Note: I formerly owned two generations of Moto G and was already very impressed with Moto G, except for the camera). And, I am comparing this against my wife's iPhone 6S Plus, which we bought at the same time. IMHO, the strength of Moto X Pure vs. IPhone 6S Plus is not only in the price tag (which was roughly 50% of a full-price iPhone 6S Plus), but the very smart and human-centric software that makes using the device enjoyable. Moto X Pure also has better ergonomics than an iPhone 6S Plus, easier to hold due to the rounded back panel that fits better in one's palm.

In terms of the camera, which was *the feature that worried me the most before making the purchase and given Motorola's previous poor track record in its phone cameras, an iPhone 6S Plus's camera is still better than a Moto X Pure's camera, especially in low-light conditions. Nevertheless, in bright conditions they are comparable and you can't really tell the difference unless you are an amateur (which I am) or a professional photographer who are used to a DSLR or SLR. Anyway, if you are shooting in low light using a phone camera, using a flash is always a good idea unless it is not an option.

Overall, an EXCELLENT, BEAUTIFUL, and really SMART product! I hope Motorola keeps up with the outstanding work in making exceptional cell phones available to the masses (from Moto E, to Moto G, to Moto X)!

Amazing phone for the price! I also own a Moto G phone and it's clear that Motorola really knows how to deliver great value in their phones.

The good:
- Good value, hundreds cheaper than most carriers flagship phones, but at least 90% as good.
- Works with any USA carrier, just plug in the SIM card and go. I'm using it with Verizon, just took the sim card out of my old phone and plugged it in and everything worked.
- Memory can be expanded up to 128GB more by plugging in a micro SD card (but you can't move apps to SD; it's just used for storage by certain apps including music, camera, etc. unless you assign the SD card to internal storage, which I tried on my Moto G and wasn't happy with; some storage hungry apps wouldn't use the additional SD memory).
- 99.9% pure version of Android with only minor tweaks that are actually useful (Moto display for showing notifications, and Moto actions motions to launch camera, light flashlight, etc.)
- No carrier bloatware either. Unless you've used an iPhone, with most previous Android phones you've no doubt experienced being stuck with multiple useless carrier apps that you can't get rid of. There's none of that on the Moto X Pure - there are hardly even any Motorola apps; I think just Moto for the cool notification and actions, and Connect for dealing with Moto accessories. Compare this to Samsung phones which are stuffed full of useless duplicative apps.
- Since no carrier is involved and Android isn't heavily customized, it gets updates faster than most other Android phones.
- Super-fast charging if you use the included adapter or any Qualcomm Quickcharge 2.0 adapter.
- Two front-facing speakers give good sound - for a phone anyway!
- It looks nice and is well put together. If you order direct and use Moto Maker you can customize the colors and materials; I did that and got the phone in about a week even though it shipped from China.
- Good performance, haven't experienced any lag or hiccups or crashes.

The less good (but nothing about this phone is bad):
- It's a little on the large side; if most new phones are too big for you, you'll think the same about this one.
- Metal body is a bit slippery on the edges; you will want a case to reduce the risk of dropping and/or dinging it (keep that in mind if you're thinking of doing a custom order thru Moto Maker; the case will hide the custom back panel unless you get a clear case - but a clear case just looks tacky to me).
- Battery life is so-so... considering the phone's size, it's too bad they couldn't cram in a bigger one. But the fast charging makes up for this by a fair amount. If you change location settings to battery saving that will also help significantly, but you'll need to switch to high accuracy (GPS) mode when using maps etc. - and then you'll need to remember to switch it back when you're done.
- Screen isn't AMOLED like many high end phones, so you won't get the blackest blacks or best contrast, but it's fine - and you aren't paying flagship phone prices.

What can a review of a smartphone on Amazon possibly entail these days compared to the avalanche of tech journalists who opine on these things weeks before we can even try them out?

Anyhow, I bought this to use on Sprint to replace a recently burnt-out HTC M8.  Activating the phone, as others have cited, can be an bit of an issue unless you know exactly what you are doing.  For me, that meant asking Sprint for the SIM card to an HTC M9 (SIMGLW446C).  I had to do the activation in store because I am still on SERO Premium and it is not an easy process for unbranded phones.

The phone is quick, and I love the moto gestures.  Being able to turn on the camera instantly to capture something is priceless.  Moto voice is very useful in the car for playing songs on the fly via youtube, and I love that the phone is always listening.  The screen is big and beautiful, and the phone charges from empty in under 45 minutes with the included 25W charger.  Needless to say, I am hooked on the moto-branded features, and I cant imagine moving to a phone without them.  Reception works fine, and the AC wireless has no problem picking up a 600mbps linkup to my Netgear router.  The SD card support is a major boon, and I have pictures and recordings save to it automatically. Front facing speakers are very loud and wonderful for watching even in a crowded room, although they sound a bit biased to the tweeter side of the spectrum vs my previous boomsound speakers. The phone was ready to download marshmallow automatically when I booted it up.

Now to the phones issues; the battery does not last long for a 2015 vintage phone...I use the phone for my business, and phone calls/google calendar/gmail are my main apps.  At the gym, I use it to watch my slingbox over wifi or stream from netflix/crunchyroll.  The phone will last a solid day...but it will not last through the night.  On wifi, I get about 5 hours of streaming.  I hope this metric helps out some.  The phone will also occasionally get hot, and I have no clue what it is doing.  Typically it is after I use navi for a while.  This didnt happen with my M8, nor does it happen with my cheapo LG Volt on Ringplus.  I lose HD Voice to other sprint callers, and voicemail is a COMPLETE PAIN to setup, because visual voicemail only works for Sprint on Sprint-branded phones.  Even sideloading the APK didnt help.  Google voice handles those duties now, but it is not without its bugs (the web interface has random "an error has occurred" messages).  I dont count lack of a fingerprint reader as an issue, as I knew I was going to go without that.

Moto's telephone support is horrendus, and I recommend that you bypass their accidental protection for something like Mobile Rhino or SquareTrade.  The former is one of the few (Besides Asurion) which will cover for loss.

I have used this phone for around two months now.  All in all, it a great budget phablet.  It does take time to be used to such a big screen with my hand gestures (my palms are fat, so my the fleshy part under my thumb often touches something on the screen unintentionally).  If you can get at least a 32 gig for $300 or less, in May 2016, then I would consider this worthwhile versus its 2016 counterparts.

Coming from the Galaxy s5, I had some high standards on the cellphone I use.  The Moto X Pure seems to be fulfilling all those requirements.  Other than that it functions well and has a good camera and looks good I can't say much as I've only had it a few days, but so far I'm happy.

UPDATE:  This is a sweet phone.  It has great battery life so far and I love it.

The phone worked well until the first fall. The kind of fall (less than 3ft on soft carpet and with a good case) that, in my experience other phones can easily resist. The phone broke with a very thin, almost perfect line across the display (about 2in from the top). No problem, you can barely see the crack.... Wrong, phone was completely unusable as the bottom part (3/4s of the display) and where the menu controls are stopped working.
I have no way to demonstrate this, and there is a chance that I was incredibly unlucky with the fall, but something does not add up.

But forget about the broken display. You can say it was just me. Fine. But the real problem with this phone is the very high cost for replacing the display (for the many times people will truly drop it). It will cost you $199 to replace it with Motorola. Compared with $100 for the iPhone 6 at Apple. That is just too high, so please account for this in your calculations, when you decide this phone has a good price.

Going to see if I can tweak it. I like cooler colors. Oh I have no trouble typing on it with it laying on table which I thought I would.

I like the new Moto X overall.  It feels really sturdy and runs fast.  I have an LG G4 which is a phone that has largely the same hardware specs.  This phone feels much faster, which is a testament to how much a manufacturer skin done wrong can bog Android down.  The rubberized back feels wonderful.  I don't really want to put a case on this thing because of how nice it feels.  Battery life is not outstanding but acceptable. I can get through a day of medium to heavy use by the skin of my teeth.

There are two things I want to point out though that people should be aware of before they pull the trigger.  These are the two things I wished I knew before buying.

1) This is not an AMOLED display. Previous Moto X phones all had AMOLED displays.  This allowed Motorola's "Active display" notification feature to keep the majority of the screen off when notifications come through and pop up on the phone.  This is an LCD panel, so the entire display lights up for Active Display notifications.  It sort of ruins the experience for me and I'm not sure why Motorola made this decision.

2) There seems to be some kind of issue with the Moto X Pure's top speaker.  I'm not sure if it's all of the units or just a bad batch.  If you get one of the bad units, you will probably notice a lot of distortion coming from the top speaker when playing music/videos/podcasts at or near maximum volume. It is bad enough that I don't even want to listen to anything on my phone because it's just irritating.  There are posts on both XDA and Motorola's official forums discussing this problem.  Motorola doesn't seem sure if this is a hardware or software problem, but even Motorola's engineers notice this problem on their own devices.

Once this second problem is worked out, this will be a solid 4 or 4.5 phone.  Until then, I would be very hesitant to buy unless you're willing to gamble.  Good luck!  I will be keeping an eye on it and returning the phone if the issue isn't resolved by the end of my return eligibility window.

Update about the speaker issues:  I've had a chance to test FOUR Moto X Pure units and all four have a top speaker that clips where the bottom doesn't seem to nearly as often.  This problem is still present in the Marshmallow update, so I'm thinking more and more this is a widespread hardware problem.

So I love the Motorola X Pure Edition. Very nice specs, a pleasure to use, no bloatware, 64GB internal memory, usable on all carriers.

HOWEVER!

Motorola repair services leave much to be desired. I broke my screen at the end of December 2015. I used the Moto-Care Accident Protection\Advance Exchange program where you pay a fee to have them send you a replacement phone and then you send in your broken one. Had a replacement phone by the end of the next week, however it would not work with my AT&T sim card. Got a new sim card from AT&T just in case the old one was damaged. Spent a couple of hours in the AT&T store and on the phone with Motorola tech support. No joy.

Motorola tells me to send that phone back for a replacement.  This time I do not use the Advance Exchange program because I don't want to pay the extra money to rush the phone to me, as paying extra for the first defective replacement phone was superfluous. I get a second replacement phone a couple of weeks later, after I send the first replacement phone back. That phone will not work with my AT&T sim card either. Spend hours troubleshooting this phone with Motorola tech support inside the AT&T store. The sim card is not the problem, replaced it again, and the replacement sim card works in three other phones there.

I finally determine that the GSM radio is turned off! I don't know how a phone is supposed to be "All Carrier" if the GSM radio is turned off and cannot function on AT&T.

Anyway, Motorola tech support(Tier 3) tells me there is no way for me to turn the GSM radio back on, and I need to send this phone in for repairs and that "things have changed" in regards to the repair facility, and that this time they'll get it right.

So I send my SECOND replacement phone in; they receive the phone on 1 March 2016(RMA 160219-005532). On 22 March 2016 I call to find out what is going on because I haven't gotten a shipping notice and the status of the repair is "closed" on the repair tracker.  They cannot even find my phone in the system based on the RMA, other to say that it's resolved/closed.  In that case, then why hasn't it been shipped to me? I finally have to give them my IMEI/MEID Number, to find it properly in the system. I find out that they are out of stock (of the phone or possibly the parts or something) and hopefully, maybe they may be able to ship it me sometime next week. They generated a new RMA(160323-005176) in the system, and the phone that they already had at the repair facility since 1 March 2016 has "arrived" on 24 March 2016. Today is 31 March 2016, still no phone

Currently this phone is in Open status.  I have no idea when this will be repaired/replaced. After not having my ~$600 phone(with customization and Moto-Care; which I paid in full - it is not subsidized) for over 3 Months, I may not have the phone for a few more months, as I'm about leave for some Army training in three days.

Wonderful phone and perfect deal.  This phone is great looking and has an sd card slot to hold my 64 gb card.  Almost pure google that gives you greater control and faster updates.  Motorolla has many functions that assist with the use of the phone as well.  The most used for me are the camera function (twist phone twice), "hey moto x" hands free control, and flashlight function (chop twice).  Love the phone!!!

Everything about the pure is good or great. I have to knock it down to 4 stars for ditching amoled for quad HD IPS screen. Don't get me wrong it's one of the best IPS screens out there especially for that size but I have to say I think the 1080p amoled screen on the 2nd gen is way better. Just hard to go from amoled back to LCD. They probably could've kept amoled display if they didn't have to make the screen so big. They've gotten too carried away with size. I don't mind that this size exists just wish they made a smaller moto pure for those who like a one handed experience. Here's to hoping they do next year or beef up the specs on the Moto g.
I charge every other day now. I always loved the phone and now the battery rocks my face off.

For $375 this is a steal, I purchased the 16gb first and then a couple days later the 32gb was on sale. Go figure right; lucky for me this is Amazon so I immediately purchased this one and start the return on the 16gb. Amazon is great and the phone is great, no problem with Verizon and it seems to get better signal than any other Verizon phone we have. The spec's to me look better than Nexus 5x, I figured this would be a fair comparison due to price and all network capabilities. If you have been in the market for unlocked type phones on Verizon/Sprint this will not disappoint as you might know CDMA is not very compatible with most unlocked phones.
There is no overlay on the android system, but the moto stuff is pretty good, it has a little more than stock Android. If you like all the bells and whistles you can always download go launcher, adw launcher or one of the 3d types that will put the fancy overlay on there for ya. And many of the carrier apps can be downloaded from play store as well, I use Verizon message app so I just downloaded it and it runs just fine on this non branded phone..

Guess I got a good one because 8 have absolutely no issues whatsoever.. I've had it for 6 months and I love the phone.. I came from a galaxy s6 edge that I broke the screen and didn't want to fork out $300 for a new piece of glass to a great budget smartphone that is up to par with the previous phone. I'm rocking marshmallow now and living all the features.

The moto features are cool but forewarning it kills the battery life, I turned them off and can get close to a full day of full use before needing charging.. The turbocharging on this phone is also light-years ahead of the Samsung Galaxy quick charge.. Phone does heat up during the ordeal but literally 10 mins gives me 40%..  Don't be turned off by the crappy reviews this is a great phone and Amazon will take care of prime members if you have an issue..

Well, it works, sort of. Got really good reviews online but I don't understand how that happened.

Things I dislike:
There are no notification LEDs. How do I know when I have a message? I need to have my phone silent most of the time. A small flashing light would have been perfect. This VITAL function for me was never mentioned in any review I read. Seems standard on EVERY phone but this. Many people complain but idiots tell them "use Moto voice to read you your messages". Did I mention I had to be silent?

Moto Voice commands aren't working. It thinks my mic is in use. 24/7 since I got it. Right. Phone calls are fine, it's just the Moto apps. It worked for a few minutes but never let me set it up. Sitting in a silent room by myself, it kept saying my area was too noisy to set it up. What? It was quieter than a library!

Flashlight gesture? I had to download a flashlight app. Thanks for making it difficult.

Things I like:
I got 64gb onboard. That is useful. Also takes a sim card, which I hear other phones are getting rid of - which again - is not what I need. Not everyone can use the cloud. This is a business phone with sensitive data.

Got rid of a lot of bloat. Samsung kept shooting me TV messages despite the fact I don't even have cable. T-mobile would pester me non-stop. It's not there now. Of course, now I have other things to frustrate me.

In short, if I had to do it over again, I would not buy this phone.
Does the job for tmobile. Great features for price point. Does not have WiFi calling on tmobile. Does have band 12 support

I don't normally write reviews but I felt I needed to for this phone. In short: this device will do everything you want and more. Gorgeous screen, perfect cameras, all around amazing device. I highly recommend this to anyone who wants a big phone without the big phone from factor.
Problems with headphones same as in a previous model.

Super fast, great camera, amazing WiFi and phone reception. Love it except that Android and Google have too many similar options for contact management and I can't find contacts I've added half the time. That's an Android thing, not a problem with the phone per se, so I'm still giving the phone full credit.

So far it has been great. So much quicker and cleaner than my old HTC One X. The two drawbacks are exactly the same things you have all heard already. 1. This thing is HUGE. It definitely took some getting used to, but it is fine once you realize this is what phones look like now. Still fits comfortably in my jean pockets (non-skinny jeans, male) and I can do most everything on it with one hand still.

2. The camera does sub-par work in low light. I had read this and didnt really care, but it kind of sucks. The pictures in good light are AWESOME, so when you see what it takes in low light it really is a bummer.

Overall the phone is great, I just wanted to confirm that I noticed these two minor issues. I have no regrets on my purchase and I would recommend the phone to anyone who asked.

I love this phone. It's quick, durable, and the turbo charger that comes with it charges the phone insanely fast. The sound is better than the iPhone6 (tested it against my sister's phone), the screen is nice and large, and there's a lot of accessories available for it. It's a little pricey, but the quality is equivalent to the price on this one.

love the phone....beautiful in every way a device can be....arrived 2 days quicker than said...just wish amazon would sell with the damn nano sim of our choice....not near a major metro town so coming up with a proper nano sim is proving to be quite difficult....great sale though....thanks

Update:  3/1/16.  Do not get this phone if u have a Verizon pre-pay account....u cannot transfer service to this phone....I'm being forced to get a contract....was pointless getting an unlocked phone...just wanted to use prepay on a better phone than some Verizon /Walmart crap....well..guess I'll go to straight talk byop..see if that works....was sooo not the plan....Amazon needs to put that little fact about the prepay issue
Currently using the phone and I've been very happy with it. I'm anticipating even better battery life with the new update coming up.

Came to this phone from a Nexus 5. I am going on day 5 with my new baby. Absolutely love this phone. The turbo charging feature is outstanding. The included charger has the micro USB charging wire permanently connected, not sure why but not a huge deal.. The included clear bumper is a nice surprise, although drop protection does not seem assured with this particular bumper.. The bumper does however add a nice lip on both the front and rear so neither the screen or the rear of the phone rest on the surface when laying the phone down. No headphones in the box, that was a diss appointment, but not a huge deal.. Overall I am very pleased.. Nice large screen, android without bloatware, turbo charging, micro-usb slot, and although I am usually not a fan of manufacturer software addons I actually find the Moto features and software pretty useful.. On the downside, no notification lights..
excellent phone for the price! camera quality very good

Although this is not as fast as current flagships, its plenty fast for anyone who wants a smooth experience. A combination of lightweight and useful software tweaks, great build, and a top tier camera(with a lackluster camera app though) makes this a jack of all trades phone. I am so happy with this handset! Still, every day, all these months later, when I pick it up or pull it out of my pocket, i revel at how nice it is. It's fast, clean, light but durable... I haven't loved a handset this much since my G2 (but no freakin' bloatware!)
Excellent price. Unlocked. Works well with Verizon. Nice size. Adequate battery life. Latest Android Marshmallow.

Awesome phone. Only had it a week, but so far so good.
Google "10 things you must do with moto x" for some excellent tips to set up the phone.

Went from 1st edition to the 3rd gen a very noticeable improvement. The phone is substantially bigger which works well for me as I have big gorilla hands. Hardly press the wrong letter now when texting. I added 128 gig card for there is very little memory left with the 16 gig phone. The camera is very nice. I use it for my main picture taking now. The low light pictures are a hit or miss not sure why but seems that way in most peoples reviews of it. I can take one good picture then the next one a few seconds later is not very bright. I bought it for 299 and I think that is about right for the price. US Cellular had to put in their system as a Moto X gen 2 phone for some reason but it works great. The signal is almost as good as the 1st edition. My house is located in signal hell but I can still make calls with 1 to no bars. The speakers are great it makes a suitable streaming radio there is no FM with it. Call sound quality is superb and people can hear me better on speakerphone. Overall it is a nice phone I grabbed the 20 dollar extended warranty from the Motorola website for an extra year of repairs. The active display and shake to turn on camera and chop to turn on flashlight are great. I have used it in the pouring rain without worry that is a big win. The battery last me all day so I cannot complain. There are phones with more functions but for 300 bucks a water-resistant phone that takes great pictures and makes a great radio you cannot go wrong
very good smart phone
Amazing piece for a price.

It is a total bummer to give this phone 3 stars.  I was delighted to find the 1st Gen Moto X.  Motorola impressed me with the quality, price and unique features.  I loved the Moto X 2nd Gen a ton.  I've taken better quality pics than my iPhone friends. I want Motorola to succeed, so if turning their latest Moto X into a phablet was a good choice for the biz, I'm happy for them.  For me, this phone's improvements don't out weigh the negatives.  If you like a phablet, then this is perfect.  I love the better selfie camera, sd card, improved front camera and screen quality. The battery has not improved and is functioning on par with last years model.  The biggest negative for me personally is the size.  It is too big.  With the last model I could get away from needing a case, but with this one, it's so big trying to work with one hand, it will drop inevitably.  One of my favorite pieces of software from Motorola was the ability to SMS with Chrome.  I was disappointed to find out it is not available for this phone and the company has no plans to support it.

I've read some people had a few small issues after upgrading to android 6.0. When you get your phone don't put your SIM card in. Sign into wifi and v shoo ask the setup stuff. Once you're to the home screen go to setting and check fit the update. Do the update and after it's finished do a hard reset (Google how to do it). Once that finishes and restarts it'll take you through the normal setup stuff again.I did that and I have had zero issues that other people have had.

As far a the phone goes, I absolutely love it so far. The one thing I waa worried about the most was using it in one hand since I don't have that big of hands. To reach the very top is a bit of a stretch that I won't make unless I absolutely need to because it feels a little risky, but the rest is as easy as my galaxy s5 was. This is phone is leaps and bounds better than the galaxy s5.

I seriously can't believe this phone is $250 less than my last phone. The build quality is so much better. I suggest buying it from Motorola (sorry Amazon, still love you guys) since you can customize it a bunch of different ways. They send it really quick to. I ordered on a Saturday and they gave me an expected delivery date of the next Monday, but it showed up four days later.
A very good phone
Nice phone. So smooth. Original sealed package But it didn't come with headphones. So 4 star is fair enough. I'm still dissatisfied.
Great phone
Yes, it's a good smartphone that covers almost all necessities.

I was really enjoying using this phone until the microphone quit working after 3 weeks. The problem is that Motorola or Lenovo or whoever is running the show has the lousiest customer service. I have now been waiting more than 2 weeks for a replacement phone even though I opted for the Advance Exchange Program where it is supposed to be shipped  in four days or less and was willing to pay $25 for the privilege. I was just told that they are out of stock on their so-called "flagship" phone and don't know when the replacements will come in. I could cry but I can't afford to throw $400 away so I have to wait with a phone that I can't make phone calls on. It's something to keep in mind if you are thinking of ordering this phone via the Internet as opposed to a brick and mortar store where you would be able to take it in and get a refund or exchange on a more immediate basis if something goes wrong.

Great phone.

Love it! It is the best unlocked phone I've ever owned.

Love it. Stock Android is mean on App privileges witch I like.  But the hardware stands out.  This phone also has a massive screen that I can use one handed.  For the Price, wife is getting one to replace her iPhone as well.

Wonderful phone. Very fast and battery lasts great. One thing that bothered me was that the Motorola logo where the dimple was off centered. That's just me but pickin small details. If you're thinking about getting this phone you won't be disappointed
Great phone

Had the phone for a while now, love it. It's super nice looking, very fast, great camera and 4k screen, and it's a 99% stock Android OS which is probably the best part. No bloatware like all the other devices, it's unlocked,  I monthly payment, and it's much cheaper than competitors! Motor display is nice, I was worried about the LCD vs AMOLED screen, but the LCD has proven to be very nice.

The reason for 4 stars is no face detection enabled on the camera, slight speaker rattle at full volume, minor/occasional WiFi connection issues, & no removeable battery. Please read more before deciding against this phone for those issues.

I am coming from several years of Samsung Galaxy - S2, Note 2, & S5. Samsung lost me when they took away the micro SD slot. Some see those as archaic, but to each his own. I find them extremely convenient & versatile. I ordered my Moto X Pure directly from Motorola, so I could customize - white/silver front, turquoise back, metallic red accent. That was a hard decision. I have not updated to Android 6.0 Marshmallow, b/c the Moto Driving mode is taken away or changed. Supposedly 6.0 Marshmallow has that feature built in, but Moto's Driving mode works so well, & I use it so often, I refuse to lose it. I literally never have to touch my phone while driving. I answer & make calls, listen & reply to texts, start Google Play Music & YouTube videos all with my voice. I'll have to read some more reviews of Marshmallow 6.0 running on Moto X Pure before updating.

Speed - Nothing to complain about here. I don't notice any delays. It never freezes on me as was happening with my Samsung Galaxy S5 on a regular basis.

Front Speakers - Love these. Just makes sense. Sound comes through good & clear. Some have complained about rattle, & I notice this slightly, but I turn all the volume controls down just a few clicks, it solves the issue, & it's loud enough. Very easy to use the speakerphone. I never have complaints of background from the person on the other end. I also don't have background noise issues on my end, which was the situation with my S5 (oh the problems with the S5).

Included Case - The clear bumper is perfect for me. I've read reviews of it being flimsy & breaking quickly, but that hasn't been my experience. I like that my phone is protected (it's not going to get any edge & corner wear from dropping) YET the customization can still be seen.

Camera - I love that the camera lens is inset somewhat, so it is less likely to get scratched when setting down somewhere. Overall it takes great pictures - typical point & shoot quality as other smartphones. I don't notice any major improvement or decrease in quality coming from any of my Samsung Galaxy phones EXCEPT the front camera. It gets skin tone right & lets in a good amount of light. I don't like that face detection is not an option on this camera. I know I can use another camera app, but I really prefer to use the stock app. I guess I just like to see those boxes around the faces, so I know for certain the faces are getting priority on focus & exposure. I have tested using another app that has face detection & compared it to the pictures taken with the stock Moto app, & the pictures come out the same, so I have to assume the stock camera app is getting it right. Also, there is an option to control focus & exposure, but that only allows me to set focus on one face, so if I have all 3 of my kids in a picture, that doesn't solve the problem. Again, I do think the Moto camera app is doing it's job, I'm just very picky about my pictures. I use a DSLR for pictures I really care about. I think the person who uses their phone as their main camera will be happy with these pictures.

Screen Durability - I ordered a Tempered Glass screen protector, but sadly before I got it put on, I had a few TINY, BARELY NOTICEABLE scratches. I'm confused as to how they got there, b/c I was putting my phone in dedicated spots in my car & purse. They can't be seen unless I'm trying very hard to find them, so it's really not a big deal.

Battery Life -  I really don't know what to say here, b/c I'm not sure what's considered good battery life. It works for me. I unplug it in the morning, and it makes it until the evening with battery left, & I plug it in through the night. I'm not a heavy user. I'm a stay-at-home mom, & I occasionally throughout the day make calls, text, check email, make entries into a Google Drive spreadsheet, look up a recipe, read an article, listen to Google Play Music in the car, etc, but I don't spend all day on my phone. The charger is super fast. I haven't timed it, but after plugging it in with low battery & coming back to my phone, I'm always in shock as how much it has charged. It uses Qualcomm Quick Charge 2.0 technology. Sadly, there is no removable battery. While I have never had to swap out a battery, I don't think phone makers should take this option away. If a phone is dropped in water, it will be more likely to save the phone if the battery can immediately be pulled.

Antenna/Reception - I always loved my Motorola Razr flip phone from years ago. It had the best call quality & reception. Same with this Moto X Pure. I get reception in a metal building at our church where I never did with any of my Samsung Galaxy phones. I always had to walk out to make a call or use data.

WiFi Connection - There is an occasional problem with reconnecting to saved WiFi connections. Instead of it connecting automatically, it will struggle a little, & I just have to go in & click connect. For me, it's not worth complaining about.

If there's something I didn't cover, please feel free to ask questions, & I'll answer what I have experience with.
So far so good ,great phone, great fun to use it!
Excellent smartphone for anyone looking for pure android on a budget, with amazing build quality to match.

Love my moto x pure. Especially the moto installed apps

Pros: beautiful screen, great reception ( i now get wifi and signals where I used to not get any and less drops. I used to have a nexus 5 and samsung s3.), beautiful screen, price, color accuracy, good camera.

1 star off because I get about 3.5 hr sot and sometimes chrome lags and not the best viewing angles

I purchased mine directly from Motorola just so that I can use Moto Maker. The inboard storage capacity I went with was the 16gb version, mainly because I already have a 64gb micro SD card.

This phone reminds me of my Droid Maxx to an extent. I still enjoy how twisting your wrist twice will automatically bring up the camera, which I like to use often. I am not a professional when it comes to taking pictures, but if I were to grade it I would give it a solid B. In decent well lighten places that quality of the pictures is nice.  In darker conditions, it is not that well when compared to the LG G4. The camera focuses faster than my Droid Maxx, which is a plus.

The phone handles multitasking very well, but we all knew this already since all new phones handle multitasking pretty good.

The LCD screen is something I am not in favor of, but so far during the day, I have no problem viewing apps on my phone (Assuming you do not have your screen brightness all the way down).

The Battery life works for me. I get about a day's worth on from it which is perfectly fine since the turbo charging is quite convenient. From 0-100% it takes about 1hr 15mins for that full charge. Though, I don't let my phone go down to 0, I usually start charging around 30%, so under an hour you will easily have a full 100% charge.

I have never had a phone with two front speakers. This is a plus for me, it is easier to hear videos or songs now without having to raise the volume all the way up.

I have noticed some people seeing the red sensor at night. This is slightly true. I actually do not notice it. The only way I see this red sensor is if I really look for the red dots (one at the top right of the phone and the other at the bottom left of the phone). If you don't see them, just keep focusing in that area and you will see them, but I do not see this as a problem as it is something that is not noticeable at all unless you are purposely looking for the sensors.

I did not have a micro SIM card, so I went to Verizon and they gave me one. It took me awhile to switch phones as this was my first time. So everything else we smoothly. I must note, where you insert the SIM card, it is a dual slot for a micro SIM card and micro SD card. That way you don't accidentally have to open it a second time like I did.

The phone feels nice in the hand, for some people it may be big, but for the most part, it should be fine. I like how the back of the phone has a nice rubbery feel (I did not go with any of the premium back that were being offered through Moto Maker) and I have a better grip on the phone, so I do not see myself needing a case for it. There is the possibility of cracking the screen, but since I have warranty under Motorola, it will be automatically replaced as long as I pay a $50 deductible.

As for the cons, I did not see anything that I disliked from the phone.

I do not see any drawbacks to this phone. You really cannot go wrong with $400. Though, I do find it silly if you compare a budget phone to a premium phone as they are pertaining to different audiences and their price tags are no where near to each other.

Even though I did get the invitation for the OnePlus 2, I am happy I went with the Moto X Pure (Style). I highly recommend this phone for anyone who is seeking for a new, but budget phone.
Oh, I'm so disappointed. The overall phone is ok, but it doesn't run smooth, nor has a good camera and even worse, it's too big. I think it's a much big price to be given to a so poor phone.
I love this phone! It's my first smart/android phone. My previous phone was a Motorola Renegade V950 flip phone.
Not good, but I guess that is the reason they sold it, I can say much about it

The stories are real, their customer support is a nightmare to deal with, and trust me, you WILL need to contact them when the phone inevitably crashes. This phone is a joke, this company is a joke. DON'T BOTHER.

The Moto X Pure died twice on me. First time, a week in, it would not turn on. After weeks of back and forth with Motorola's customer service (a grueling experience), they finally sent me a "refurbished" replacement. A month in, the display on the replacement device went all wonky. Lines appeared on half of the screen and a white cast would pop up randomly. I sent it to Motorola for repair, and after the requisite weeks of BS from their staff, they refused to honor the warranty claim, citing "internal physical abuse". However, the phone was in perfect physical condition, not a scratch on the screen. The display was messed up and they couldn’t explain how I could have caused it, but still kept going on about “internal physical abuse” when it was clearly a manufacturing defect. They were extremely rude and unhelpful, and after three levels of escalation, the conclusion was that whatever the repair guy says goes.  They would not even give me the option to pay for a repair. They sent me back the broken phone as "unrepairable".

So after spending 400 dollars on the phone, plus nearly 50 dollars on accessories (Incipio case, tempered glass screen protector, etc), and so many hours of pointless argument with Motorola’s version of customer support, all I’ve got is a paperweight. Expensive lesson to learn, but I’m coming from a Galaxy S3 that lasted three solid years (and I never needed to contact Samsung, ever, over those three years and the phone still works great today, cracked screen and all), and let me tell you, the Moto X Pure is not worth it. There are so many great phones out there, do not bother with this one. I got myself a Nexus 6P and couldn’t be happier.

Really nice phone. It's big but no more so than a 5.5". The display is really nice. The turbo charger is fast, so is the phone. The phone came with Marshmallow installed. There was one update to install. The call quality is really good. Hard to say how the battery life is. I've only had the phone for a day. Overnight with the phone on it only drained 2%. So that's good.

UPDATE: I had to change the rating. The phone has a great screen and camera. It's very smooth and fast. The problem is the battery. It's what makes this phone no good. With just light use the battery drains really quick. The trubo charger works fast but like I said the charge doesn't last. Read one email and the battery goes down 10%. A battery only has so many charges in it. For a $300+ price this phone isn't worth it. I'm sending the phone back today.

Everything about this phone is good except the size. While the size maybe comparable to other flagship models, I wish it were smaller. It also would have been nice if it had fingerprint ID.But it has all the other features of a flagship model for $200 less. Setup was a snap. The best feature is that it is pure Android and I will receive updates as they are rolled out. I have already upgraded to Marshmellow 6.0.

Although I am having buyers remorse it's only because I always want the latest and greatest. Which is the Nexues 5x or 6p maybe in a couple years when finger print and mobile pay are needed i'll upgrade.
The phone camera is really really good. Pretty much I have no complaints. The image quality is perfect and low light photos have natural colors.
Battery life last about a full 12 hours under moderate to heavy use. Quick charge is the saving grace for me. Transitioning through application are not the fastest but who really complains about a few milliseconds.
Great phone for the pricing point. if you need all the bell and whistle then this phone isn't for you. If you are somewhat a purest and would like a phone that doesn't have excess bloat wear with enough ram to tweek multi task and casually gaming I definitely recommend the Moto X pure.

I love the way it fits in my hand and I love the way it looked. I love it ease-of-use in particular the camera activating gesture there were only two problems with this phone which made it a dealbreaker. Callers frequently complained about my voice transmission being garbled in addition to that when I moved about and entered different Wi-Fi areas and saved them when I return to those areas I was always asked whether or not I wanted to join those areas again it didn't connect to them automatically although the information had been saved. I live in an area where the signal strength is frequently low that's what two years ago I purchased a phone dual antennas baby the phone was a Huawei Mate. Prior to that, I was having trouble both receiving and placing calls because the signal just dropped. At this point I have to make it very difficult decision and reluctantly I must return this very smart and beautiful phone.
I removed one star for Poor voice quality in one star for non-seamless wi-Fi integration.
I must say that the apps run superfast and without hesitation. the battery life it's only fair in comparison to my old phone but the turbo charger made up for it handsomely. The camera was superb. Press anywhere on the screen and you could take photos in rapid succession. If you stay within the same Wi-Fi area the Wi-Fi sometimes fades out annable actually if you want to rejoin. This is an in frequent annoyance we're as garbled phone call transmissions frequently Head callers asking me to repeat myself over and over and over again. I tried changing the phone call settings to 3G then 2G but there was no improvement and call Quality. I might add that in my area there is no 4G. For this reason I am again looking at the new Huawei Mate or Huawei Mediated with the dual antennae techology.

Rerun complete but it was the best toy ever. Lightning fast.  Just poor call quality and networking capabilities and I have not seen any other post about  call quality or networking so at this point I feel I may have just gotten a defective unit. I am strongly considering purchasing a note and giving it a try especially , Since I had no problems returning at , Since I had no problems returning it it call and do that all.

I so regret buying this phone as a replacement for my 5S. Like many, I was drawn to the attractive combination of specs, performance, and price. After 9 months of ownership, I've found that you get what you pay for (well, less actually). Issues to-date:

- An apparent manufacturing defect that's resulted in a 1cm (and growing) yellow discoloration in the top left corner of my screen
- Data connectivity issues with my provider (AT&T)
- GPS accuracy problems

All of this is on top of the truly awful camera and buggy Moto apps. I'd RMA the phone, but have been discouraged by horror stories of refurbished replacements that perform worse than the devices being returned. Please, don't make the same mistake I did -- avoid the Moto X Pure.

Let me preface this by saying that only 1.5 months ago, I really liked Motorola and loved my Moto X. Sadly, I cracked its screen, and even though I could fix it myself (I've done many phone repairs) I paid $130 to send it to Motorola for the original manufacturer parts and repair warranty. I figured I was paying for ease and covenience.

I was so wrong.

Almost two weeks passed without indication they had received my device. I called in a serious of support specialists before finally being forwarded to the escalation team, who took about 30 minutes to locate my phone, verify it had been received, and assue me that it would be sent back to me within 5 business days.

But that wasn't the end.

5 days later and no word from Motorola. I called again. Support informed me that, actually, they could not replace my Moto X. 'Replace' is the word they used. But wait - they are supposed to be repairing it, right? Wrong. Apparently they just send you a refurished edition of the same model. So they no longer had my original phone and could not even replace it with the same model.

The representative offered me an 'upgrade' to the Nexus 6, which I absolutely HATE. It was way too big for me (I am a woman with small hands) and they are apparently completely unable to provide a Moto X Pure, which is the closest thing to what I have now. Somehow, it's not in stock? How is MOTOROLA, the company who MAKES the Moto X Pure supposed to be 'out of stock'?

Anyway, they assured me the Nexus would ship in 5 business days. Here we are, 8 business days later, and STILL nothing. I called in at this point to demand a refund for all the inconvence, which I was informed they "do not owe me" because I agreed to receive a Nexus 6. Mind you, I agreed to a replacement for my LOST device - I did NOT agree that the replacement would be satisfactory compensation for all this grief and aggravation.

This has been absolutely, by FAR, the worst customer service experience I have ever suffered through. On top of everything described, each representative could barely speak English, was dismissive and rude with me, and clearly barely trained, just reading off a script. I cannot express how enough how disappointed I am given how much I enjoyed the original product.

At this point, I am only eager to receive my 'upgrade' to the Nexus 6 in order to promptly sell it, never buy anything Lenovo or Motorola again, and make it my life's mission to make sure everyone else knows how awful this company is, too.

In sum, stay away from Motorola; while they make a decent product, should anything go wrong, God forbid, they will not support you and determine instead to make your life miserable.

I really wanted to keep the Moto X Pure as a replacement for my Nexus 5.  The Moto X Pure definitely has an advantage over my Nexus 5 when comparing the speaker and display.  However, I use the slimport hdmi and wireless charging feature on my Nexus 5 nearly every day.  If the Moto X Pure included wireless charging and slimport hdmi...this would have been a total keeper!

I never thought that I would write a negative review about a company I've been so fond of for so long.
I've been a loyal Motorola customer for the past 15 years, but here's why this will be the last Motorola phone I will ever purchase:
I received my Moto X Pure Edition 32GB back in January. The phone was defective out of the box. It was overheating and could not connect over WiFi. I sent the phone to Moto Care in Fort Worth hoping to receive a replacement phone soon.
That was my first mistake. I should have sent it back to Amazon for a full refund.
The first warning sign that something is wrong at Moto Care: I received an email notifying me that my phone has arrived, along with an RMA tracking number - yet no information was available online. In fact, 5 weeks later, there is still no information online regarding my phone. The online RMA Status form simply doesn't work. Motorola's response? "Yes, we know." So, I've been calling Moto Care weekly hoping for some good news. Each time, a customer service representative reads off the same script, in broken English: "Sir, I am sorry to inform you that we are currently out of stock but we have moved you to the top of our priority list. We hope to have a new shipment arriving soon".
Me: "This is the fifth time I'm calling and each time, I was told exactly the same thing."
Moto Care: "Is there anything else I can do for you today, sir?"
I think to myself, wait, this can't be...I can order a new phone for $400 yet they don't have a phone in stock to replace my defective device?
Frustrated, I look deeper into the negative reviews here on Amazon - perhaps it's just me? Well, it isn't just me. Check the 1 & 2 star reviews and you'll quickly see that Motorola has a serious problem with their customer service/repair center that needs to be addressed.
Bottom line: Avoid the pain. I cannot recommend this phone.

I advise everyone to buy the phone directly through Motorola website.

Motorola offers additional protection for 15 mos or 24 mos. CA residents get 30 days to try and return if there are issues.

I think it is an okay phone. Only 2 points I really love are that you can use it on any carrier and no bloatware.

IT GETS HOT and that freaks me out. When a phone gets so hot it is very likely that it exceeds the SAR rating, which I have NOT found a SAR for the Motorola X Pure Edition 2015. ***NO CONSISTENT SAR RATING LISTED***

It is not easy getting a really protective cover that fits b/c of the back curve.
The leather, wood etc are a joke b/c you need to be able to grip your phone.
It is not a cheap phone so you lose your gimmicky back stuff when you get a quality protective cover.
Don't waste your money on the bkkc cover gimmicks & put that extra cash into a quality phone protector/ cover.
Get the standard plastic back cover in your fave color choice, which is sort of grippy and get it engraved if you are 100% certain this is your phone for additional security i.e. proof it is your phone if you leave it somewhere.

The camera is on par with phones in this price point in my opinion. Some are better some are worse but overall it is a wash because compare to Samsung Galaxy S6 and Apple s6. There are wins for each camera phone in different situations when we took the exact same pics. Plus if then you zoom and you will see they don't all look the same.

You really don't want a phone that runs this hot around kids so it is making me lean towards returning it, along with the fact I don't enjoy a large phone.
Excellent

This is why you buy android people.  Forget samsung, apple, LG, this is a great phone, reasonably priced (although technically still ridiculous but its the tech age and its business).  Fully unlocked on all carriers, great storage and a SD slot, free update to Marshmallow, phone is fast, great apps and voice control is handy.  I use the hand gesture stuff a lot more than I ever thought I would, very handy (pun intended @_@).  I can see this phone easily lasting five years or more depending on how often you like to update (which I do not).  Design is nice, size is perfect for the average hand and even those with larger hands.  The google suite is wonderful.  Just great stuff no matter where ya look with this phone, must have for sure.

I have bought Motorola Phones since the original droid x. I for whatever reason prefer the tweaks and OS setup they do over the other vendors. I also have found their support for their phones outstanding. I had a previous Moto X developers edition with issues and after some diagnostics they shipped me a new phone without any hassle. With this new Moto X Pure Edition phone I have never had any issues with battery life. I don't use my phone a ton at work and usually come home with 70-80% battery which is my biggest feature I look for in a phone. This is the first phone in probably 4-5 years that I have been able to get through a day without having the dreaded 15 or worse 5% battery warning at the end of the day. The other selling point on this phone was the turbo charger that comes with it. Within 20 minutes I can usually have 30-40% battery life back. Overall with each update (now on Marshmallow) this phone gets better and better. I have loaded it up with more apps than any previous phone I have owned and it still flys. Great phone! Completely expect to be using this still another year from now (already been using for 8 months)

I purchased this phone on 2/12/2016, and on 3/16/2016, just over a month after purchasing (so out of the return policy for Amazon) and just under 3 weeks of having it hooked up for service, the screen went out.  Half of the screen is static, making the phone unusable for anything except answering a phone call.  I contacted Motorola through their warranty department on 3/16 and was told the only thing they could do was to put me in their Advance Exchange program, and they would send me a "like-new" phone that I would have in my hands in 4-5 business days, then I would send them my broken phone in return.  It's been 7 days and I still have no phone.  After another 30 minute call today, 3/23 that escalated to a supervisor and their "Repair Escalation" team, they admitted they don't even have a phone to send me, and aren't sure when they will have one.  I expressed my frustration at being promised a phone in 4-5 days and now being told they never even had a phone, and have no idea when I will get one, and they said there's nothing they can do.  They will not send me a different phone, they will not send me a brand new phone, they can't tell me when I will actually receive a refurbished phone, and they won't reverse the charges on my credit card for their Advance Exchange program. I'm self-employed, with this being my main form of communication for my business.  I expressed this to them, and they said there's nothing they can do.

So here's the thing - for the 3 weeks this phone worked, it was great.  But it broke, and Motorola has a terrible warranty program and are extremely frustrating to work with.  Unless you're prepared to deal with a situation like this, don't buy this phone.

Don't waste your time and money,  please before buying  read  MOTOROLA'S CONSUMER AFFAIRS COMPLAINS  website,  I place an order at motorola.com of a x pure phone and they put my order on hold,  when I call them they told me that I don't live in the U. S.  and my order it's fraudulent, can't believe it, ahh but they charged my credit card,  they discriminate between customers,  why? I don't know, but certainly if you got a defective phone it's going to be a hell to get the repair or replace it with a new one as many complainers stated.

Update...
Because I like this phone once the price drop I got the white 32gb and was so happy with the phone,  great camera,  fast,  vivid screen, screen size,  but after 25 five days of using it started with screen backlight bleeding,  so disappointed,  at least the problem before the 30 days return window,  so I just returned it, I didn't accept the replacement for the bad quality,  so my one star continues and my recommendation is stay away of this phone.

What can I say, it's the quality I expect from Motorola, with the specs of a phone that costs much more.

This was replacing a Moto X 2014, in a way. I had dropped my 2nd gen Moto X and shattered the screen, and have been using a Galaxy S4 until I could get the Moto X fixed with my crazy busy work  hours. Obviously this phone is light years ahead of the S4, and I like it better than the Moto X 2nd Gen, if for nothing but the screen size.

I've wanted a bigger phone for a while, and this one covers that base in spades. It's still small enough to fit in the pockets of the jeans I wear, and I can carry it comfortably.

Battery life does leave something to be desired, but it does at least come with a quick charger, which helps when I'm at home. Considering I pretty much have chargers available wherever I go, I've never been too concerned about battery life on any phone. At any rate, if your looking for a great phone at a decent price, and can handle a larger phone, you won't be disappointed.

When I got my Note 3, I thought that it was the perfect phone, and I was mostly right.
The USB 3.0 I loved so much burnt out and all replacements failed, so time to get a new phone...

After 3 weeks of researching every phone on the planet, I finally narrowed it down to the top three, another unlocked Note 3, the Moto X, and the LG G5.
The LG G5 had similar specs, but cost $200 more.
The Note 3 is a great phone, but I can't afford to get burned by the 3.0 USB port failing again.
MotoX winner.

Pro's
Fairly large battery(unremovable), I really wished it was a little bigger to make it through a 16 hour day of moderate use without needing a recharge, it will do a 12 hour day though, and the turbo charger is pretty fast charging the phone, it seems to vary though, sometimes it's 25 minutes to full, other times it's around 40 on the same charger and wall outlet....

The screen is large enough to make me not miss my Note, and the LCD screen is brighter, I read the active matrix isn't as good so it fades out when not looking directly at the screen, but it is a minimal shading difference, and I like the LCD display better the the super amoled, except for the lack of stylus function.(see cons)

Memory is 64gig ROM, and 3 gig of Ram, backed by a 808 Snap Dragon processor that can run anything to date, and I never had it lag out yet.

Camera is great, dual flash rear, and front facing flash is nice to for low light selfies to see if you got a booger in your nose at the bar...

Cons
Pure Android is nice for a smooth operating system, but the apps for the camera are low rent when compared to Samsung, the phone call screen is poorly laid out with undescript buttons, and the screen doesn't know when to shut off sometimes and you end up hitting a mystery mute button that can't be undone.

I tried using a stylus to write my signature on a PDF file, but the stylus doesn't register on the screen, and the picture editor is very basic, these are software issues that can be remedied with 3rd party software, so I still give it 5 stars for being a high end phone with a mid range price tag.

The upsides:
1.  Material wise Motorola did a great job.  This phone has the fit and finish of any flagship and the display is absolutely beautiful.
2.  Audio quality from the speakers and headphone output are fantastic.
3.  The ability to use a micro SD card.

The downsides:
1.  Compared to the 2013 Nexus 5, this Moto X Pure 2015 has actual Geekbench 3 performance scores between 2750-2950.  The 2013 Nexus 5 is more consistent between 2600-2750.  Not much of a performance boost and at times I've noticed that this phone is "laggy" relative to the 2013 Nexus 5.
2.  It does get a bit warm in use, which isn't a big deal, but irritating.
3.  Phone call audio quality doesn't seem to be as good as expected since the speakers and headphone output are excellent.
4.  The camera, although scores high on DxO Mark, seems to have too much noise in low light and really suffers from not having image stabilization.  Also, don't use Motorola's camera app as it does not have geotagging.  Use Google's or some other camera app.
5.  Battery drains a bit too fast, but if you have a few phone calls and text messages, you can get through the work day.

Bottom line:
At this price point it would be worth looking at the Nexus 5X and perhaps the HTC One A9.  I would not upgrade to this phone if I had a 2013 Nexus 5 or Galaxy Note 4.

No bloatware! Excellent battery life. The moto automation software is awesome. Simple to setup and use. My old phone was Samsung Galaxy S4. I like the size of the S4 better but this is acceptable. My only concern with this phone is the size. Quick battery charge! Nano! All of this for a reasonable price. I can't imagine paying 600 to 800 for a phone.
Great device, unfortunately had two bad devices sent to me, lasted less than a week each, if still had one would have gave 5/5

This really is a great phone in almost every way but one: battery life. I've read a lot of mixed reviews about the battery life, but in my experience, it doesn't cut it. Perhaps my unit is somewhat faulty, but I have yet to go a day without having to charge it midday from less than 10%. It's 3:30 now, and I've only used it for a little calling and texting and some light browsing, the battery is at 20%. That was with the brightness at about half. I don't have a lot of experience with Android, but all the iPhones I owned would have been still above 60-70% by now.

It may just be the cost of having all of those beautiful pixels to light up, but if this is the sort of battery performance to expect from hi-res devices, I'll go back to 1080 and below screens that can actually last. Either way, this phone is going back. Maybe I'll try one of the new nexus phones. If the battery on that isn't an improvement, I guess it's back to an expensive apple device.

YMMV, and I hope it does. I do like Motorola devices, and wanted to love this!

QA is what Motorola lacks.
3 phones so far and all with unacceptable flaws.
Flaw 1 - dirt under screen and chips on the edge of the glass.

Flaw 2 - crooked speaker grill and hair under camera lens.

Flaw 3 - very noticeable backlight bleed on the whole right side of screen.

If number 4 comes with any problems, I will not be attempting a 5th.
Great screen clarity.  Turbo charger is a great feature.  I decided to go with Droid Turbo 2 as I drop things.  Little big for men's back pocket.
Liked this smartphone overall . Only thing that was disappointing was the Led light in phone from factory is not rooted to be a working part of phone . Otherwise good phone for the price . 😉

32 days after getting a moto x pure the phone went into a reboot loop that couldn't be stopped.  it must have restarted about 20 times in a row, not even getting the the main screen, just  the motorola boot screen.  I finally managed to get it to power off and then I did a factory reset through the bootloader, cleared the cache, etc..  this did not solve the problem.
so I spoke with motorola customer support and the issued a fedex call tag and it was returned.  they sent me an email saying when they got it a replacement would be shipped in 4 days.  unfortunately, it has been two weeks and no replacement.  looking at the forums this is a common issue with support.  I just spoke with support and they have no idea when they will get replacement phones in.

I had the Moto X (2014) prior to this and just could not successfully get it rooted (already had android 5.1). So, I bought this phone... Within a couple hours of getting it, I had the boot loader unlocked and it was rooted. Now I can tether my phone to my iPad at work (night shift). This phone also has better speakers (stereo), better cameras (front facing flash), bigger screen. It's just an altogether better phone than the basic Moto X. Love it and would buy it again!

Picked this up to replace my broken Galaxy S5 Active.
Pros:
Great feal make the phone seem smaller than it really is
The screen is very bright and crystal clear.
Close to AOSP (although that is becoming less of an advantage with Google's current direction)

Cons:
I don't care for the lack of dedicated haptic or physical buttons.
No notification light
The auto brightness is a bit touchy and can create a flickering sensation at times (but at least it is aways bright enough, which is much better the my previuos Samsungs)

Would be a string four star device, but the lack of notification lights is a real deal breaker for me.

My recommendation…  run away.

Please note these are just my initial thoughts and impressions since I have had the phone for only a couple of days!

OK, so this phone is Motorola’s flagship, but in the end, considering the current market, it’s a really really good midrange phone.

It does not feel nor looks totally premium, but it does not feel low end either. It has a good build quality and feels solid in my hands.

The OS runs smoothly and fast, nearly stock Android experience with few but powerful Motorola’s applications added.

The screen is no longer AMOLED, so Motorola’s Moto Display notification system is no longer “battery friendly” as all the screen lights up instead of only the required pixels. So if you came from a previous Moto X, you will notice that Moto Display’s black areas are not really black but faint grey. This is totally normal in LCD displays and is no issue, the screen actually looks really good without the grainy texture you can see in bright areas in AMOLEDs.

As to the camera, it really isn’t great as Motorola claims nor is it a huge disappointment as previous Moto Xs. It takes really good pictures in well lighten situations: sharp, correctly exposed, color balanced. But in low light situations it takes noticeably weak pictures, below premium phone cameras standards. On the other hand, Motorola’s camera application has a Night Mode that reduces the final size of the picture from 21 megapixels to 5 megapixels and works really well. Using this mode night pictures look sharp and low noise, with a grain that I actually like. Of course switching Night Mode on and off is far from ideal, but I think the decrease in the megapixel count in the final picture is an acceptable sacrifice for better low light pics as 5 megapixels seem about enough for everyday use.

Battery life is not great also, nor is bad. It’s actually close to Nexus 6 and you can go about 12 hours of intense use. Turbo charger is really fast, full charge in less than an hour, though it can really heat the phone up.

Finally, there is this thing with the infrared lights that I really dislike, to the point of thinking that maybe I have a defective unit. You see, Moto Display allows you to check notifications without even touching the phone by waving your hand over it. It’s a nice feature present in previous Moto Xs. It works with 3 infrared lights that reflect IR light on your hand for a sensor to detect your gesture and turn the screen on. We humans are not supposed to see infrared light, but in dark rooms when the screen is off I can actually see the three infrared lights on, which is really creepy. I found it so disturbing having those three red lights on in the night that I actually turn Moto Display off (which luckily turns off the infrared lights). Maybe someone else can check if in dark rooms with Moto Display on and the screen off they can see those infrared (not so infra) lights glowing?

Don’t get me wrong, I think for the money it is a really great phone and to have a slightly better phone you will have to expend much more money.

Hope this helps!

I like the phone a lot,  It can get a little warm at times,
my previous phone was a one plus 1  and the speed of this phone
is dramatically faster inside of apps.

While you may not get a fingerprint scanner the price and features of this smartphone are stellar.  Very quick and responsive. I have yet to notice any slowdown when multi-tasking.
