Love it!

Great phone. Hands down the best Android experience I've had with any phone. This thing can compete with any flagship and it can stand toe to toe with them. The moto apps are really useful without adding too much bloatware. I'm glad I made my purchase super happy with the phone
Tried to return my item on 11/23. Last date to ship was 11/23. No, longer eligible for shipping day of.

I had this phone for 2 months now and it's been great so far. The speakers are loud enough and I like the front facing speakers having switched from an LG Optimus G phone. The viewing angles are perfect with its Quad HD display. I can really tell the difference between my old 720p phone. It makes reading and watching videos much more enjoyable. Overall, it's a pretty good deal for only 400 dollars unlocked. Although it was pretty big at first, I quickly got used to it and the screen is just big enough to see everything that I need in detail. The battery is much better than my old phone that would use up a chunk of battery on moderate to somewhat heavy use and it would be at 30% before 4:00 (which was the time I got out of school) which I hated on there. The standby times are pretty great. I could just not charge it one night and still have enough to go through half the day the next day. I could normally go through an entire day from waking up at around 10-11 am with light to moderate use and still have 30% leftover before going to bed at around 2 am. On days of heavy use I could find myself at 15 or less but it can't be killed in a day, I figured. The only concern is that it consumes through battery very quickly if you're not careful, and I have to turn the brightness down nearly all the way in order to conserve battery and keep it from overheating (which it does overheat sometimes so keep it cool). The camera is pretty good. It takes pretty great high def photos but it's still not iPhone or Samsung quality. There are some times when the phone will hiccup and lag and sometimes pages will take a while to load or won't load at all so I'd have to refresh to try again. And, sometimes the web browser can crash if it gets to that point, but I think maybe at that point you'd need to just have a little bit of patience and wait, or close out any running apps in the background. But, there's been no stutter between opening apps and scrolling through articles.  But, overall, it's an excellent smartphone if you're trying to dive into the smartphone realm and don't have enough to buy iPhones or Samsungs at their unlocked prices. You can get the same high definition quality for more than half the price off contract. So, I think this aspect is pretty neat. It works with every carrier, and I have Cricket so it's bound to work for other small ones. Just pop in your SIM card and it's ready to run out of the box.

It's been so long since I last use phones from Moto, which was back in the ages of the Flip Phone time, this time I got my self a Moto X Pure 32GB/White/Silver/Bamboo back.

When I discovered that Moto X Pure was available for use with AT&T, I was so excited to get my hands on it, and I ended up returning my HTC A9, Nexus 5x and Nexus 6 phones.

This Moto X Pure is really a beauty to hold on your hands, I love the feeling of the solid build with good amount of weight and the phone it self functions really well in overall usage.

The camara is way better than the Nexus phones, and reaction time was way faster while taking each shots.

cons: it only can have 4 rows of icons, vs Nexus can have 5.

3 months after buying this phone, I sent it to Motorola repair in Ft Worth They told me they have no parts or replacement phones to send to me. Should have checked the forums before purchase. I am not alone. Buyer be aware.

Great phone so far. I wanted a bigger screen than my galaxy S5, I was looking at a note, but price wise this phone can't be beat and I like that I can go with any carrier. Love everything about the phone, except compared to my old phone the battery and camera seem to be a bit lacking. But the pros definitely outweigh the cons, you get a nice screen, fast phone, almost stock Android, all for around $400 (depending on what model you get). I'm also using it on Verizon no problem.
if you need to read this to know to buy it, you have phone uncertainty and fixable with a sure purchase for satisfaction just like Mik:)
My 19 yo son is in love with his new phone. He paid for it, and he's extremely happy with his purchase. He's extremely picky so that should say a lot!
Phone came with a faulty power button. Had to return it, but there was no stock available

This has been my favorite phone so far. (Black 32 GB).  So far I've had every iOS except the big 6. Also have androids: LG, ASUS, Samsungs, HTC's, Used both AMOLED and LCD. Thought it might be too big for me but has turned out just perfect after a week of getting used to it. Carry in front shirt pocket or front pants pocket. 5'10" guy. It's an amazing price point and love that Motorola bypasses the carriers and makes a universal device. Currently using the Verizon network via an MVNO with no problem. Just switched the SIM card after cutting it down to nano size. I find the battery life to be excellent.

Update to Marshmallow 6.0 causes some minor glitches in the Motorola add-on bits - specifically "Moto Voice activation" in conjunction with "Google Commands ON" when the phone is locked doesn't behave. Also, the Android trusted places is glitchy as it was reported on a lot of 6.0 Nexus phones and got fixed with 6.0.1. I hope that 6.0.1 comes out soon for this phone. Prefer the Google camera to stock. Marshmallow doze mode gets me very good battery life - much better than my Samsung. I love the screen. All those software problems can be fixed with Tasker. Otherwise the phone has been rock stable unlike my Zen. A stable tool with all the features working when I need them is very important to me.

I particularly like the fact that Motorola hasn't gone USB-C and has kept the SIM. A touch of extra thickness so you can have multiple standard charge cords available everywhere is worth it. They also don't break all the time like Apple lighting cords. Don't really miss finger print scanner or QI charging. I like "OK Google" better than Siri.

Like it enough that I would probably buy it at twice the price if I break this one.

awesome phone.

i started out with a moto g on verizon prepaid,  that was my first smart phone,  i waited till you could get a smart phone plan for a descent price before i finally got one..  it was a very nice phone for around 100 bucks. but not much storage and the verizon version was full of bloat wear.  i could only add a few apps and a couple of games and the memory was full.  any games that were large like asphalt 8  i was not able to play since i did not have enough storage.  the phone was not super snappy or super powerfull but it was great for the money..

next i recently bought a htc 526  since it has a SD cars slot.  but when you moved a app to the sd card it said it was moved but it was still taking up the storage of the phone.  still could not play asphalt 8  since it was also full of bloat wear and most of the storage was taken up.  this phone was not snappy at all,  it lagged big time when trying to do anything.  took for ever to load apps.  all i can say is its a absolutely horrible poor excuse for a smart phone.  a few weeks later i decided to get a nice phone and picked up this moto x pure edition.

The moto X....  i got the 16 gig version,  now i see i could have got the 32 gig version for the same price.  well crap i screwed up but i am fine with the 16 gigs..  i have several games and apps installed, a few of them are pretty large and i still have about 2 gigs of space left,  i can store music and pics and what not on the SD card.  cant figure out how to move a app over to the SD card after it updated to android marshmallow.  before the update it had the option to move the apps,  now i cant find that option..  but hey  ill tell you what.  this phone is very snappy,  loads apps and games quickly,  plays games no problem.  this is what i would imagine a good phone should be like..  this thing just works the way it should.  seems just as good if not better than my friends latest and greatest i phones,  not sure how this holds up compared to the really high end android phones but i really cant imagine them being any better than this besides maybe having more storage.

my only real complaint is sound quality when listening with head phones.  the sound is very thin,  say the electric guitar on rock and roll music,  its kind of on the bright side,  not a nice warm sound like i am used to hearing, also when the volume gets past a certin point the sound starts to get a bit muddy and is not as clear..  i have a very nice set of head phones,  both my moto g and the HTC music sounded great when i was listening with these head phones but the moto x is dissapointing,  really it just needs a equalizer to add some low mids to warm up the sound and make it sound a bit more beefy. but i cant seem to find a EQ that will work with Pandora,  i mainly just stream music on Pandora.  as far as the built in speakers they are pretty impressive,  the sound great for tiny little phone speakers and the phone gets pretty darn loud too,  they also sound a bit muddy once you start to get the volume up there when listening to music but over all i guess i cant complain about the built in speakers..  these built in speakers sound better than some laptop speakers do i would say..  i guess ill have to put some music on my SD card and try to find a player that will allow me to EQ the sound.

the camera takes nice photos and videos.  i just wish the camera had some manual controols so you could set the ISO, aperture and shutter speed where you want them,  i am a photographer that shoots manual mode on my real cameras and it would be nice to be able to do the same here but hey its a phone and the camera is pretty good,  not bad in low light either,  much better than the camera on either of my old phones.

the screen looks great, videos and games and photos on this phone look very very good,  probably better than my HD TV looks,  ts a bit large but not too big IMO,  fits in my pockets just fine but if i bend forward for a hamstring stretch or something like that the phone digs into my hip but any other time i dont really notice it in my pocket,  if your working out or doing yoga or something it might be a issue,  for every day use just walking aorund, setting down and stuff like that its not a issue at all for me...  my friend has a phone with a 6 inch screen and that is just too big,  i would not want a screen any bigger than this.  preferably i like a 5.5 inch screen as far as fitting the thing in your pocket comfortably,  this screen looks a good deal bigger than a 5.5 inch screen but does not really feel bigger in my pocket.  now compard to a 5 inch or 5.2 inch screen those are much better as far as pocketability goes.  but its sure nice to have a screen this size when you are using the phone..

all i can say is this phone is great.  very glad i got this one.

I love this phone.  I've owned the 16gb model for about two months.  Great physical size, beautiful screen.  I have the bamboo back and supplied clear edge protector.  Fast, painless operation.  Really appreciate the pure Android experience that's not bogged down by bloatware.  Super fast charging.  Sound quality is great.  Surprised at how good music sounds on it.  Gets an ATT signal where my LG-G2 would not.  I live on the highest point of my city, surrounded by cell towers, and my LG-G2 had trouble selecting a tower and maintaining signal.  No more trouble.  Also gets a signal in far rural Wisconsin where my LG could not.  If I had it to do over again, I would order the 32gb model, as the operating system takes up quite a bit of memory.  I have about 3GB left, with quite a few large apps downloaded to it.  The saving grace is the ability to store photos and certain apps on a micro SD card.  Camera is great in most situations, but struggles in certain conditions.  Smart phones may never offer the photo quality people expect from a full sized camera.  That's why I own a DSLR.  Excellent value for the money.  (About 400.00 USD).  This phone performs far better than my LG-G2, and it cost about 300.00 USD less than the locked LG did on contract.  It has fallen out of my shirt pocket (edge protected), to the floor several times and continues to perform flawlessly.  Now it resides safely in my front pants pocket, where it fits nicely.  And best of all, it gives me the freedom of an unlocked, no contract phone.
Fantastic, great performance fits my lifestyle perfectly, thanks!

My previous phone is a Samsung Galaxy Note II. I skipped several generations as the Note2 did everything I needed. But over the past few months its performance was more and more sluggish, and I was never really happy with the camera. And obviously Samsung stopped releasing updates a long time ago, and even when they did support the Note2 the releases were many months late.

I chose the Moto X Pure as I liked the idea of a phone majoring on the majors, good screen, good camera, decent battery life, and sticking close to stock Android. As I looked into it further I liked the idea of an affordable unlocked phone that could work with any phone network. If and when Sprint goes toes up I can switch carriers without a lot of fuss.

After powering up I connected to my home WiFi and installed the latest Android OTA update. Very easy, took about an hour to finish. I popped the SIM card into the phone (opening the tray requires a tiny Motorola tool, essentially a tiny paperclip with a handle), logged into Sprint.com from a desktop computer, and activated the phone service very very easily.

The form factor is very similar to the the Note2, in both size and weight. I am perfectly fine with plastic - shiny metal or glass enclosures hold no appeal to me. The screen is noticeably more crisp especially within the OS. I'm still getting used to Marshmallow but I like it so far. The stock keyboard is superb. I enjoy the very subtle vibrate-on-key-press, a very superficial thing that nevertheless adds to the feeling of a premium phone.

I've only taken a few pictures but the camera is light-years beyond the old Note2 camera. I can't compare it to other recent phones but man, good pix.

I plan to update this review as OS updates are released. Thanks Motorola for filling a niche in the marketplace that was ideal for me.

I bought this phone when my Samsung Galaxy S4 screen cracked. I was tempted to buy another Galaxy but when Amazon dropped the price to $399 for the 32GB model I decided to pull the trigger.  The size is fine not too big. Just a little taller than my wife's Galaxy S6.  The specs were comparable with the Galaxy S7 but $300 cheaper.

My biggest fear with this phone was the size, but now I really don't mind it.  The phone is well designed to be held nicely in your hand (and my hands aren't huge).  Hold this baby up next to an iPhone 6+ and you'll see it is MUCH more pocketable.  Once you're over that here's what you're getting:

- Super fast, buttery smooth, pure Android experience (soon to be updated to Marshmallow)
- No processor overheating issues like the OnePlus2 or others that use the Snapdragon 810
- SD Card slot so space is never an issue
- Beautiful, and I mean BEAUTIFUL, screen
- Loud stereo front-facing speakers (seriously, once you experience these you'll never want to go back)
- All day battery (no more than that, but hey, that's why there's fast charging!)
- No carrier restrictions

...all for $400!
Overall pretty good phone. Switched from a GS4 and having natural Android is so nice.

This is a great phone if you're on a budget. It has a decent amount of space, a slim and stylish design and a very high quality screen. My main gripe lies in the camera. The camera on this phone is... how do I put this lightly... terrible. The camera tends to shoot in a greenish/yellow hue and has absolutely horrible night performance. This is one of those cases of "more pixels is not better." The camera is decent under good lighting conditions, but if you're at a concert, or anywhere where light is not perfect, do not expect to have good results. Overall I can't complain about the phone though. Calls are clear, and the stereo front facing speakers are a dream! Do yourself a favor and get yourself a Nexus 5 or 6 if you're looking for camera quality. I'm tempted to purchase a OnePlus Two to carry around just for photos and have this for my main device. It's great all around BESIDES the camera. If the camera does not matter to you, but you want an otherwise premium device that is high quality and budget friendly, look no further, this is the phone for you.

The moto X pure / style offers everything that I want in a phone with very few compromises.

1) Display - I'm probably in the minority on this but I actually prefer LCD to AMOLED and the X actually offers one of the better LCDs in terms of displaying natural colors. While not the standout display the the Galaxy s7 possesses, this is certainly nothing to sneeze at.

2) stereo speakers - They sound fantastic. On par with Boomsound or the Alcatel Idol 3 (probably a little bassier than the idol even at higher volumes). Very pleased.

3) Camera - amazing in sunlight. decent in lowlight. Definitely not a deal breaker and a nice upgrade from previous phones used recently (idol3 , m8 etc).

4) water resistance - always good to have that piece of mind.

5) Performance - This thing is buttery smooth. I've yet to experience any lag whatsoever. Runs marshmallow the way that it was intended. It's quick and probably stacks up with most high end phones out there. Stock Android is fantastic and the moto software only enhances the experience. The ability to text someone while sitting across the room from your phone is quite awesome.

6) screen size / hardware - Feels solid. Bamboo back looks / feels amazing. The metal around the edges also feels nice. 5.7 inches is a perfect screen size for me,

Overall the moto X at $300 to $400 truly makes me question why / how Samsung, Apple etc can charge upwards of $800 for their flagship devices. Yes their camera experience may be slightly better but I cannot think of anything else that would justify $400 more for an s7 (the snapdragpn 820 maybe?). Plus the X offers the ability to choose your carrier. Overall I'm very happy with the X and looking forward to hanging on to this device for some time.

----UPDATE----
After a month with this phone, my conclusions:
- Screen: 4/5, beautiful screen with good brightness and color. Clear text and images.
- Speed for business: 4/5, great for email, documents, social networks, browsing... No problems so far, everything seems to bee snappy.
- Speed for games: 3.5/5, I haven't tested it a lot on games but on the few I did, it did well.
- Sound: 4.5/5, beautiful sound through the speakers, with its stereo speakers music and voice sound crisp and clear with good balance of high and low tones.
- Battery: 4/5, it lasts a full day (from 7:30am to 10pm) with moderate use: some pictures (with and without flash), 1hr or 2hrs of social network and browsing, 30min of email, 2hrs of messaging and chat. It could be better but considering the big screen and network connections I think it does well. It charges fast, 10-15min of charging gives you 2 or 4 additional hours of life.
- Camera: 4/5, can't complain, it takes good images with the front camera and great ones with the back camera. It's fast with some good basic options.
- Feeling: 4.5/5, the device feels great in hands and it looks awesome, everybody has loved it. The only thing, it's a bit slippery on soft surfaces so be aware.
- Bumper case: 4/5, not sure how much it protects but it feels and it looks awesome on the phone. It would be great to be able to buy more of this but I can't find it.
- Call quality: 4.5/5, no problem, awesome reception for voice and data compared to my old Samsung Galaxy S4 i9500.

Coming from an HTC One M7 so comparisons will be made to it.

PRO:
- The speakers kick butt on the M7 as far as volume is concerned.  They can be turned up so loud they will overdrive if you're not careful.
- The quick peek notifications are great.  Phone knows when you take it out of your pocket and look at it, so I'm not constantly clicking the unlock button to see notifications.
- Turbo charging, WOW.  I'm not even remotely concerned about running down the battery on a days use, which I haven't done yet.  3 hours of straight screen on use, battery down to 60%.  Plug in charger, 12 min to 100%
- Smart lock is great.  I used to use llama for location based unlocking and it was a battery drainer.
- Moto Migrate was quick to use for contacts and messages, but I would not recommend it for images or music.
- Bamboo back give a lot better grip than I was expecting.

CONS:
- This is my first phone in the new larger size.  As some one with smaller hands I already miss the ability to type and hold with one hand.  This is however purely my choice in size and not necessarily a deficit to others.
- I didn't like that I couldn't use Moto Voice and "Ok, Google" side by side.  Seems it should be able to listen for more than one attention phrase.  I went back to "Ok, Google" because it seemed like 3/4 of the time Moto Voice just passed my question or command to "Ok, Google" anyway.

OBSERVATIONS:
I've heard people complain about it having a poor viewing angle because it is a TFT display.  I think it is no worse than the AMOLED on my old HTC.

The main drawback I am experiencing is that it is harder to hold with one hand and scroll with the thumb, and in the process of changing grip, I often inadvertently change something on the screen because the bezel is so thin that in order to hold on, my fingers overlap onto the screen. I am using it without a case of any kind, and I might add one just for this reason. The transition of all my data from the old phone to this one was very easy, very fast, and very accurate. If you plan to use this as a phone (i.e. to make/receive calls on a cellular network), please consider buying a different phone. I bought mine during the Xmas/New Year Amazon sale. Most phone features work as advertised, except the phone part! When I got the phone it's OK. Then it started to develop a cracking/sputtering noise every time I make/receive a call. The noise comes only when the other person talks. Apparently, this is a common issue and there are many people complaining about this on Motorola forums. But there are some people who do not have any problems. So, it seems like a hit or miss. The 4k display on this phone is very nice, and that's the trigger point for me to buy this. However, if you need a reliable device (i.e. a "phone") consider Galaxy S6 or equivalent. I have S6 through my employer, it just works flawlessly (at least so far). I have several other phone brands, and they all work well as a "phone", the basic functionality you need from a phone. I'm currently trying to get a replacement device from Motorola, but be aware that they charge $25 fee if you do not want to wait for few weeks to "send your phone back to Motorola, wait for the new one to arrive".

I've had the phone for a while now, and I think I'm ready to share my thoughts on this phone.

Let me start with the things I like about the phone.

1. OS: I appreciate how close Moto stays to stock Android. I use Nova Launcher to customize the look and feel.
2. Moto Apps: the few apps that Motorola ships with the phone enhance the phone's usability. I really like Moto Voice and gestures, although I don't think I'm using them to their fullest potential.
3. Updates: so far, security updates are rolling out in a timely fashion, and we've gotten Android Marshmallow.
4. SD card: it's nice to be able to extend the storage in the device, I have 64GB in mine and that is more than adequate.
5. Size: yes, it's large. But I'm coming from a Sony Z Ultra, so  anything with a screen under 5.5" is too small for me. I have no problem getting the phone in a back pocket (just make sure you remove it before sitting down).
6. Appearance: I love the bamboo/champagne/white color scheme of the phone. It doesn't get dirty easily and doesn't seem to have issues with scratches or the veneer coming off.
7. Performance: overall, the phone is snappy and seldom bogs down when having multiple apps open. Wifi is fast, as is my T-Mo LTE connection; I don't have problems with connecting or maintaining a connection.
8. Speakers: the front-facing speakers are loud and easy to hear.
9. NFC: this is important to me because I use NFC to connect to my BT headphones and for Android Pay.

The cons are few, but they keep me from loving the phone wholeheartedly:

1. Battery life: battery life is OK, but not stellar. On a typical day, I can make it about 10 hours, low to medium brightness, ~3.25-3.5 hrs SOT. I know that your can use the TurboPower charger, but that isn't always an option (think Disneyland). So, if you *need* great battery life and don't want to have to top off to get it, this may not be the phone for you.
2. Heat: my phone can get pretty warm, especially when the screen brightness is high. I notice it because the metal  Moto dimple on the back gets very warm, and that's where you put your finger. I've never had it force-shutdown from heat, but it is disconcerting when it heats up.
3. Camera software: I am not crazy about Moto's camera software.  I prefer a tap-to-focus, not a tap-to-take-picture interface. I find it awkward. I also find that the phone can hunt for focus, especially when you are trying to capture a moving subject, resulting in blurry pictures when you least want them. As annoying as it can be, the camera problems could be fixed via a software update, so this may not a be a problem in the future.

All in all, while there a few downsides, the phone as a whole is quite impressive. When you factor it's PRICE into the equation, it makes the phone even more attractive and a strong recommendation if you're looking for a combination of performance and value.

If you're thinking about a case, I've found that the Invisible Armor Xtreme Slim Clear TPU case is great if you want to have a very thin, clear case to show off your phone's back. If you prefer more protection for your phone, I like the Incipio Octane cases in Frost; they're translucent but not transparent and not terribly bulky.

My review is for the new 32GB White/Bamboo Moto X Pure Edition phone - I did not notice that the 16GB phone was selected when I wrote the review.

I have only had this phone for a couple days and will update my review later should my point of view change but so far I am very happy with the Moto X Pure Edition phone.  The LTE connection works well; the Wifi connection works extremely well and I was so happy to learn that I could surf the internet and check email, etc over WiFi rather than consuming data - a feature I have enjoyed with my old Nokia Lumia Windows phone.  I tested this by setting up my phone without a sim card and I had full functionality other than making calls.

I noticed in settings that the phone has Tethering capabilities too, although I have not tried this functionality.

Consumer Cellular is my carrier and I noticed that I am getting one extra bar in signal strength compared to what I was getting with my 4G Nokia Lumia phone on the same service.  Set up was super easy - I just transferred the sim from my old phone to the Pure Edition and did one reboot.  The phone installed the correct APN for Consumer Cellular automatically.  I did not need to call Consumer Cellular.

There is no FM Radio functionality so you will need to download an app from the Play Store if you like to listen to FM radio.

I took a couple of photos indoors of my dog today and while the indoor photos looked dark the camera has features that will allow you to adjust the brightness, sharpness and crop photos as well as some other camera features that I have not explored yet.  After applying the brightness and crop tools I was very happy with the results.

Battery life in standby mode has been excellent but it can decrease fairly rapidly with heavy use but no worse than the Samsung Galaxy that I tried before I bought the Pure Edition.  The TurboPower Charger is really appreciated as an inclusion with the phone.  As others have said it  really does charge the phone very rapidly which could be your savior if stuck at an airport due to flight delays but not having long access to a power plug.

The sound from the speakers and for conversations is excellent.  The screen is beautiful and details are sharp plus you have the option of changing wallpaper or using a photo as your wallpaper by simply touching the little dots that are located right above the apps icon.  This shrinks the page to reveal the wallpaper, widget and settings icons.  Motorola included some really nice wallpaper options including some that are animated.

As for the animations during start-up, I too could do without those.

So far I like everything about the phone with a few exceptions that do not impact my rating at this time.  Those exceptions are:
1)  Lack of an FM Radio feature
2)  Non-removable battery
3)  Those silly animations during start-up
4)  The fact that the internal storage shows about 8GB less Total Space than what I purchased which is a 32GB phone - I just find that odd.

I tend to keep my phones for a long time (usually about 4 years) before upgrading and I seriously doubt the battery will last that long.  If the battery does not last at least 3 years my rating will be different.  This is the first phone I have purchased that has a non-removable battery so we'll see how it goes.

I definitely would not pay any more for a phone that did not have a removable battery.  I paid $475 for my phone so if the battery lasts three years that means the phone is costing me slightly over $13 per month for three years of use (not counting service of course).  If I add Moto-Care accident protection/extended warranty that pushes the price up even higher.

As referenced above my only question is given that I purchased a 32GB phone why would the Total Space (NOT referring to Available Space, but Total Space) in Settings only show 24GB?  I am assuming the space used by the system is hidden, but the fact that the system does not show 32GB Total Space does cause me to question just how much space is really in the phone.  The Available Space is just under 20GB.
it is a good mobile, but not prefect. to me, the size is a litter big.  the camera is good enough. but i like moto x 1st more. :)
I love it. Super fast and beautiful. Excellent product. Great price fast shipping. Thank you.
I love this so far.... Great phone

I've tried so many different Android devices this year it's insane. From OPO to LG, I've covered every base. For the money, this phone not only feels sturdy and well-built, but it delivers a better Vanilla Android experience than the Nexus 5x...really.

The lag is non-existent, the display is beautiful, and it isn't as big as a phone like the Nexus 6 which will leave some people with Donald Trump to medium size hands cramping. I can't recommend this phone more. This is the 2015 killer.

Larger than I would have liked it to be but it was one of the only current phones with a slot for a SD card.  It works great and is as described.  I would give it 4 3/4 stars but amazon ratings don't allow for fractions.  Because of the size, it is not perfect.  Phone makers need to go back to making phones that can actually fit in your pocket for those of us that use their phone primarily as a phone.  I don't need a large screen or a super high tech camera.  However, I want the speed of the new processors so that I can use it for certain things for work.

It works... usually.  That's about the best I can say for it.
The power button is flimsy and clearly not designed to actually be used.  I have to restart the phone because its stopped working at least once every couple of days.  The battery life is atrocious.  I don't use apps, yet it basically lasts a day.  I'm at work for 8 hours and sleeping for 8 hours, so my phone sits unused on my nightstand for 16 hours a day and somehow it still runs out of battery.  My old basic smartphone would last at least 3 days before I needed to charge it.

I like this phone much better than my older one. It does get a bit warm (hot actually) in the beginning, but as the phone "ages", it seems to not run so hot. I guess the phone is learning??? Screen and camera are very nice. As with any phone or tablet, the speed and capability will degrade with more and more apps running, so don't blame the phone if you overload it. I will say that it does run much faster than my two year old phone, and I think the build is also better. I added a 64 gb memory card so there is a ton of storage available. I expect that to be all I need until I someday replace this phone (I don't do a lot of downloads onto the phone). Top of the line device!

This phone is amazing.  I have owned Samsung Galaxy Notes I have owned LG Gs I have owned iPhones,  and HTC in my lifetime. I have tried out all of the major brands that appeal to me. This was my first time that I owned a Motorola smartphone. Well this x pure has amazed me at every level. It is very well built.  It flies speedwise,  the screen is almost as good as aa flagship samsung,  but at half the price the difference between the two is really minimal. The weakest point of the phone is the camera,  in low lights it doesn't perform well but it is passable,  and the stock photo app is terrible. I changed it to another camera app and am content now. I got a 16gb model and purchased 128gb card and with Android 6.0 you can merge your card to your phone. So not I have 144gb of storage...  I can download as I wish and not worry about space. Grab this phone,  the construction is top of the lone the metal rim round the phone hives it a iPhone or htc feel,  very high end feel. I look forward to the 2016 version.

Quick review: The moto x pure is a great budget phone. Marshmallow is great on it, and the phone is very responsive. My only real complaint is that the battery life is very mediocre; however, if you are near a a charger, the quick charge can have you up and running again in a about 20 minutes. (typically takes a little over an hour for a full charge)

Best Android phone I have ever used. Have had many Android phones since the G1 (am a developer). Actually dumped my iPhone 6 Plus for this. Way lighter, better screen, and devoid of Apple bugs. Sucky battery life though. Good thing this has the quick charge feature. My iPhone easily lasts me a full work day. Now...I carry an extra battery
Quick and snappy, absolutely no laglag.  Quick charger is awesome. Micro SD slot clutch.  Works perfectly on cricket and project fi

If you haven't seen MKBHD's youtube review of this phone, I recommend you watch that, he hits the nail on the head. The display is very nice 1440p, though not as nice as the AMOLED screens that can make dark black. I like the design and centered usb port, headphone jack, camera and finger rest. The speakers are stereo and very loud for a phone. Though I have only used it for 3 days now, it is very fast and responsive. It comes with limited 3rd party software, which is a huge plus, and it can be easily disabled and opted out of. Many people will find the Motorola display and gesture software combined with the infrared front sensors on the phone useful to quickly check the time/notifications. I prefer my phone screen to stay off until I hit the unlock button, so with a bit of looking and tinkering I have disabled those settings. I haven't yet found the need to root the phone, which I normally do for speed reasons and the ability to seriously customize my phone.. With Nova Launcher and Custom Icon Packs, You can make your phone look very amazing. So far I am extremely satisfied with the phone, and hopefully it stays that way.
This phone had everything I wanted

So far, this phone has been fantastic. My former phone was a samsung galaxy s3. Buying this unlocked option made so much more sense than moving into another contract or getting stuck in a payment plan of an overly expensive flagship phone with no more options than what the Moto X Pure has.
Very satisfied with the product
I am having an extremely difficult time trying to activate this phone on Verizon, and as of yet have been unable to do so despite assurances in the specs and descriptions that it would work.
Not able to add custom sings as ringtones

This phone is OK. It's definitely not great though. Now that I've used it for a few months, I've found it to be slow. It has touch delay, like all android phones. The Motorola camera app is probably the worst camera app of all time, and it's pared with an incredibly underwhelming sub-par camera. There is no music player either, just Google Play Music which is awful. Hardware wise, this phone is great. No complaints other than it being fat, and heavy. It is very well put together, and durable. I have dropped this down a flight of stairs with no case, and there's only a very very small dent in a corner. Software wise, it could use a lot of work.

I regret buying this phone and would be much happier just saving up a bit more, and buying an iPhone.
It is simple, this Phone is amazing, buy it...

This is my 4th Motorola phone after buying the Moto G (1st Gen 3G), Moto X (Dev. Edition), Moto X (2014) and now the new Pure Edtion. I love it! Working with several techies I see all current phones in the hands of my colleagues and had the chance to check out the iPhone 6S Plus and Nexus 6P too before committing to the Pure Edition with an all-in attitude. I can afford any phone my heart desires, but the chance to buy this on Amazon for $349 sealed the deal - what an great price. I cannot comment enough how easy the phone is to use, how fast it is, how sophisticated it is, but the new camera takes great shots and the stabilization in the video is quite noticeable if you own a phone without that feature. The battery life is excellent and have yet to have it quit during my day, however the quick charger included makes fast charging a breeze - all I need is like 20 minutes and I'm good till well into the next day. The Moto X 2014 is still in my possession and is also amazing.

Most importantly to me, this phone has everything I could want, but the cellular radio is incredible and before this phone I would get dead spots in certain coverage areas, but now I get LTE where I could not before.

You can use this phone with numerous unlocked carriers such a Ptel, T-Mobile and many other mobile virtual network operators.

Sold by: Amazon.com LLC - Wish I could give this negative stars. Received in January and by May will not connect to cell network ("no service"). Sim card checks out in another phone, factory reset doesn't fix the problem, so I have a $400 brick on my hands. Btw, phone was very well protected by hybrid case and glass screen protector. Never had any other android go belly up like this trash. Now I have to go back and forth with Amazon and/or Motorola, oh joy! Speaking of which Moto's online lookup tool doesn't seem to recognize the phones IMEI so that should be a treat and Amazon says the refund period is over. Makes me wonder if this is a Chinese knockoff.

Great phone 128g card slot and the Android Marshmallow update give the phone alot of seamless storage. Bringing the music library and the Motorola quality speakers to a pocket in coat, pants, or shirt  is a great way to lose the headphones. Buy a qi charging coil and install it underneath the phone cover and now there is wireless charging. If you need more power on the go use the included turbo charger. That charger is fast. Chop twice for flashlight. Rock for camera. The camera is good not great. Great is a real camera, but this is the camera in my pocket. Size is big enough to read on even when the font size is increased. Except for the light Motorola skin this phone is pure Android.
Great phone at a great price.
Absolutely love the phone. It exceeded mu expectation.

Great reception, performs really fast and has a great camera (very capable at low-light, see picture attached taken at a relatively dim restaurant at night). Very light and easy to carry, despite the large screen.

Has an MicroSD Card slot, which is a great option to expand storage that Nexus devices (to which this one is often compared) currently lack.

Motorola also has a better history than most with keeping their phones up to date with the latest Android, which is always important.

Back is grippy is comfortable.

Active Display is REALLY useful. The ability to see basic notification by just bringing your hand close to the screen becomes second nature very quick.

One thing you'll probably want to do is go to developer options and increase the speed of animations. Phone looks a lot slower than it actually is because transitions are artificially made slow. (Google how to do it ;D).

To be honest, would have bought a Nexus 6P if buying it wasn't the complete nightmare Google makes it. But barring that, this is the best cell phone in the market IMHO.

Honestly it's a good phone but it has a s***ty battery. Like I'm connected (Snapchat, Facebook and Instagram mainly) but not that much and the battery lasts not more than 4 hours I had to buy an external battery so I can use my phone all day. Otherwise it's a very convenient phone +++ camera is amazing !

Ordered directly through Motorola. First impressions:best phone I've had. It is a big phone, but doesn't feel big. The screen is same size as the note, but overall it's just a tad smaller because there is less bezel around the screen. Camera is very nice with some cool features. It is very nice to not have Verizon's bloatware on the phone. Moto has a few preinstalled apps but they are usefully and I don't need to get rid of them. The softback is very nice. The bumper case that comes with it is a nice touch. Thw phone is just absolutely beautiful. Activating through Verizon is tricky. But it worked. You just have to get ahold of the right person. We will see how this holds up over time.
Came on time. And works pretty well.

Pros
1. Great design and build quality (metal frame, durable)
2. Great display (5.7" 1440p IPS LCD)
3. Great performance (Qualcomm SD 808 SoC, 3GB RAM)
4. Good cameras (21MP rear-facing, 5MP front-facing w/ LED flash)
5. Outstanding speakers (front-facing dual stereo)
6. Great software (near stock Android 6.0)
7. Incredible charging speed (with the included charger)

Cons
1. Mediocre battery life (3,000mAh)
2. Camera's lowlight performance

Conclusion
The Moto X Pure Edition brings incredible value to the table. In my opinion, it's better than the OnePlus 2 and the Nexus 5X.
Thus phone has been better then I thought and the battery life is great
